['Teacher: How are specific heat and heat capacity related to each other?', 'Heat capacity is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ .']
['What is the equation for heat capacity (C) in terms of mass (m) and specific heat (c)?', 'In equation form, heat capacity C is  $$\\(C = mc\\)$$, where m is mass and c is specific heat.']
['What are the SI units for specific heat (c) and heat capacity (C)?', 'Note that heat capacity is the same as specific heat, but without any dependence on mass.']
['What is the SI unit for heat capacity (C)?', 'Consequently, two objects made up of the same material but with different masses will have different heat capacities.']

['What is the relationship between the mass of an object and its heat capacity?', 'This is because the heat capacity is a property of an object, but specific heat is a property of any object made of the same material.']

['Teacher: Why must values of specific heat be looked up in tables instead of being calculated?', 'Values of specific heat must be looked up in tables, because there is no simple way to calculate them.']
['Teacher: Why is Table 11.2 used as a reference for values of specific heat for substances?', 'Table 11.2 gives the values of specific heat for a few substances as a handy reference.']

['Teacher: How does Table 11.2 provide information about the specific heat of different substances?', 'We see from this table that the specific heat of water is five times that of glass, which means that it takes five times as much heat to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water than to raise the temperature of 1 kg of glass by the same number of degrees.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the three different modes of heat transfer?', 'Whenever there is a temperature difference, heat transfer occurs.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of how heat transfer can occur rapidly and slowly?', 'Heat transfer may happen rapidly, such as through a cooking pan, or slowly, such as through the walls of an insulated cooler.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what conduction, convection, and radiation are in the context of heat transfer?', 'There are three different heat transfer methods: conduction, convection, and radiation.']
['What are the three different heat transfer methods?', 'At times, all three may happen simultaneously.']
['What can you infer from Figure 11.3?', 'See Figure 11.3.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of conduction in everyday life?', 'Conduction is heat transfer through direct physical contact.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain the process of convection and provide an example?', 'Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.']

['Can you provide an example of how people control the conduction of heat to make themselves more comfortable?', 'Sometimes, we try to control the conduction of heat to make ourselves more comfortable.']

["Teacher: That's a great example! Can you explain how choosing a thick wool sweater helps slow down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter?", 'Since the rate of heat transfer is different for different materials, we choose fabrics, such as a thick wool sweater, that slow down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter.']

['Teacher: Why do your feet feel relatively comfortable as you walk barefoot across the living room carpet?', 'As you walk barefoot across the living room carpet, your feet feel relatively comfortable…until you step onto the kitchen’s tile floor.']
['Teacher: What are the three modes of heat transfer?', 'This is explained by different rates of heat transfer:']

['Teacher: How does the transfer of heat occur between objects or substances in the three modes of heat transfer?', 'The tile material removes heat from your skin at a greater rate than the carpeting, which makes it feel colder.']
['Teacher: What is one key factor in determining the rate at which thermal energy is conducted through different materials?', 'Some materials simply conduct thermal energy faster than others.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of materials that are good conductors of heat?', 'In general, metals (like copper, aluminum, gold, and silver) are good heat conductors, whereas materials like wood, plastic, and rubber are poor heat conductors.']

['Teacher: What does Figure 11.4 illustrate regarding the particles in the two bodies at different temperatures?', 'Figure 11.4 shows particles (either atoms or molecules) in two bodies at different temperatures.']

['What does the difference in kinetic energy of the particles in the hot and cold bodies indicate in terms of temperature?', 'The (average) kinetic energy of a particle in the hot body is higher than in the colder body.']

['Teacher: How does the transfer of energy between the particles occur in the context of conduction?', 'If two particles collide, energy transfers from the particle with greater kinetic energy to the particle with less kinetic energy.']

['What is the term used to describe the transfer of heat between two bodies that are in contact with each other?', 'When two bodies are in contact, many particle collisions occur, resulting in a net flux of heat from the higher-temperature body to the lower-temperature body.']

['What are the three main mechanisms of heat transfer discussed in the textbook passage?', 'The heat flux depends on the temperature difference  $$\\(\\Delta T = T_{\\text{hot}} - T_{\\text{cold}}\\)$$ .']
['What factors affect the rate of heat transfer by conduction?', 'Therefore, you will get a more severe burn from boiling water than from hot tap water.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what conduction is?', 'Convection is heat transfer by the movement of a fluid.']
['What is an example of convection?', 'This type of heat transfer happens, for example, in a pot boiling on the stove, or in thunderstorms, where hot air rises up to the base of the clouds.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the expansion of fluids as temperature increases is related to the concept of conduction, convection, and radiation?', 'As the temperature of fluids increase, they expand and become less dense.']

['How does the expansion of fluids as temperature increases contribute to the concept of conduction, convection, and radiation?', 'For example, Figure 11.4 could represent the wall of a balloon with different temperature gases inside the balloon than outside in the environment.']

['What is the relationship between the expansion of the gas particles inside the balloon and the concept of conduction, convection, and radiation?', 'The hotter and thus faster moving gas particles inside the balloon strike the surface with more force than the cooler air outside, causing the balloon to expand.']

['What role does the decrease in density of the gas inside the balloon play in the concept of conduction, convection, and radiation?', 'This decrease in density relative to its environment creates buoyancy (the tendency to rise).']

['How is convection related to the buoyancy created by the decrease in density of the gas inside the balloon?', 'Convection is driven by buoyancy—hot air rises because it is less dense than the surrounding air.']
['Teacher: How can we control the temperature of our homes or ourselves by controlling air movement?', 'Sometimes, we control the temperature of our homes or ourselves by controlling air movement.']

["Teacher: That's a great point! Can you give me another example of how controlling air movement can help regulate temperature in our homes or ourselves?", 'Sealing leaks around doors with weather stripping keeps out the cold wind in winter.']

['Can you explain how sealing leaks around doors with weather stripping helps regulate temperature in our homes?', 'The house in Figure 11.5 and the pot of water on the stove in Figure 11.6 are both examples of convection and buoyancy by human design.']

['What are some examples of natural convection?', 'Ocean currents and large-scale atmospheric circulation transfer energy from one part of the globe to another, and are examples of natural convection.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what happens during radiation in terms of heat transfer?', 'Radiation is a form of heat transfer that occurs when electromagnetic radiation is emitted or absorbed.']

['Teacher: Can you give some examples of electromagnetic radiation that can be involved in radiation as a form of heat transfer?', 'Electromagnetic radiation includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared radiation, visible light, ultraviolet radiation, X-rays, and gamma rays, all of which have different wavelengths and amounts of energy (shorter wavelengths have higher frequency and more energy).']
['Teacher: How do we classify the transfer of heat that occurs from a fire and from the sun?', 'You can feel the heat transfer from a fire and from the sun.']

["Teacher: That's correct! So, would you classify the heat transfer from the fire, sun, and oven as conduction, convection, or radiation?", 'Similarly, you can sometimes tell that the oven is hot without touching its door or looking inside—it may just warm you as you walk by.']

['What type of heat transfer is the student describing when they say the oven may just warm you as you walk by?', 'Another example is thermal radiation from the human body; people are constantly emitting infrared radiation, which is not visible to the human eye, but is felt as heat.']

["Teacher: That's correct, radiation is a unique method of heat transfer. Can you please explain the concept of conduction and give an example of how it occurs?", 'Radiation is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required, meaning that the heat doesn’t need to come into direct contact with or be transported by any matter.']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Now, can you describe the concept of convection and provide an example of how it occurs?', 'The space between Earth and the sun is largely empty, without any possibility of heat transfer by convection or conduction.']

['Teacher: How is heat transfer between the Earth and the sun primarily achieved?', 'Instead, heat is transferred by radiation, and Earth is warmed as it absorbs electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what Figure 11.7 illustrates about objects?', 'All objects absorb and emit electromagnetic radiation (see Figure 11.7).']

['Teacher: According to Figure 11.7, what is the main factor that affects the rate of heat transfer by radiation?', 'The rate of heat transfer by radiation depends mainly on the color of the object.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of an object that would be a good absorber and radiator of heat based on the information from Figure 11.7?', 'Black is the most effective absorber and radiator, and white is the least effective.']

['Teacher: Why do people living in hot climates generally avoid wearing black clothing, according to the information from Figure 11.7?', 'People living in hot climates generally avoid wearing black clothing, for instance.']

['Teacher: How does the heat transfer through conduction differ from heat transfer through radiation, based on the information from Figure 11.7?', 'Similarly, black asphalt in a parking lot will be hotter than adjacent patches of grass on a summer day, because black absorbs better than green.']
['Teacher: How do conduction and radiation differ in terms of heat absorption and emission, according to Figure 11.7?', 'The reverse is also true—black radiates better than green.']

['According to Figure 11.7, what is the main factor that affects the rate of heat transfer by conduction?', 'On a clear summer night, the black asphalt will be colder than the green patch of grass, because black radiates energy faster than green.']
['According to Figure 11.7, how does the rate of heat transfer by convection compare to the rate of heat transfer by conduction?', 'In contrast, white is a poor absorber and also a poor radiator.']
['What does Figure 11.7 suggest about the behavior of a white object when it comes to absorbing and reflecting radiation?', 'A white object reflects nearly all radiation, like a mirror.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, let's apply that knowledge to phase changes. Can you explain how adding thermal energy affects the phase of a substance?", 'So far, we have learned that adding thermal energy by heat increases the temperature of a substance.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a situation where adding thermal energy does not change the temperature of a substance?', 'But surprisingly, there are situations where adding energy does not change the temperature of a substance at all!']

['Can you explain what happens to the bonds between molecules or atoms when thermal energy is added during a phase change?', 'Instead, the additional thermal energy acts to loosen bonds between molecules or atoms and causes a phase change.']

['What is the term used to describe the energy that enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change?', 'Because this energy enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change in the system, it is known as latent heat (latent means hidden).']

['Teacher: Can you please explain what the figure in the textbook shows regarding the three phases of matter?', 'The three phases of matter that you frequently encounter are solid, liquid and gas (see Figure 11.8).']

['Teacher: What does Figure 11.8 in the textbook illustrate about the arrangement and movement of particles in the solid phase of matter?', 'Solid has the least energetic state; atoms in solids are in close contact, with forces between them that allow the particles to vibrate but not change position with neighboring particles.']

['What is the state of energy and the arrangement of particles in the liquid phase of matter?', '(These forces can be thought of as springs that can be stretched or compressed, but not easily broken.)']

['Teacher: Can you compare the characteristics of liquid and gas in terms of their particle behavior and energy levels?', 'Gas has a more energetic state than liquid, in which particles are broken free of their bonds.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why particles in liquids are still held together by their mutual attraction even though they can slide smoothly past one another and change neighbors?', 'Particles in gases are separated by distances that are large compared with the size of the particles.']
['Teacher: What is the characteristic state of a liquid in terms of the movement of its particles?', 'The most energetic state of all is plasma.']

["Teacher: That's true, plasma is indeed the most energetic state of matter. However, in the context of the passage we are discussing, what is the characteristic state of a liquid in terms of the movement of its particles?", 'Although you may not have heard much about plasma, it is actually the most common state of matter in the universe—stars are made up of plasma, as is lightning.']

["Teacher: Good explanation of plasma! Now, let's refocus on the passage we're discussing. Can you tell me what happens to the particles in a liquid when it comes to their movement and arrangement?", 'The plasma state is reached by heating a gas to the point where particles are pulled apart, separating the electrons from the rest of the particle.']

["Teacher: That's correct, but let's stay focused on the characteristics of liquids. In regards to the movement of particles in a liquid, what happens to the particles in terms of sliding past one another and changing neighbors?", 'This produces an ionized gas that is a combination of the negatively charged free electrons and positively charged ions, known as plasma.']
['Teacher: Why is energy required to melt a solid?', 'Energy is required to melt a solid because the bonds between the particles in the solid must be broken.']

['What is the relationship between the breaking of bonds and the increase in kinetic energies of the particles during a phase change?', 'Since the energy involved in a phase changes is used to break bonds, there is no increase in the kinetic energies of the particles, and therefore no rise in temperature.']
['What is the purpose of energy in the process of vaporizing a liquid?', 'Similarly, energy is needed to vaporize a liquid to overcome the attractive forces between particles in the liquid.']
['What is the role of energy in the process of condensation?', 'There is no temperature change until a phase change is completed.']

['What is the reason for the temperature staying at 0 degrees Celsius until all of the ice has melted?', 'The temperature of a cup of soda and ice that is initially at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  stays at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  until all of the ice has melted.']

['What happens to the energy during the process of freezing and condensation?', 'In the reverse of these processes—freezing and condensation—energy is released from the latent heat (see Figure 11.9).']

['Teacher: What are the meanings of the symbols  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  in the equation  $$\\(Q = mL_{v}\\)$$  for vaporization/condensation?', 'where  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  is the latent heat of fusion, and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  is the latent heat of vaporization.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the latent heat of vaporization represents and when it is applicable?', 'The latent heat of fusion is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between solid and liquid.']

['Teacher: What is the difference between the latent heat of fusion and the latent heat of vaporization in terms of the phase changes they represent?', 'The latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas.']

['Teacher: How do the coefficients $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$ and $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$ vary between substances and what units are they typically measured in?', '$$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  are coefficients that vary from substance to substance, depending on the strength of intermolecular forces, and both have standard units of J/kg.']
['Teacher: Where can you find values of \\(L_f\\) and \\(L_v\\) for different substances?', 'See Table 11.3 for values of  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  of different substances.']

['Teacher: What equation describes the relationship between the amount of heat added and the change in mass during vaporization or condensation?', 'Let’s consider the example of adding heat to ice to examine its transitions through all three phases—solid to liquid to gas.']

['Teacher: Does Figure 11.10 in the textbook show the changes in temperature as heat is added to water?', 'A phase diagram indicating the temperature changes of water as energy is added is shown in Figure 11.10.']

['What does the phase diagram in Figure 11.10 show about the temperature changes of water as heat is added?', 'The ice starts out at −20 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, and its temperature rises linearly, absorbing heat at a constant rate until it reaches 0 $$\\(\\text{°}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the name of the phase change that occurs at 0 degrees Celsius on the phase diagram in Figure 11.10?', 'Once at this temperature, the ice gradually melts, absorbing 334 kJ/kg.']

['What is the name of the phase change that occurs when the ice gradually melts at a constant temperature on the phase diagram in Figure 11.10?', 'The temperature remains constant at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  during this phase change.']

['What is the name of the phase change that occurs once all the ice has melted and the temperature of the liquid water starts to rise on the phase diagram in Figure 11.10?', 'Once all the ice has melted, the temperature of the liquid water rises, absorbing heat at a new constant rate.']

['What is the name of the phase change that occurs at 100 degrees Celsius on the phase diagram in Figure 11.10?', 'At 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, the water begins to boil and the temperature again remains constant while the water absorbs 2256 kJ/kg during this phase change.']

['What is the name of the phase change that occurs once all the liquid has become steam and the temperature starts to rise on the phase diagram in Figure 11.10?', 'When all the liquid has become steam, the temperature rises again at a constant rate.']

['Teacher: What is the equation that represents the relationship between heat transfer and the mass of a substance for vaporization/condensation?', 'We have seen that vaporization requires heat transfer to a substance from its surroundings.']

['Teacher: That\'s correct! Now, can you please complete the sentence: "Condensation is the reverse process, where heat is transferred ___?"', 'Condensation is the reverse process, where heat in transferred away from a substance to its surroundings.']

['What is the equation that represents the relationship between heat transfer and the mass of a substance for condensation?', 'This release of latent heat increases the temperature of the surroundings.']

['What is the equation that represents the relationship between heat transfer and the mass of a substance for vaporization/condensation in the context of condensation?', 'Energy must be removed from the condensing particles to make a vapor condense.']

['What is the equation that represents the relationship between heat transfer and the mass of a substance for condensation in the context of condensation occurring on cold surfaces?', 'This is why condensation occurs on cold surfaces: the heat transfers energy away from the warm vapor to the cold surface.']

['What equation can be used to calculate the energy transfer for condensation occurring on cold surfaces?', 'The energy is exactly the same as that required to cause the phase change in the other direction, from liquid to vapor, and so it can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{v}\\)$$ .']

['What equation can be used to calculate the energy transfer for vaporization?', 'Latent heat is also released into the environment when a liquid freezes, and can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{f}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: What is the process by which heat transfers thermal energy from an object at a higher temperature to one at a lower temperature until they reach equilibrium?', 'We learned in the previous chapter that when two objects (or systems) are in contact with one another, heat will transfer thermal energy from the object at higher temperature to the one at lower temperature until they both reach the same temperature.']

['What happens when two objects at different temperatures come into contact with each other?', 'The objects are then in thermal equilibrium, and no further temperature changes will occur if they are isolated from other systems.']

['What is the term used to describe the state when two objects at different temperatures come into contact with each other?', 'The systems interact and change because their temperatures are different, and the changes stop once their temperatures are the same.']

['What is the term used to describe the state when two bodies are in thermal contact with each other and heat transfer can occur between them?', 'Thermal equilibrium is established when two bodies are in thermal contact with each other—meaning heat transfer (i.e., the transfer of energy by heat) can occur between them.']
['What is necessary for two systems to reach thermal equilibrium?', 'If two systems cannot freely exchange energy, they will not reach thermal equilibrium.']

['Why is it fortunate that empty space stands between Earth and the sun?', '(It is fortunate that empty space stands between Earth and the sun, because a state of thermal equilibrium with the sun would be too toasty for life on this planet!)']

['Teacher: According to the passage on Section Key Terms, can you explain the concept of thermal equilibrium and its relationship between three systems A, B, and C?', 'If two systems, A and B, are in thermal equilibrium with each another, and B is in thermal equilibrium with a third system, C, then A is also in thermal equilibrium with C.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to understand the concept of thermal equilibrium in the context of thermodynamics?', 'This statement may seem obvious, because all three have the same temperature, but it is basic to thermodynamics.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the significance of the zeroth law of thermodynamics in relation to the concept of thermal equilibrium?', 'It is called the zeroth law of thermodynamics.']

['Teacher: Why did scientists decide that this law should logically come first, even though it was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics?', 'The explanation is that this law was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics but is so fundamental that scientists decided it should logically come first.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example that demonstrates the zeroth law of the textbook's section on key terms?", 'As an example of the zeroth law in action, consider newborn babies in neonatal intensive-care units in hospitals.']
['Teacher: How do hospitals ensure that premature or sick newborns are cared for according to the zeroth law?', 'Prematurely born or sick newborns are placed in special incubators.']

['What is the purpose of placing premature or sick newborns in special incubators?', 'These babies have very little covering while in the incubators, so to an observer, they look as though they may not be warm enough.']

['What principle of the zeroth law is exemplified by the fact that the air, the cot, and the baby inside the incubator are all at the same temperature?', 'However, inside the incubator, the temperature of the air, the cot, and the baby are all the same—that is, they are in thermal equilibrium.']

['What is the significance of maintaining thermal equilibrium between the air, cot, and baby inside the incubator?', 'The ambient temperature is just high enough to keep the baby safe and comfortable.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why understanding the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature is important before covering the first law of thermodynamics?', 'Before covering the first law of thermodynamics, it is first important to understand the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.']
['the force exerted per unit area on a surface.', 'Pressure, P, is defined as']

['Teacher: Why is the SI unit for pressure, the pascal, particularly important when discussing fluids?', 'Pressure is defined for all states of matter but is particularly important when discussing fluids (such as air).']

['Teacher: How else is the concept of pressure, specifically related to fluids, commonly used or referred to in everyday contexts?', 'You have probably heard the word pressure being used in relation to blood (high or low blood pressure) and in relation to the weather (high- and low-pressure weather systems).']
['Teacher: Can you provide some other examples of situations where the concept of pressure in fluids is commonly used or referred to?', 'These are only two of many examples of pressures in fluids.']
['Teacher: What is the unit of measurement for pressure in the SI system?', 'The relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas is given by the ideal gas law.']

['Teacher: What is the equation that represents the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas?', 'A gas is considered ideal at low pressure and fairly high temperature, and forces between its component particles can be ignored.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a gas that is considered ideal?', 'The ideal gas law states that']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the meaning of each variable in the equation $$PV = NkT$$ and how they are related to the gas?', 'where P is the pressure of a gas, V is the volume it occupies, N is the number of particles (atoms or molecules) in the gas, and T is its absolute temperature.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the significance of the Boltzmann constant in the equation PV = NkT and its unit of measurement?', 'The constant k is called the Boltzmann constant and has the value  $$\\(k = 1.38 \\times 10^{-23}\\text{J/K}\\text{,}\\)$$']

['Teacher: How does the Boltzmann constant affect the relationship between pressure, volume, number of particles, and absolute temperature in the ideal gas law equation PV = NkT?', 'For the purposes of this chapter, we will not go into calculations using the ideal gas law.']

['Teacher: What is important to notice from the equation PV = NkT for a given mass of gas?', 'Instead, it is important for us to notice from the equation that the following are true for a given mass of gas:']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what happens to the pressure when the volume is constant?', 'When volume is constant, pressure is directly proportional to temperature.']

["Teacher: Fantastic! Now, let's flip it around. According to the passage, what happens to the pressure when the temperature is constant?", 'When temperature is constant, pressure is inversely proportional to volume.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, what can you conclude about the relationship between volume and temperature when the pressure is constant?', 'When pressure is constant, volume is directly proportional to temperature.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of thermal expansion and how it relates to the given equation $$PV = NkT$$?', 'This last point describes thermal expansion—the change in size or volume of a given mass with temperature.']

['Teacher: How does an increase in temperature affect the kinetic energy of individual atoms?', 'An increase in temperature means that there’s an increase in the kinetic energy of the individual atoms.']

['Teacher: How does the increase in temperature affect the overall volume of a gas, liquid, and solid?', 'Gases are especially affected by thermal expansion, although liquids expand to a lesser extent with similar increases in temperature, and even solids have minor expansions at higher temperatures.']

['Teacher: Why do railroad tracks and bridges have expansion joints?', 'This is why railroad tracks and bridges have expansion joints that allow them to freely expand and contract with temperature changes.']

['Teacher: How does pumping air into a deflated tire relate to the relationship among pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas?', 'To get some idea of how pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas are related to one another, consider what happens when you pump air into a deflated tire.']

['Teacher: What can you infer about the relationship between volume and pressure based on the initially observed behavior of the tire when air is pumped into it?', 'The tire’s volume first increases in direct proportion to the amount of air injected, without much increase in the tire pressure.']

['Teacher: What can you conclude about the relationship between volume and pressure once the tire has expanded to nearly its full size?', 'Once the tire has expanded to nearly its full size, the walls limit volume expansion.']

['Teacher: Based on the observed behavior of the tire, what relationship can you deduce between pressure and temperature when the volume is nearly constant?', 'If you continue to pump air into tire (which now has a nearly constant volume), the pressure increases with increasing temperature (see Figure 12.4).']
['Teacher: What is pressure–volume work?', 'Pressure–volume work is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of when pressure–volume work occurs?', 'Whenever there is a change in volume and external pressure remains constant, pressure–volume work is taking place.']

['Teacher: How does the change in volume affect the internal pressure during a compression?', 'During a compression, a decrease in volume increases the internal pressure of a system as work is done on the system.']

['Teacher: How does the change in volume affect the internal pressure during an expansion?', 'During an expansion (Figure 12.5), an increase in volume decreases the internal pressure of a system as the system does work.']

['Teacher: Good job recalling the formula for work! Now, how is the formula for work specifically related to the concept of Pressure-Volume work?', 'Recall that the formula for work is  $$\\(W = Fd.\\)$$']

["Teacher: That's correct! So, how can we express force in terms of pressure using the equation you mentioned?", 'We can rearrange the definition of pressure,  $$\\(P = \\frac{F}{A},\\)$$  to get an expression for force in terms of pressure.']

['Teacher: How can we express work, in terms of pressure and change in volume, for fluids?', 'Just as we say that work is force acting over a distance, for fluids, we can say that work is the pressure acting through the change in volume.']

['Teacher: In the equation $$\\[W = P\\Delta V\\]$$ for pressure-volume work, can you explain the analogy between pressure and force, and volume and distance?', 'For pressure–volume work, pressure is analogous to force, and volume is analogous to distance in the traditional definition of work.']
['Teacher: What are the two ways to add or remove energy from a system according to the passage?', 'Heat (Q) and work (W) are the two ways to add or remove energy from a system.']
['Can you explain the difference between heat and work in terms of adding or removing energy from a system?', 'The processes are very different.']

['Teacher: How is heat driven in terms of temperature differences, and what is involved in work in terms of energy transfer?', 'Heat is driven by temperature differences, while work involves a force exerted through a distance.']
['What common result can be produced by both heat and work?', 'Nevertheless, heat and work can produce identical results.']
['What is an example of a common result that both heat and work can produce?', 'For example, both can cause a temperature increase.']

['What happens to the air in a bicycle tire when heat is transferred into it from the sun?', 'Heat transfers energy into a system, such as when the sun warms the air in a bicycle tire and increases the air’s temperature.']
['How is work done on the system when the bicyclist pumps air into the tire?', 'Similarly, work can be done on the system, as when the bicyclist pumps air into the tire.']

['What is the common result produced when heat is transferred into the air in a bicycle tire from the sun and when work is done on the system by pumping air into the tire?', 'Once the temperature increase has occurred, it is impossible to tell whether it was caused by heat or work.']
['What is the key concept regarding heat and work in the context of energy transfer in a system?', 'Heat and work are both energy in transit—neither is stored as such in a system.']
['What is the effect of heat and work on the internal energy of a system?', 'However, both can change the internal energy, U, of a system.']

['Teacher: How would you define internal energy in relation to the atoms and molecules comprising a system?', 'Internal energy is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules.']

['What are some of the subcategories of internal energy?', 'It can be divided into many subcategories, such as thermal and chemical energy, and depends only on the state of a system (that is, P, V, and T), not on how the energy enters or leaves the system.']

['Teacher: How do we conceptualize the connection between heat, work, and internal energy in thermodynamics?', 'In order to understand the relationship between heat, work, and internal energy, we use the first law of thermodynamics.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the first law of thermodynamics applies the conservation of energy principle to systems utilizing heat and work?', 'The first law of thermodynamics applies the conservation of energy principle to systems where heat and work are the methods of transferring energy into and out of the systems.']

['Teacher: How does the first law of thermodynamics describe the transfer of energy in systems involving heat and work?', 'It can also be used to describe how energy transferred by heat is converted and transferred again by work.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the net heat transfer into a closed system represents according to the first law of thermodynamics?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy of a closed system equals the net heat transfer into the system minus the net work done by the system.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, could you please write out the equation that represents the first law of thermodynamics?", 'In equation form, the first law of thermodynamics is']
['Teacher: What does $$\\(\\Delta U\\)$$ represent in the equation $$\\(\\Delta U = Q - W\\)$$?', 'Here,  $$\\(\\Delta U\\)$$ is the change in internal energy, U, of the system.']
['Teacher: How is Q defined in the equation?', 'As shown in Figure 12.6, Q is the net heat transferred into the system—that is, Q is the sum of all heat transfers into and out of the system.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where work is done on the system?', 'W is the net work done by the system—that is, W is the sum of all work done on or by the system.']

['Teacher: How is the sign convention of Q and W determined in the equation?', 'By convention, if Q is positive, then there is a net heat transfer into the system; if W is positive, then there is net work done by the system.']

['Teacher: What does a positive value of Q indicate in terms of energy transfer into the system?', 'So positive Q adds energy to the system by heat, and positive W takes energy from the system by work.']

['Teacher: In the given equation, how is the difference between heat transfer and work represented in terms of the change in internal energy?', 'Note that if heat transfers more energy into the system than that which is done by work, the difference is stored as internal energy.']

["Teacher: That's correct, engines cannot be 100 percent efficient. Now, can you explain why this is the case?", 'Recall from the chapter introduction that it is not even theoretically possible for engines to be 100 percent efficient.']

['Teacher: How does the second law of thermodynamics and the concept of entropy explain the phenomenon of engines not being 100 percent efficient?', 'This phenomenon is explained by the second law of thermodynamics, which relies on a concept known as entropy.']
['What role does entropy play in determining the efficiency of engines?', 'Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.']
['What happens to the entropy of a system as the efficiency of an engine decreases?', 'Entropy also describes how much energy is not available to do work.']
['How does the increase in entropy of a system affect the efficiency of an engine?', "The more disordered a system and higher the entropy, the less of a system's energy is available to do work."]

['Teacher: Why is it not possible to use the entire available energy for work?', 'Although all forms of energy can be used to do work, it is not possible to use the entire available energy for work.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it is not possible to use the entire available energy for work?', 'Consequently, not all energy transferred by heat can be converted into work, and some of it is lost in the form of waste heat—that is, heat that does not go toward doing work.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of waste heat relate to the unavailability of energy in thermodynamics?', 'The unavailability of energy is important in thermodynamics; in fact, the field originated from efforts to convert heat to work, as is done by engines.']

['Teacher: Can you clarify the relationship between the sign of Q and the direction of energy transfer during a process?', 'Q is positive for energy transferred into the system by heat and negative for energy transferred out of the system by heat.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the sign of Q is related to the direction of energy transfer during a process?', 'In SI, entropy is expressed in units of joules per kelvin (J/K).']

['Teacher: How is the SI unit for entropy expressed?', 'If temperature changes during the process, then it is usually a good approximation (for small changes in temperature) to take T to be the average temperature in order to avoid trickier math (calculus).']

['Teacher: What does the passage imply about the relationship between practical jokes and the second law of thermodynamics?', 'If so, you have been on the receiving end of a practical joke and, in the process, learned a valuable lesson about the nature of the universe as described by the second law of thermodynamics.']

['Teacher: How does the game of 52 pickup relate to the second law of thermodynamics?', 'In the game of 52 pickup, the prankster tosses an entire deck of playing cards onto the floor, and you get to pick them up.']

['Teacher: What does the observation made while picking up the cards in the game of 52 pickup indicate about the relationship between the second law of thermodynamics and the amount of work required to restore order?', 'In the process of picking up the cards, you may have noticed that the amount of work required to restore the cards to an orderly state in the deck is much greater than the amount of work required to toss the cards and create the disorder.']

['Teacher: Can you explain to me what the second law of thermodynamics states?', 'The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any spontaneous process; it never decreases.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the second law of thermodynamics relates to the transfer of heat between objects of different temperatures?', 'An important implication of this law is that heat transfers energy spontaneously from higher- to lower-temperature objects, but never spontaneously in the reverse direction.']

['Teacher: How does the second law of thermodynamics explain the direction of heat transfer between objects of different temperatures?', 'This is because entropy increases for heat transfer of energy from hot to cold (Figure 12.9).']

['Teacher: How does the change in temperature affect the change in entropy during heat transfer according to the second law of thermodynamics?', 'Because the change in entropy is Q/T, there is a larger change in  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$  at lower temperatures (smaller T).']

['Teacher: How does the concept of entropy relate to the second law of thermodynamics when considering the change in temperature during heat transfer?', 'The decrease in entropy of the hot (larger T) object is therefore less than the increase in entropy of the cold (smaller T) object, producing an overall increase in entropy for the system.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it is impossible for a process to transfer heat from a cooler object to a hotter object, according to the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'Another way of thinking about this is that it is impossible for any process to have, as its sole result, heat transferring energy from a cooler to a hotter object.']

['Why would the entropy of the overall system decrease if heat were to transfer energy from a cooler to a hotter object?', 'Heat cannot transfer energy spontaneously from colder to hotter, because the entropy of the overall system would decrease.']

['Teacher: What scenario is being considered when we mix equal masses of water at different temperatures?', 'Suppose we mix equal masses of water that are originally at two different temperatures, say  $$\\(\\text{20}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{40}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: What is the concept that explains the change in temperature when we mix two masses of water at different temperatures?', 'The result will be water at an intermediate temperature of  $$\\(\\text{30}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the outcomes of mixing equal masses of water at different temperatures result in an increase in entropy, a decrease in available energy, and a decrease in orderliness of the system?', 'Three outcomes have resulted: entropy has increased, some energy has become unavailable to do work, and the system has become less orderly.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between entropy and the increase in disorderliness of the system when equal masses of water at different temperatures are mixed?', 'Let us think about each of these results.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how mixing two bodies of water is related to the heat transfer of energy between substances of different temperatures?', 'Mixing the two bodies of water has the same effect as the heat transfer of energy from the higher-temperature substance to the lower-temperature substance.']

['Teacher: How does mixing two bodies of water affect the entropy of the hotter and colder water?', 'The mixing decreases the entropy of the hotter water but increases the entropy of the colder water by a greater amount, producing an overall increase in entropy.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what happens to the temperature difference once the two masses of water are mixed?', 'Second, once the two masses of water are mixed, there is no more temperature difference left to drive energy transfer by heat and therefore to do work.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the energy in the water is now unavailable to do work?', 'The energy is still in the water, but it is now unavailable to do work.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the level of orderliness or structure in the mixture according to the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'Third, the mixture is less orderly, or to use another term, less structured.']

['How does the Third Law of Thermodynamics explain the change in the level of orderliness or structure in the mixture compared to the initial state?', 'Rather than having two masses at different temperatures and with different distributions of molecular speeds, we now have a single mass with a broad distribution of molecular speeds, the average of which yields an intermediate temperature.']

['Teacher: How are the three results of entropy, unavailability of energy, and disorder related in terms of the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'These three results—entropy, unavailability of energy, and disorder—not only are related but are, in fact, essentially equivalent.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the transfer of heat from hot to cold, the tendency for systems to become disordered, and the availability of energy for use as work, according to the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'Heat transfer of energy from hot to cold is related to the tendency in nature for systems to become disordered and for less energy to be available for use as work.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why a cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter?', 'A cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter.']

["Why doesn't a cold object in contact with a hot one spontaneously transfer energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter?", 'Nor does a hot, stationary automobile ever spontaneously cool off and start moving.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of a scenario that demonstrates the concept of the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'Another example is the expansion of a puff of gas introduced into one corner of a vacuum chamber.']
['Teacher: Why does the gas never regroup on its own in the corner of the chamber?', 'The gas expands to fill the chamber, but it never regroups on its own in the corner.']

['Teacher: Why is the random motion of the gas molecules not observed to take them back to the corner of the chamber?', 'The random motion of the gas molecules could take them all back to the corner, but this is never observed to happen (Figure 12.10).']

['Teacher: Can you recall what this principle is called in the context of the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', "We've explained that heat never transfers energy spontaneously from a colder to a hotter object."]
['Teacher: Precisely! Now, can you explain why the concept of spontaneity is important in the context of the Second Law of Thermodynamics?', 'The key word here is spontaneously.']

['Why is the concept of spontaneity important when considering the transfer of energy by heat from a colder to hotter object?', 'If we do work on a system, it is possible to transfer energy by heat from a colder to hotter object.']

['What is another example of an application of the laws of thermodynamics that we will be covering in the next section?', "We'll learn more about this in the next section, covering refrigerators as one of the applications of the laws of thermodynamics."]

['Teacher: What is a common misconception about the second law of thermodynamics, particularly regarding the concept of entropy?', 'Sometimes people misunderstand the second law of thermodynamics, thinking that based on this law, it is impossible for entropy to decrease at any particular location.']

['Teacher: How does the second law of thermodynamics allow for the entropy of one part of the universe to decrease while still maintaining an overall increase in entropy?', 'But, it actually is possible for the entropy of one part of the universe to decrease, as long as the total change in entropy of the universe increases.']
['dS_universe = dS_system + dS_surroundings > 0.', 'In equation form, we can write this as']
['Teacher: Why is energy transfer necessary?', 'Energy transfer is necessary.']

['Teacher: How does the decrease in entropy of the system relate to the necessity of energy transfer?', 'If you pick up marbles that are scattered about the room and put them into a cup, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how work decreasing the entropy of a system can be related to energy transfer?', 'If you gather iron ore from the ground and convert it into steel and build a bridge, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']

['Teacher: How does energy coming from the sun decreasing the entropy of local systems on Earth relate to the necessity of energy transfer?', 'Energy coming from the sun can decrease the entropy of local systems on Earth—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{syst}}\\)$$  is negative.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the decrease in entropy of the system and the overall increase in entropy of the rest of the universe?', 'But the overall entropy of the rest of the universe increases by a greater amount—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{envir}}\\)$$  is positive and greater in magnitude.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of entropy relate to the energy transfer from the sun to Earth and the rest of the universe?', 'In the case of the iron ore, although you made the system of the bridge and steel more structured, you did so at the expense of the universe.']

['Teacher: How does the increase in entropy of the universe relate to the energy transfer from the sun to Earth and the rest of the universe?', 'Altogether, the entropy of the universe is increased by the disorder created by digging up the ore and converting it to steel.']

['Teacher: How can we determine the direction of energy transfer between the system and the environment based on the entropy changes?\nStudent: By analyzing the entropy changes, we can determine whether energy transfer is necessary and the direction it takes.', 'Therefore,']

['Teacher: How does Earth experience changes in entropy when energy from the sun is transferred into deep space and used to perform work?', 'Every time a plant stores some solar energy in the form of chemical potential energy, or an updraft of warm air lifts a soaring bird, Earth experiences local decreases in entropy as it uses part of the energy transfer from the sun into deep space to do work.']

["Teacher: What is the overall effect on Earth's entropy when energy from the sun is transferred into deep space and used to perform work?", 'There is a large total increase in entropy resulting from this massive energy transfer.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why the overall effect on Earth's entropy is a large increase despite the occurrence of smaller, local decreases in entropy?", 'A small part of this energy transfer by heat is stored in structured systems on Earth, resulting in much smaller, local decreases in entropy.']

['Teacher: How is entropy related to the availability of energy to do work and the measure of disorder?', 'Entropy is related not only to the unavailability of energy to do work; it is also a measure of disorder.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a process that demonstrates how entropy is related to the measure of disorder?', 'For example, in the case of a melting block of ice, a highly structured and orderly system of water molecules changes into a disorderly liquid, in which molecules have no fixed positions (Figure 12.11).']

['Teacher: What factors contribute to the increase in entropy during the process of melting a block of ice?', "There is a large increase in entropy for this process, as we'll see in the following worked example."]
['Teacher: What is the purpose of a heat engine?', 'A heat engine does exactly this—it makes use of the properties of thermodynamics to transform heat into work.']
['Teacher: Can you name some examples of heat engines?', 'Gasoline and diesel engines, jet engines, and steam turbines that generate electricity are all examples of heat engines.']
['Teacher: How does Figure 12.13 demonstrate the way in which heat transfers energy to do work?', 'Figure 12.13 illustrates one of the ways in which heat transfers energy to do work.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how fuel combustion leads to the transfer of chemical energy in Figure 12.13?', 'Fuel combustion releases chemical energy that heat transfers throughout the gas in a cylinder.']

['Teacher: How does the increased pressure of the gas affect the movement of the movable piston in Figure 12.13?', 'This increases the gas temperature, which in turn increases the pressure of the gas and, therefore, the force it exerts on a movable piston.']
['Teacher: What does the movement of the piston in Figure 12.13 ultimately result in?', 'The gas does work on the outside world, as this force moves the piston through some distance.']
['Teacher: How does the process described in Figure 12.13 relate to the laws of thermodynamics?', 'Thus, heat transfer of energy to the gas in the cylinder results in work being done.']
['Teacher: What is required for the piston to be returned to its starting point in order to repeat the process?', 'To repeat this process, the piston needs to be returned to its starting point.']

['What causes the pressure of the gas to decrease and the surroundings to exert a force on the piston?', 'Heat now transfers energy from the gas to the surroundings, so that the gas’s pressure decreases, and a force is exerted by the surroundings to push the piston back through some distance.']

['Teacher: What is the characteristic of a cyclical process in terms of the system it involves?', 'A cyclical process brings a system, such as the gas in a cylinder, back to its original state at the end of every cycle.']
['Teacher: What are some examples of heat engines that you can think of?', 'All heat engines use cyclical processes.']
['Teacher: How do heat engines work in terms of the laws of thermodynamics?', 'Heat engines do work by using part of the energy transferred by heat from some source.']

['What is the purpose of heat transfers in a heat engine?', 'As shown in Figure 12.14, heat transfers energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, from the high-temperature object (or hot reservoir), whereas heat transfers unused energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, into the low-temperature object (or cold reservoir), and the work done by the engine is W.']

['What is the role of a reservoir in a heat engine?', 'In physics, a reservoir is defined as an infinitely large mass that can take in or put out an unlimited amount of heat, depending upon the needs of the system.']

['What are the roles of the temperatures  $$\\(T_{\\text{h}}\\text{,}\\)$$  and  $$\\(T_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  in a heat engine?', 'The temperature of the hot reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{h}}\\text{,}\\)$$  and the temperature of the cold reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: What is the significance of a cyclical process in the operation of heat engines, heat pumps, and refrigerators, as mentioned in the passage?', 'As noted, a cyclical process brings the system back to its original condition at the end of every cycle.']

['What is the relationship between a cyclical process and the internal energy, U, of a system?', 'Such a system’s internal energy, U, is the same at the beginning and end of every cycle—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta U = 0\\)$$ .']

['What is the equation that relates the change in internal energy, heat transfer, and work done by the system, according to the first law of thermodynamics?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that  $$\\(\\Delta U = Q - W\\text{,}\\)$$  where Q is the net heat transfer during the cycle, and W is the net work done by the system.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the equation for net heat transfer, Q, in relation to the operation of heat engines, heat pumps, and refrigerators?', 'The net heat transfer is the energy transferred in by heat from the hot reservoir minus the amount that is transferred out to the cold reservoir ( $$\\(Q = Q_{\\text{h}} - Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ ).']

['Teacher: What about the net work done by the system in a complete cycle? Can you explain its significance?', 'Because there is no change in internal energy for a complete cycle ( $$\\(\\Delta U = 0\\)$$ ), we have']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the work to be done as efficiently as possible in the cyclical process where the hot reservoir is heated externally?', 'Because the hot reservoir is heated externally, which is an energy-intensive process, it is important that the work be done as efficiently as possible.']

['What is the specific goal we want to achieve in terms of work and heat in the cyclical process where the hot reservoir is heated externally?', 'In fact, we want W to equal  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, and for there to be no heat to the environment (that is,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}} = 0\\)$$ ).']
['Can you explain why achieving a cycle with  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}} = 0\\)$$ in the cyclical process where the hot reservoir is heated externally is impossible?', 'Unfortunately, this is impossible.']

['What is one of the key principles stated by the second law of thermodynamics that explains why achieving a cycle with Qc = 0 in the cyclical process where the hot reservoir is heated externally is impossible?', 'According to the second law of thermodynamics, heat engines cannot have perfect conversion of heat into work.']

['What is the relationship between entropy and the efficiency of a heat engine according to the second law of thermodynamics?', 'Recall that entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system, which is also how much energy is unavailable to do work.']

['What does the second law of thermodynamics require in terms of the total entropy of a system in any process?', 'The second law of thermodynamics requires that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any process.']

['What does the minimum amount of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$ that cannot be used for work indicate according to the second law of thermodynamics?', 'Therefore, there is a minimum amount of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  that cannot be used for work.']

['What does the efficiency of the heat engine determine in terms of the amount of heat rejected to the cold reservoir,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$?', 'The amount of heat rejected to the cold reservoir,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\text{,}\\)$$  depends upon the efficiency of the heat engine.']

['What is the relationship between the increase in entropy, ΔS, and the amount of heat rejected to the cold reservoir, Qc, according to the second law of thermodynamics?', 'The smaller the increase in entropy,  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$ , the smaller the value of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, and the more heat energy is available to do work.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the heat transfer of energy from low to high temperatures in heat pumps, air conditioners, and refrigerators is different from what heat engines do?', 'Heat pumps, air conditioners, and refrigerators utilize heat transfer of energy from low to high temperatures, which is the opposite of what heat engines do.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the difference between the heat transfer in heat pumps, air conditioners, and refrigerators and the heat transfer in heat engines in terms of the direction of energy transfer from low to high temperatures?', 'Heat transfers energy  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from a cold reservoir and delivers energy  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  into a hot one.']

['Teacher: How is the transfer of energy from low to high temperatures in heat engines different from that in heat pumps, air conditioners, and refrigerators in terms of the requirement of work input?', 'This requires work input, W, which produces a transfer of energy by heat.']
['Q_h = Q_c + W.', 'Therefore, the total heat transfer to the hot reservoir is']

['Teacher: What equation represents the relationship between the amount of heat gained by the hot reservoir, the amount of heat lost by the cold reservoir, and the work done by a heat pump?', 'The purpose of a heat pump is to transfer energy by heat to a warm environment, such as a home in the winter.']

['W\\) and uses a relatively small amount of electrical energy to do so.', 'The great advantage of using a heat pump to keep your home warm rather than just burning fuel in a fireplace or furnace is that a heat pump supplies  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}} = Q_{\\text{c}} +']

['What is the formula that represents the relationship between the amount of heat gained by the hot reservoir, the amount of heat lost by the cold reservoir, and the work done by a heat pump?', 'W\\)$$ .']
['What are the hot reservoir and cold reservoir in the equation?', 'Heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  comes from the outside air, even at a temperature below freezing, to the indoor space.']
['What does the hot reservoir in the equation represent?', 'You only pay for W, and you get an additional heat transfer of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from the outside at no cost.']

['Why is it advantageous to use a heat pump to keep your home warm instead of burning fuel in a fireplace or furnace?', 'In many cases, at least twice as much energy is transferred to the heated space as is used to run the heat pump.']
['What is the advantage of using a heat pump to keep your home warm instead of burning fuel in a fireplace or furnace?', 'When you burn fuel to keep warm, you pay for all of it.']

['What equation represents the relationship between the amount of heat gained by the hot reservoir, the amount of heat lost by the cold reservoir, and the work done by a heat pump in the context of a heat pump being more advantageous than burning fuel in a fireplace or furnace?', 'The disadvantage to a heat pump is that the work input (required by the second law of thermodynamics) is sometimes more expensive than simply burning fuel, especially if the work is provided by electrical energy.']

['Teacher: Can you recall the equation that relates the heat absorbed by the hot reservoir, the heat released by the cold reservoir, and the work done by the heat pump?', 'The basic components of a heat pump are shown in Figure 12.15.']
["Teacher: That's correct. Now, can you tell me what is the function of the working fluid, such as a refrigerant, in a heat pump system?", 'A working fluid, such as a refrigerant, is used.']

['What happens to the working fluid in the outdoor coils (the evaporator) of a heat pump?', 'In the outdoor coils (the evaporator), heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  enters the working fluid from the cold outdoor air, turning it into a gas.']

['Teacher: How does the electrically driven compressor affect the temperature and pressure of the gas in the system?', 'The electrically driven compressor (work input W) raises the temperature and pressure of the gas and forces it into the condenser coils that are inside the heated space.']

['Teacher: Why does the heat transfer from the gas to the room and cause the gas to condense into a liquid?', 'Because the temperature of the gas is higher than the temperature inside the room, heat transfers energy to the room, and the gas condenses into a liquid.']
['Teacher: What happens to the pressure and temperature of the gas as it flows through the expansion valve?', 'The liquid then flows back through an expansion (pressure-reducing) valve.']
['Teacher: What is the purpose of the expansion valve in the system?', 'The liquid, having been cooled through expansion, returns to the outdoor evaporator coils to resume the cycle.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of air conditioners and refrigerators in terms of heat transfer?', 'Air conditioners and refrigerators are designed to cool substances by transferring energy by heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  out of a cool environment to a warmer one, where heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  is given up.']
['Teacher: How is the quality of a heat pump judged?', 'In the case of a refrigerator, heat is moved out of the inside of the fridge into the surrounding room.']
['Teacher: How is the quality of a heat pump judged in terms of energy transfer and input work?', 'For an air conditioner, heat is transferred outdoors from inside a home.']

['Teacher: How is the quality of a heat pump judged in terms of energy transfer and input work in relation to cooling substances like air conditioners and refrigerators?', 'Heat pumps are also often used in a reverse setting to cool rooms in the summer.']
['Teacher: What is the relationship between work input and heat transfer of energy in heat pumps?', 'As with heat pumps, work input is required for heat transfer of energy from cold to hot.']

['Teacher: How is the quality of air conditioners and refrigerators judged in terms of energy removed by heat from a cold environment and the amount of work required?', 'The quality of air conditioners and refrigerators is judged by how much energy is removed by heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from a cold environment, compared with how much work, W, is required.']

['Teacher: In the context of heat pumps and refrigerators, what is considered the energy benefit in a heat pump and waste heat in a refrigerator?', 'So, what is considered the energy benefit in a heat pump, is considered waste heat in a refrigerator.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the ratio between the useful work output and the total energy input in a process?', 'In the conversion of energy into work, we are always faced with the problem of getting less out than we put in.']

['Teacher: What term is used to describe the situation where there is a difference between the useful work output and the total energy input in a process, due to the transfer of energy to the environment?', 'The problem is that, in all processes, there is some heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  that transfers energy to the environment—and usually a very significant amount at that.']

['Teacher: What term is used to quantify how efficiently a machine runs in terms of the ratio between the useful work output and the energy input from heat transfer to the environment?', 'A way to quantify how efficiently a machine runs is through a quantity called thermal efficiency.']

['Teacher: How do we define thermal efficiency, Eff, in terms of energy input and energy output?', 'We define thermal efficiency, Eff, to be the ratio of useful energy output to the energy input (or, in other words, the ratio of what we get to what we spend).']

['Teacher: Can you express the formula for thermal efficiency, Eff, in terms of the variables mentioned in the passage?', 'The efficiency of a heat engine is the output of net work, W, divided by heat-transferred energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, into the engine; that is']
['Teacher: Can you explain what a wave is?', 'A wave is a disturbance that travels or propagates from the place where it was created.']
["Teacher: That's correct. Can you now differentiate between mechanical and non-mechanical waves?", 'Waves transfer energy from one place to another, but they do not necessarily transfer any mass.']
['Teacher: How do mechanical waves differ from non-mechanical waves in terms of their transfer of energy?', 'Light, sound, and waves in the ocean are common examples of waves.']
['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a non-mechanical wave?', 'Sound and water waves are mechanical waves; meaning, they require a medium to travel through.']

['Teacher: How does the medium affect the speed of a mechanical wave?', 'The medium may be a solid, a liquid, or a gas, and the speed of the wave depends on the material properties of the medium through which it is traveling.']
['What is an example of a non-mechanical wave that can travel through a vacuum?', 'However, light is not a mechanical wave; it can travel through a vacuum such as the empty parts of outer space.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a familiar wave that you can easily imagine?', 'A familiar wave that you can easily imagine is the water wave.']

['What is an example of disturbance for water waves?', 'For water waves, the disturbance is in the surface of the water, an example of which is the disturbance created by a rock thrown into a pond or by a swimmer splashing the water surface repeatedly.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a disturbance that creates sound waves?', 'For sound waves, the disturbance is caused by a change in air pressure, an example of which is when the oscillating cone inside a speaker creates a disturbance.']

['What are some examples of disturbances that create earthquake waves?', 'For earthquakes, there are several types of disturbances, which include the disturbance of Earth’s surface itself and the pressure disturbances under the surface.']
['What is an example of a familiar wave that can help us understand the behavior of radio waves?', 'Even radio waves are most easily understood using an analogy with water waves.']

['How can visualizing water waves help in studying other types of waves, especially those that are not visible?', 'Because water waves are common and visible, visualizing water waves may help you in studying other types of waves, especially those that are not visible.']

['Teacher: What is the difference between the waves generated when you drop a pebble into the water and the waves in a wave pool?', 'If you drop a pebble into the water, only a few waves may be generated before the disturbance dies down, whereas in a wave pool, the waves are continuous.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by a pulse wave in the context of the pebble example you mentioned?', 'A pulse wave is a sudden disturbance in which only one wave or a few waves are generated, such as in the example of the pebble.']
['Teacher: Can you provide another real-life example where pulse waves are generated, besides the pebble dropping into water?', 'Thunder and explosions also create pulse waves.']

['Teacher: What is an example of a real-life situation where periodic waves are generated, besides a wave pool?', 'A periodic wave repeats the same oscillation for several cycles, such as in the case of the wave pool, and is associated with simple harmonic motion.']

['Teacher: How is the motion of particles in periodic waves different from the motion of particles in pulse waves?', 'Each particle in the medium experiences simple harmonic motion in periodic waves by moving back and forth periodically through the same positions.']
['Teacher: What should we consider about the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2?', 'Consider the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2.']
['Teacher: How is the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2 characterized?', 'This wave is an up-and-down disturbance of the water surface, characterized by a sine wave pattern.']
['Teacher: What are the uppermost and lowest positions called in the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2?', 'The uppermost position is called the crest and the lowest is the trough.']

['Teacher: How does the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2 affect the motion of the seagull?', 'It causes a seagull to move up and down in simple harmonic motion as the wave crests and troughs pass under the bird.']

['Teacher: How are mechanical waves categorized based on their type of motion?', 'Mechanical waves are categorized by their type of motion and fall into any of two categories: transverse or longitudinal.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of each type of mechanical wave, either transverse or longitudinal?', 'Note that both transverse and longitudinal waves can be periodic.']

['Teacher: How does a longitudinal wave propagate in relation to its disturbance and direction of propagation?', 'A transverse wave propagates so that the disturbance is perpendicular to the direction of propagation.']

['What is the difference between the direction of propagation and the direction of disturbance in a longitudinal wave?', 'An example of a transverse wave is shown in Figure 13.3, where a woman moves a toy spring up and down, generating waves that propagate away from herself in the horizontal direction while disturbing the toy spring in the vertical direction.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the disturbance in a longitudinal wave differs from the disturbance in a transverse wave?', 'In contrast, in a longitudinal wave, the disturbance is parallel to the direction of propagation.']

['Teacher: How does the disturbance in a longitudinal wave compare to the direction of propagation?', 'Figure 13.4 shows an example of a longitudinal wave, where the woman now creates a disturbance in the horizontal direction—which is the same direction as the wave propagation—by stretching and then compressing the toy spring.']
['Teacher: Can you please explain the different types of waves?', 'Waves may be transverse, longitudinal, or a combination of the two.']

['Teacher: How are the waves on the strings of musical instruments and electromagnetic waves, such as visible light, classified in terms of their wave properties?', 'The waves on the strings of musical instruments are transverse (as shown in Figure 13.5), and so are electromagnetic waves, such as visible light.']
['Teacher: How are sound waves in air and water classified in terms of their wave properties?', 'Sound waves in air and water are longitudinal.']

['Teacher: How would you classify longitudinal waves in terms of their wave properties and what is their mode of transmission?', 'Their disturbances are periodic variations in pressure that are transmitted in fluids.']

["Teacher: That's correct, sound waves can indeed be both longitudinal and transverse. Can you give an example of a situation where sound travels as a longitudinal wave?", 'Sound in solids can be both longitudinal and transverse.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where water waves exhibit both transverse and longitudinal motion?', 'Essentially, water waves are also a combination of transverse and longitudinal components, although the simplified water wave illustrated in Figure 13.2 does not show the longitudinal motion of the bird.']
["Teacher: What components do earthquake waves under Earth's surface have?", 'Earthquake waves under Earth’s surface have both longitudinal and transverse components as well.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the characteristics of longitudinal waves in an earthquake?', 'The longitudinal waves in an earthquake are called pressure or P-waves, and the transverse waves are called shear or S-waves.']

['Teacher: How can we differentiate between longitudinal waves and transverse waves when it comes to their propagation speeds?', 'These components have important individual characteristics; for example, they propagate at different speeds.']
['Teacher: What are the names of the surface waves in an earthquake?', 'Earthquakes also have surface waves that are similar to surface waves on water.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what variables have the same basic meaning for waves?', 'For waves, these variables have the same basic meaning.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how amplitude, frequency, and period are all related to the behavior of waves?', 'However, it is helpful to word the definitions in a more specific way that applies directly to waves:']

['Teacher: What are the two additional characteristics of waves besides amplitude, frequency, and period?', 'In addition to amplitude, frequency, and period, their wavelength and wave velocity also characterize waves.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Can you explain what we mean by "wave velocity"?', 'The wavelength $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a wave, parallel to the direction of propagation.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you tell me how wave velocity is related to wavelength and frequency?", 'The wave velocity $$\\(v_{w}\\)$$  is the speed at which the disturbance moves.']
['Teacher: What does the term "amplitude" refer to in regards to the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'Consider the periodic water wave in Figure 13.7.']

['Teacher: That\'s correct. Now, can you explain what the term "frequency" refers to in relation to the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'Its wavelength is the distance from crest to crest or from trough to trough.']

['What does the term "period" refer to in regards to the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'The wavelength can also be thought of as the distance a wave has traveled after one complete cycle—or one period.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, based on what you just mentioned, can you explain the relationship between frequency and period for the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'The time for one complete up-and-down motion is the simple water wave’s period T.']
['What is the relationship between frequency and wavelength for the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'In the figure, the wave itself moves to the right with a wave velocity vw.']

['Teacher: Great job explaining the amplitude! Now, can you explain what the term "velocity" refers to in relation to the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'Its amplitude X is the distance between the resting position and the maximum displacement—either the crest or the trough—of the wave.']

['What does the term "velocity" refer to in regards to the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'It is important to note that this movement of the wave is actually the disturbance moving to the right, not the water itself; otherwise, the bird would move to the right.']

['What is the relationship between velocity and amplitude for the periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7?', 'Instead, the seagull bobs up and down in place as waves pass underneath, traveling a total distance of 2X in one cycle.']

['What is the difference between actual ocean waves and the simplified example of a periodic water wave shown in Figure 13.7, according to the text feature on surfing?', 'However, as mentioned in the text feature on surfing, actual ocean waves are more complex than this simplified example.']
['Teacher: How is the relationship between period (T) and frequency (f) similar to the harmonic motion of an object?', 'just as in the case of harmonic motion of an object.']
