['Teacher: What is the blue line in Figure 19.9 labeled as?', 'The electric current in Figure 19.9 is indicted by the blue line labeled I.']
['What does the arrow in Figure 19.9 represent?', 'The arrow indicates the direction in which positive charge would flow in this circuit.']

['Teacher: Why do negative charges flow in the opposite direction compared to the direction indicated by the arrow in the circuit?', 'Recall that, in metals, electrons are mobile charge carriers, so negative charges actually flow in the opposite direction around this circuit (i.e., counterclockwise).']

['Why do we draw the current in the direction in which positive charge would move instead of showing the actual direction of negative charge flow?', 'However, we draw the current to show the direction in which positive charge would move.']
['Teacher: What is presented on the right side of Figure 19.9 to help us understand electric circuits?', 'On the right side of Figure 19.9 is an analogous water circuit.']

["Teacher: That's correct. And what is the role of the water pump in the analogous water circuit?", 'Water at a higher pressure leaves the top of the pump, which is like charges leaving the positive terminal of the battery.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you tell me what happens to the water when it reaches the resistor in the water circuit?', 'The water travels through the pipe, like the charges traveling through the wire.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, in terms of the electric circuit, what is the function of the resistor when the charges travel through it?', 'Next, the water goes through a sand filter, which heats up as the water squeezes through.']
['Teacher: Good comparison! Now, in terms of the electric circuit, what happens to the charges as they pass through the resistor?', 'This step is like the charges going through the resistor.']

["Teacher: That's correct! How does the resistor in an electric circuit compare to the sand filter in the water circuit in terms of the effect it has on the charges passing through it?", 'When charges flow through a resistor, they do work to heat up the resistor.']

['What effect does the resistor have on the charges passing through it in terms of energy conversion?', 'After flowing through the sand filter, the water has converted its potential energy into heat, so it is at a lower pressure.']

['What is the voltage of the charges after they pass through the resistor in the electric circuit?', 'Likewise, the charges exiting the resistor have converted their potential energy into heat, so they are at a lower voltage.']
['What happens to the voltage of the charges as they pass through the resistor?', 'Recall that voltage is just potential energy per charge.']
['What physical quantity does the water pressure in the water circuit represent in the electric circuit?', 'Thus, water pressure is analogous to electric potential energy (i.e., voltage).']

['What does the return of water to the bottom of the pump represent in terms of the electric circuit?', 'Coming back to the water circuit again, we see that the water returns to the bottom of the pump, which is like the charge returning to the negative terminal of the battery.']

['What is the role of the water pump in the water circuit in terms of energy conversion?', 'The water pump uses a source of energy to pump the water back up to a high pressure again, giving it the pressure required to go through the circuit once more.']

['How does the battery in an electric circuit compare to the water pump in the water circuit in terms of the energy conversion it performs?', 'The water pump is like the battery, which uses chemical energy to increase the voltage of the charge up to the level of the positive terminal.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery and the voltage rating of the battery?', 'The potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery is the voltage rating of the battery.']

['Teacher: How would you explain the relationship between the potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery and the voltage rating of the battery using an analogy?', 'This voltage is like water pressure in the upper pipe.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another analogy to help illustrate the relationship between the potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery and the voltage rating of the battery?', 'Just like a higher pressure forces water to move toward a lower pressure, a higher voltage forces electric charge to flow toward a lower voltage.']

['Teacher: So, in terms of electric circuits and resistors, what would be a comparable example to the pump taking water at low pressure and ejecting it at a higher pressure?', 'The pump takes water at low pressure and does work on it, ejecting water at a higher pressure.']

['Teacher: In an electric circuit with resistors, what is responsible for doing work on the charge and increasing its voltage before it is ejected?', 'Likewise, a battery takes charge at a low voltage, does work on it, and ejects charge at a higher voltage.']

['Teacher: In the water circuit of Figure 19.9, what is true about the current throughout the circuit?', 'Note that the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9 is the same throughout the circuit.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9 remains the same throughout the circuit, using the analogy of measuring the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time?', 'In other words, if we measured the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time at any point in the circuit, we would get the same answer no matter where in the circuit we measured.']

['Teacher: How does the analogy of measuring the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time relate to the current in the electrical circuit?', 'The same is true of the electrical circuit in the same figure.']

['Teacher: Why is it that the electric current remains the same at all points in the circuit, including inside the battery and in the resistor?', 'The electric current is the same at all points in this circuit, including inside the battery and in the resistor.']
['Teacher: Why does the electric current neither speed up in the wires nor slow down in the resistor?', 'The electric current neither speeds up in the wires nor slows down in the resistor.']
['Teacher: What would happen if the electric current were to speed up in the wires or slow down in the resistor?', 'This would create points where too much or too little charge would be bunched up.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the electric current to be the same at all points in the circuit shown in Figure 19.9?', 'Thus, the current is the same at all points in the circuit shown in Figure 19.9.']

['Teacher: How does the voltage or water pressure change as you move through the circuits?', 'Although the current is the same everywhere in both the electric and water circuits, the voltage or water pressure changes as you move through the circuits.']

['Teacher: How does the voltage change in the electric circuit as you move through different components?', 'In the water circuit, the water pressure at the pump outlet stays the same until the water goes through the sand filter, assuming no energy loss in the pipe.']

['Teacher: How does the voltage change in the electrical circuit as you move through different wires or components?', 'Likewise, the voltage in the electrical circuit is the same at all points in a given wire, because we have assumed that the wires are perfect conductors.']

['Teacher: What does the constant red color of the upper wire in Figure 19.11 indicate about the voltage throughout the wire?', 'Thus, as indicated by the constant red color of the upper wire in Figure 19.11, the voltage throughout this wire is constant at  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: What does the change in voltage as you move through the resistor indicate about the flow of electric current in the circuit?', 'The voltage then drops as you go through the resistor, but once you reach the blue wire, the voltage stays at its new level of  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  all the way to the negative terminal of the battery (i.e., the blue terminal of the battery).']

['Teacher: What happens to the voltage as we trace the path from the blue wire through the battery to the red wire?', 'If we go from the blue wire through the battery to the red wire, the voltage increases from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$ to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens to the voltage as we trace the path from the blue wire through the battery to the red wire?', 'Likewise, if we go from the blue wire up through the resistor to the red wire, the voltage also goes from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']
['the battery and resistor in series, we can see that the total voltage across the circuit is the same as the voltage of the battery.', 'Thus, using']
["Teacher: Using Ohm's law, we can write <mask>?", 'Ohm’s law, we can write']

['Teacher: How is the voltage across a resistor measured?', 'Note that  $$\\(V_{\\text{resistor}}\\)$$  is measured from the bottom of the resistor to the top, meaning that the top of the resistor is at a higher voltage than the bottom of the resistor.']

['Teacher: What does it mean when we say that the top of the resistor is at a higher voltage than the bottom?', 'Thus, current flows from the top of the resistor or higher voltage to the bottom of the resistor or lower voltage.']
['Teacher: What other circuit elements, in addition to resistors, can be included in a circuit?', 'Other possible circuit elements include capacitors and switches.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how capacitors and switches are depicted in a circuit diagram?', 'These are drawn as shown on the left side of Figure 19.12.']
['Teacher: How are capacitors and switches depicted in a circuit diagram?', 'A switch is a device that opens and closes the circuit, like a light switch.']
['What is a capacitor and how is it depicted in a circuit diagram?', 'It is analogous to a valve in a water circuit, as shown on the right side of Figure 19.12.']
['Why is it said that a switch is similar to a light switch in a circuit diagram?', 'With the switch open, no current passes through the circuit.']
['How is the current affected when the switch is closed in a circuit diagram?', 'With the switch closed, it becomes part of the wire, so the current passes through it with no loss of voltage.']
['Teacher: What is the labeling for the resistor in Figure 19.12?', 'The capacitor is labeled C on the left of Figure 19.12.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, based on the passage, can you tell me how the resistor is labeled in Figure 19.12?', 'A capacitor in an electrical circuit is analogous to a flexible membrane in a water circuit.']

["Teacher: That's a great explanation of the capacitor! Now, according to the passage, how is the resistor labeled in Figure 19.12?", 'When the switch is closed in the circuit of Figure 19.12, the battery forces electrical current to flow toward the capacitor, charging the upper capacitor plate with positive charge.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain what happens to the voltage across the resistor in Figure 19.12 when the switch is closed?", 'As this happens, the voltage across the capacitor plates increases.']

['What happens to the voltage across the resistor in Figure 19.12 when the switch is closed, considering the analogy of the membrane in the water circuit?', 'This is like the membrane in the water circuit:']

['What happens to the voltage across the resistor in Figure 19.12 when the switch is closed, considering the analogy of the membrane in the water circuit?', 'When the valve is opened, the pump forces water to flow toward the membrane, making it stretch to store the excess water.']

['What happens to the pressure behind the membrane in the water circuit when the valve is opened and the pump forces water to flow toward the membrane, making it stretch to store the excess water?', 'As this happens, the pressure behind the membrane increases.']

['Teacher: What happens to the voltage across the resistor and the battery when the switch is opened?', 'Now if we open the switch, the capacitor holds the voltage between its plates because the charges have nowhere to go.']

['Teacher: How is the situation with the capacitor similar to the water pressure in the pipe when the valve is closed?', 'Likewise, if we close the valve, the water has nowhere to go and the membrane maintains the water pressure in the pipe between itself and the valve.']

['Teacher: What is the condition that can cause the current to eventually stop flowing in an electric circuit or a water circuit?', 'If the switch is closed for a long time in the electric circuit or if the valve is open for a long time in the water circuit, the current will eventually stop flowing because the capacitor or the membrane will have become completely charged.']

['What is the term used to describe the condition when each circuit is in the steady state and its characteristics do not change over time?', 'Each circuit is now in the steady state, which means that its characteristics do not change over time.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the steady state condition in an electric circuit where the current remains constant as long as the switch is in the same position?', 'In this case, the steady state is characterized by zero current, and this does not change as long as the switch or valve remains in the same position.']

['Teacher: What is the condition called when no electrical current passes through a resistor in an electric circuit and no water current passes through a membrane in a water circuit?', 'In the steady state, no electrical current passes through the capacitor, and no water current passes through the membrane.']

['What is the condition called when the voltage difference between the capacitor plates is the same as the battery voltage?', 'The voltage difference between the capacitor plates will be the same as the battery voltage.']

['What is the term used to describe the condition when the voltage difference across a resistor in an electric circuit is the same as the voltage of the battery?', 'In the water circuit, the pressure behind the membrane will be the same as the pressure created by the pump.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the circuit shown in Figure 19.12 when the switch is closed?', 'Although the circuit in Figure 19.12 may seem a bit pointless because all that happens when the switch is closed is that the capacitor charges up, it does show the capacitor’s ability to store charge.']

['What does the equation $$V_{\\text{resistor}} = V_{\\text{battery}} = IR$$ tell us about the role of the resistor and the battery in the circuit?', 'Thus, the capacitor serves as a reservoir for charge.']

OR

Teacher: How does the equation $$V_{\text{resistor}} = V_{\text{battery}} = IR$$ provide information about the roles of the resistor and the battery in the circuit?', 'This property of capacitors is used in circuits in many ways.']
['What are some ways in which capacitors are used in circuits, while batteries are being charged?', 'For example, capacitors are used to power circuits while batteries are being charged.']
['What are some other ways in which capacitors are used in circuits, aside from powering circuits while batteries are being charged?', 'In addition, capacitors can serve as filters.']
['What is the purpose of using capacitors as filters in a circuit?', 'To understand this, let’s go back to the water analogy.']
['What is one similarity between using capacitors as filters in a circuit and using a water hose to water a garden?', 'Suppose you have a water hose and are watering your garden.']
['How does kinking the hose affect the flow of water?', 'Your friend thinks he’s funny, and kinks the hose.']
['What can we conclude about the flow of water when the hose is kinked?', 'While the hose is kinked, you experience no water flow.']

['What is one similarity between the flow of water in the hose when it is kinked and the flow of current in a circuit when a capacitor is used as a filter?', 'When he lets go, the water starts flowing again.']

['What does this analogy teach us about the flow of current in a circuit when a capacitor is used as a filter?', 'If he does this really fast, you experience water-no water-water-no water, and that’s really no way to water your garden.']

['What is one drawback of using a capacitor as a filter in a circuit, according to the analogy mentioned?', 'Now imagine that the hose is filling up a big bucket, and you are watering from the bottom of the bucket.']

['What does this analogy suggest about the effectiveness of using a capacitor as a filter in a circuit, as long as certain conditions are met?', 'As long as you had water in your bucket to begin with and your friend doesn’t kink the water hose for too long, you would be able to water your garden without the interruptions.']

['What can we conclude about the effectiveness of using a capacitor as a filter in a circuit, as long as certain conditions are met?', 'Your friend kinking the water hose is filtered by the big bucket’s supply of water, so it does not impact your ability to water the garden.']
['What can we think of the interruptions in the current (be it water or electrical current) as?', 'We can think of the interruptions in the current (be it water or electrical current) as noise.']
['What is the role of capacitors in filtering out noise in a circuit?', 'Capacitors act in an analogous way as the water bucket to help filter out the noise.']

['What is one reason why capacitors are commonly used in electronic circuits?', 'Capacitors have so many uses that it is very rare to find an electronic circuit that does not include some capacitors.']

["Teacher: That's great progress! So, when we have circuits with more than one circuit element, what is another term we use to refer to these elements connected one after another?", 'Now that we have a basic idea of how electrical circuits work, let’s see what happens in circuits with more than one circuit element.']
["Teacher: Excellent! Now that we're discussing resistors in series, can you tell me what happens when resistors are connected in this way?", 'In this section, we look at resistors in series.']

['Teacher: Good job! Now, when resistors are connected in series, how does the current flow through them compared to resistors connected in parallel?', 'Components connected in series are connected one after the other in the same branch of a circuit, such as the resistors connected in series on the left side of Figure 19.14.']

['Teacher: How can we find the single resistance that is equivalent to the three resistors in series?', 'We will now try to find a single resistance that is equivalent to the three resistors in series on the left side of Figure 19.14.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how we can calculate the equivalent resistance of resistors in series?', 'An equivalent resistor is a resistor that has the same resistance as the combined resistance of a set of other resistors.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the equivalent resistor to have the same resistance as the combined resistance of the set of resistors in series?', 'In other words, the same current will flow through the left and right circuits in Figure 19.14 if we use the equivalent resistor in the right circuit.']

["Teacher: Can you explain Ohm's law and how it relates to the voltage drop across a resistor?", 'According to Ohm’s law, the voltage drop V across a resistor when a current flows through it is  $$\\(V = IR\\)$$  where I is the current in amperes (A) and R is the resistance in ohms ( $$\\(\\Omega\\)$$ ).']

["Ohm's law, can you explain how the voltage drop changes if the resistance increases?", 'Another way to think of this is that V is the voltage necessary to make a current I flow through a resistance R. Applying']

['Teacher: If we have resistors in series, how is the total voltage drop across the resistors related to the individual voltage drops across each resistor?', 'Ohm’s law to each resistor on the left circuit of Figure 19.14, we find that the voltage drop across  $$\\(R_{1}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{1} = IR_{1}\\)$$, that across  $$\\(R_{2}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{2} = IR_{2}\\)$$, and that across  $$\\(R_{3}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{3} = IR_{3}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: How can we express the total voltage drop across the resistors in terms of the individual voltage drops across each resistor?', 'The sum of these voltages equals the voltage output of the battery, that is']
['Teacher: Can you explain the rationale behind the requirement of voltage addition in this equation?', 'You may wonder why voltages must add up like this.']

['Teacher: How does going once around the circuit and adding up the successive changes in voltage help us understand the requirement of voltage addition in this equation?', 'One way to understand this is to go once around the circuit and add up the successive changes in voltage.']

['Why should the total change in voltage be zero if you go once around a loop and get back to the starting point?', 'If you do this around a loop and get back to the starting point, the total change in voltage should be zero, because you end up at the same place that you started.']
['What does going for a stroll through hilly countryside help us better understand?', 'To better understand this, consider the analogy of going for a stroll through some hilly countryside.']

['What can we conclude about the total voltage change in a circuit after going through a loop and returning to the starting point?', 'If you leave your car and walk around, then come back to your car, the total height you gained in your stroll must be the same as the total height you lost, because you end up at the same place as you started.']

['What analogy does the student use to explain the concept of total voltage change in a circuit after going through a loop and returning to the starting point?', 'Thus, the gravitational potential energy you gain must be the same as the gravitational potential energy you lose.']
['What does the student suggest about the total voltage change in going around an electric circuit?', 'The same reasoning holds for voltage in going around an electric circuit.']
['What specific reasoning should we apply to the left circuit in Figure 19.14?', 'Let’s apply this reasoning to the left circuit in Figure 19.14.']

['What is the voltage contribution of the battery when moving from below the battery to the top?', 'We start just below the battery and move up through the battery, which contributes a voltage gain of  $$\\(V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']
['What is the voltage contribution of the resistors when moving from below the battery to the top?', 'Next, we got through the resistors.']

['What is the total voltage change when moving from below the battery to the top, considering the contributions from the resistors?', 'The voltage drops by  $$\\(V_{1}\\)$$  in going through resistor  $$\\(R_{1}\\)$$, by  $$\\(V_{2}\\)$$  in going through resistor  $$\\(R_{2}\\)$$, and by  $$\\(V_{3}\\)$$  in going through resistor  $$\\(R_{3}\\)$$ .']

['What equation can we use to represent the total voltage change when moving from below the battery to the top, considering the contributions from the resistors?', 'After going through resistor  $$\\(R_{3}\\)$$, we arrive back at the starting point, so we add up these four changes in voltage and set the sum equal to zero.']

["Teacher: Excellent! Now, using Ohm's law, can you rewrite the equation $$\\[0 = V_{\\text{battery}} - V_{1} - V_{2} - V_{3}\\]$$ in terms of current and resistance?", 'Ohm’s law tells us that  $$\\(V_{1} = IR_{1}\\)$$,  $$\\(V_{2} = IR_{2}\\)$$, and  $$\\(V_{3} = IR_{3}\\)$$ .']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, if we substitute the given equations about voltage into the original equation, what does the resulting equation become?", 'Inserting these values into equation  $$\\(V_{\\text{battery}} = V_{1} + V_{2} + V_{3}\\)$$  gives']

['Teacher: Can you please explain how to calculate the equivalent resistance for a series of resistors based on the equation given?', 'This shows that the equivalent resistance for a series of resistors is simply the sum of the resistances of each resistor.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you tell me how resistors in parallel are connected?", 'In the previous section, we learned that resistors in series are resistors that are connected one after the other.']

['Teacher: Excellent! So, how would you define resistors in parallel based on their connection?', 'If we instead combine resistors by connecting them next to each other, as shown in Figure 19.16, then the resistors are said to be connected in parallel.']

['Teacher: Very well! Now, can you explain how the current flows through resistors in parallel compared to resistors in series?', 'Resistors are in parallel when both ends of each resistor are connected directly together.']

['Teacher: Why is the voltage at the top of each resistor the same in a parallel circuit with resistors connected to the same wire?', 'Note that the tops of the resistors are all connected to the same wire, so the voltage at the top of the each resistor is the same.']

['Teacher: What is the reason for the voltage at the bottom of each resistor being the same in a parallel circuit with resistors connected to the same wire?', 'Likewise, the bottoms of the resistors are all connected to the same wire, so the voltage at the bottom of each resistor is the same.']

['Why is it important for the voltage drop across each resistor to be the same in a parallel circuit with resistors connected to the same wire?', 'This means that the voltage drop across each resistor is the same.']

['What does it mean when the voltage drop across each resistor is the same in a parallel circuit with resistors connected to the same wire?', 'In this case, the voltage drop is the voltage rating V of the battery, because the top and bottom wires connect to the positive and negative terminals of the battery, respectively.']

['Teacher: Why is it not possible to say the same about the current running through each resistor in a parallel circuit, even though the voltage drop across each resistor is the same?', 'Although the voltage drop across each resistor is the same, we cannot say the same for the current running through each resistor.']

["Teacher: Why can't we say that the current running through each resistor is the same in a parallel circuit, even though the voltage drop across each resistor is the same?", 'Thus,  $$\\(I_{1},I_{2},\\text{and}I_{3}\\)$$  are not necessarily the same, because the resistors  $$\\(R_{1},R_{2},\\text{and}R_{3}\\)$$  do not necessarily have the same resistance.']

['Teacher: How does Figure 19.16 demonstrate the different paths available for current flow with the three resistors?', 'Note that the three resistors in Figure 19.16 provide three different paths through which the current can flow.']

['Teacher: Why does the current have multiple paths to flow through the three resistors in Figure 19.16?', 'This means that the equivalent resistance for these three resistors must be less than the smallest of the three resistors.']

['What would happen to the current if the smallest resistor was the only path available for current flow in Figure 19.16?', 'To understand this, imagine that the smallest resistor is the only path through which the current can flow.']

['What impact does adding the alternate paths by connecting other resistors in parallel have on the current flow in Figure 19.16?', 'Now add on the alternate paths by connecting other resistors in parallel.']

['What is the effect of adding resistors in parallel on the overall resistance in Figure 19.16?', 'Because the current has more paths to go through, the overall resistance (i.e., the equivalent resistance) will decrease.']

['What is the significance of the overall resistance being less than the smallest resistance of the parallel resistors in Figure 19.16?', 'Therefore, the equivalent resistance must be less than the smallest resistance of the parallel resistors.']

['Teacher: How do we find the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel?', 'To find the equivalent resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{equiv}}\\)$$  of the three resistors  $$\\(R_{1},R_{2},\\text{and}R_{3}\\)$$, we apply Ohm’s law to each resistor.']
["Teacher: Can you explain how you apply Ohm's law to each resistor to find the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel?", 'Because the voltage drop across each resistor is V, we obtain']

['Teacher: According to conservation of charge, how should the three currents \\(I_{1}, I_{2},\\) and \\(I_{3}\\) relate to the current I going through the battery?', 'We also know from conservation of charge that the three currents  $$\\(I_{1},I_{2},\\text{and}I_{3}\\)$$  must add up to give the current I that goes through the battery.']

['Teacher: What would happen if the sum of \\(I_{1}\\), \\(I_{2}\\), and \\(I_{3}\\) did not equal the current \\(I\\) going through the battery?', 'If this were not true, current would have to be mysteriously created or destroyed somewhere in the circuit, which is physically impossible.']
['Teacher: How are more complex connections of resistors typically formed?', 'More complex connections of resistors are sometimes just combinations of series and parallel.']

['What technique is used to simplify combinations of series and parallel resistors?', 'Combinations of series and parallel resistors can be reduced to a single equivalent resistance by using the technique illustrated in Figure 19.17.']

['Teacher: How are the various parts of combinations of series and parallel resistors identified and reduced?', 'Various parts are identified as either series or parallel, reduced to their equivalents, and further reduced until a single resistance is left.']
['What is the end goal of identifying and reducing the various parts of combinations of series and parallel resistors?', 'The process is more time consuming than difficult.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the four steps outlined in Figure 19.17 for reducing the seven resistors to a single equivalent resistor?', 'Let’s work through the four steps in Figure 19.17 to reduce the seven resistors to a single equivalent resistor.']

['Teacher: What are the four steps outlined in Figure 19.17 for reducing the seven resistors to a single equivalent resistor with all resistors assumed to be 10 $$\\(\\text{Ω}\\)$$?', 'To avoid distracting algebra, we’ll assume each resistor is 10  $$\\(\\text{Ω}\\)$$ .']
['What is the second step in reducing the seven resistors to a single equivalent resistor?', 'In step 1, we reduce the two sets of parallel resistors circled by the blue dashed loop.']

['What is the equivalent resistance in the upper set of resistors after reducing them to a single equivalent resistor?', 'The upper set has three resistors in parallel and will be reduced to a single equivalent resistor  $$\\(R_{\\text{P1}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the equivalent resistance in the lower set of resistors after reducing them to a single equivalent resistor?', 'The lower set has two resistors in parallel and will be reduced to a single equivalent resistor  $$\\(R_{\\text{P2}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the total equivalent resistance of the two sets of resistors after reducing them to single equivalent resistors?', 'Using the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel, we obtain']

['Teacher: What are the equivalent resistances of the two encircled regions in the red dashed loop following step 1?', 'These two equivalent resistances are encircled by the red dashed loop following step 1.']

['Teacher: How can we determine the equivalent resistance of resistors in series?', 'They are in series, so we can use the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in series to reduce them to a single equivalent resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{S1}}\\)$$ .']
['Teacher: Can you show me the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in series?', 'This is done in step 2, with the result being']

['Teacher: What was the final resistance value obtained in step 3?', 'This is done in step 3.']

['What is the equation that represents the relationship between \\(R_{\\text{P3}}\\) and \\(R_{\\text{equiv}}\\) after step 3?', 'These two resistors are combined in the final step to form the final equivalent resistor  $$\\(R_{\\text{equiv}}\\)$$, which is']

['Teacher: Why is it important for us to determine the equivalent resistance of the entire circuit?', 'It’s important for us to know the equivalent resistance of the entire circuit so that we can calculate the current flowing through the circuit.']

['Teacher: How does determining the equivalent resistance of the entire circuit help us calculate the current flowing through the circuit?', 'Ohm’s law tells us that the current flowing through a circuit depends on the resistance of the circuit and the voltage across the circuit.']
["Teacher: Why is it necessary to know the current flowing through the circuit in order to apply Ohm's law?", 'But to know the current, we must first know the equivalent resistance.']

['Teacher: Can you think of a combination of resistors where all of them are connected in parallel or all of them are connected in series?', 'Identify a group of resistors that are only in parallel or only in series.']

['Teacher: Great! Now, can you remind us what the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in series is?', 'For resistors in series, use the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in series to reduce them to a single equivalent resistance.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, how about reminding us what the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is?", 'For resistors in parallel, use the equation for the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel to reduce them to a single equivalent resistance.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, after finding the equivalent resistance for a combination of resistors, what should we do next to simplify the circuit further?', 'Draw a new circuit diagram with the resistors from step 1 replaced by their equivalent resistor.']

["Teacher: That's correct! After drawing a new circuit diagram with the equivalent resistor, what should we do next to simplify the circuit further?", 'If more than one resistor remains in the circuit, return to step 1 and repeat.']
['Teacher: What is the purpose of returning to step 1 and repeating if more than one resistor remains in the circuit?', 'Otherwise, you are finished.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me what concept is commonly associated with electricity?', 'Power is associated by many people with electricity.']
['What is one example of an appliance that runs on electric power?', 'Every day, we use electric power to run our modern appliances.']
['What are some visible examples of electricity providing power?', 'Electric power transmission lines are visible examples of electricity providing power.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how we use electric power in vehicles, computers, or homes?', 'We also use electric power to start our cars, to run our computers, or to light our homes.']
['What is the definition of electric power?', 'Power is the rate at which energy of any type is transferred; electric power is the rate at which electric energy is transferred in a circuit.']
['What will we be learning in this section about electric power and its determination?', 'In this section, we’ll learn not only what this means, but also what factors determine electric power.']

['Teacher: How are light bulbs often described in terms of their characteristics?', 'To get started, let’s think of light bulbs, which are often characterized in terms of their power ratings in watts.']
['What are light bulbs often characterized in terms of?', 'Let us compare a 25-W bulb with a 60-W bulb (see Figure 19.20).']
['Teacher: How does the light intensity of a 60-W bulb compare to a 25-W bulb?', 'Although both operate at the same voltage, the 60-W bulb emits more light intensity than the 25-W bulb.']

['Teacher: What does the comparison between the light intensity of a 60-W bulb and a 25-W bulb tell us about the power output of an electric circuit?', 'This tells us that something other than voltage determines the power output of an electric circuit.']

['Teacher: How would you describe incandescent light bulbs in terms of their functionality and the type of light they emit?', 'Incandescent light bulbs, such as the two shown in Figure 19.20, are essentially resistors that heat up when current flows through them and they get so hot that they emit visible and invisible light.']

['Teacher: What are the main characteristics of incandescent light bulbs in terms of their functionality and the type of light they emit?', 'Thus the two light bulbs in the photo can be considered as two different resistors.']

['Teacher: How does the resistance of an incandescent light bulb affect the current and power in a circuit?', 'In a simple circuit such as a light bulb with a voltage applied to it, the resistance determines the current by Ohm’s law, so we can see that current as well as voltage must determine the power.']
['Teacher: How can the formula for power be determined?', 'The formula for power may be found by dimensional analysis.']
['What does dimensional analysis involve when determining the formula for power?', 'Consider the units of power.']
['What are the units of power in the SI system?', 'In the SI system, power is given in watts (W), which is energy per unit time, or J/s']

['Teacher: How does substituting J = V * C into the equation for watts help us?', 'V}\\  \\times \\ \\text{C}\\)$$  and substitute this into the equation for watts to get']

['Teacher: What is the equation for determining electric current?', 'But a Coulomb per second (C/s) is an electric current, which we can see from the definition of electric current,  $$\\(I = \\frac{\\Delta Q}{\\Delta t}\\)$$, where  $$\\(\\Delta\\)$$']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain the relationship between electric current and power?', 'Q is the charge in coulombs and  $$\\(\\Delta\\)$$ t is time in seconds.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain how the equation for electric power relates voltage and current?", 'Thus, equation above tells us that electric power is voltage times current, or']
['Teacher: What circuit does Figure 19.21 represent in relation to the passage?', 'For example, consider the circuit in Figure 19.21.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, how is the current running through the circuit in Figure 19.21 determined?', 'Ohm’s law, the current running through the circuit is']
['Teacher: What is the main purpose of the power in this circuit?', 'In this circuit, the power goes primarily into heating the resistor in this circuit.']
['Teacher: How did we determine the voltage in the circuit of Figure 19.21?', 'In calculating the power in the circuit of Figure 19.21, we used the resistance and Ohm’s law to find the current.']

['Teacher: Excellent. Now, can you show me the equation for electric power that we used to calculate the power in the circuit?', 'Ohm’s law gives the current: $$\\(I = {V/R}\\)$$, which we can insert into the equation for electric power to obtain']

["Teacher: How can we use Ohm's law to express power in terms of only the current and resistance?", 'We can also use Ohm’s law to eliminate the voltage in the equation for electric power and obtain an expression for power in terms of just the current and the resistance.']

["Teacher: Excellent! So, how would you express power in terms of only the current and resistance using Ohm's law?", 'If we write Ohm’s law as  $$\\(V = IR\\)$$  and use this to eliminate V in the equation  $$\\(P = IV\\)$$, we obtain']

['Teacher: How can we express power in terms of only the current and the resistance?', 'Thus, by combining Ohm’s law with the equation  $$\\(P = IV\\)$$  for electric power, we obtain two more expressions for power: one in terms of voltage and resistance and one in terms of current and resistance.']

["Teacher: What are the two additional expressions for power when combining Ohm's law with the equation P = IV?", 'Note that only resistance (not capacitance or anything else), current, and voltage enter into the expressions for electric power.']

['Teacher: What is the specific physical characteristic of a circuit that determines how much power it dissipates?', 'This means that the physical characteristic of a circuit that determines how much power it dissipates is its resistance.']

['Teacher: What is the role of capacitors in terms of electric power dissipation in a circuit?', 'Any capacitors in the circuit do not dissipate electric power—on the contrary, capacitors either store electric energy or release electric energy back to the circuit.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the formula wheel in Figure 19.22 illustrates the relationship between voltage, resistance, current, and power?', 'To clarify how voltage, resistance, current, and power are all related, consider Figure 19.22, which shows the formula wheel.']

['Teacher: What quantities are represented in the center quarter circle of the formula wheel in Figure 19.22?', 'The quantities in the center quarter circle are equal to the quantities in the corresponding outer quarter circle.']

['Teacher: How does the formula wheel in Figure 19.22 illustrate the relationship between power, current, and voltage, specifically when expressing voltage in terms of power and current?', 'For example, to express a potential V in terms of power and current, we see from the formula wheel that  $$\\(V = {P/I}\\)$$ .']
['Teacher: What is the length of time that people have been aware of magnets and magnetism?', 'People have been aware of magnets and magnetism for thousands of years.']

['What is the significance of the region of Asia Minor called Magnesia in relation to magnets and magnetism?', 'The earliest records date back to ancient times, particularly in the region of Asia Minor called Magnesia—the name of this region is the source of words like magnet.']

['What is the main reason that magnetic rocks found in Magnesia stimulated interest during ancient times?', 'Magnetic rocks found in Magnesia, which is now part of western Turkey, stimulated interest during ancient times.']

['What was the discovery made by humans when they first found magnetic rocks?', 'When humans first discovered magnetic rocks, they likely found that certain parts of these rocks attracted bits of iron or other magnetic rocks more strongly than other parts.']
['What are the two areas of a magnet where the magnetic force is strongest?', 'These areas are called the poles of a magnet.']

['What is the function or purpose of a magnetic pole in relation to other magnets or magnetic material?', 'A magnetic pole is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material, such as iron.']

['What are the areas of the bar magnet shown in Figure 20.2 where the paper clips are concentrated?', 'For example, the poles of the bar magnet shown in Figure 20.2 are where the paper clips are concentrated.']

['Teacher: What will happen if a bar magnet is suspended so that it rotates freely?', 'If a bar magnet is suspended so that it rotates freely, one pole of the magnet will always turn toward the north, with the opposite pole facing south.']

['Teacher: What invention was developed as a result of the discovery you just mentioned?', 'This discovery led to the compass, which is simply a small, elongated magnet mounted so that it can rotate freely.']
['Teacher: How does a compass use the principle of magnetization to determine direction?', 'An example of a compass is shown Figure 20.3.']

["Teacher: How does the compass use the orientation of the magnet's poles to determine direction?", 'The pole of the magnet that orients northward is called the north pole, and the opposite pole of the magnet is called the south pole.']

['Teacher: What did the discovery about the orientation of one pole of a magnet to the north and the other pole to the south allow people to identify?', 'The discovery that one particular pole of a magnet orients northward, whereas the other pole orients southward allowed people to identify the north and south poles of any magnet.']

['Teacher: What happened when it was observed that the north poles of two different magnets interacted with each other?', 'It was then noticed that the north poles of two different magnets repel each other, and likewise for the south poles.']

['Teacher: How does the interaction between the north pole of one magnet and the south pole of other magnets differ from the interaction between the north poles or the south poles of two magnets?', 'Conversely, the north pole of one magnet attracts the south pole of other magnets.']

['Teacher: How can we relate the interaction between magnets to the concept of electric charge?', 'This situation is analogous to that of electric charge, where like charges repel and unlike charges attract.']
['What is the relationship between the interaction of magnets and the orientation of their poles?', 'In magnets, we simply replace charge with pole: Like poles repel and unlike poles attract.']
['What does Figure 20.4 in the textbook summarize?', 'This is summarized in Figure 20.4, which shows how the force between magnets depends on their relative orientation.']
['Teacher: What is the name given to the pole of a magnet that orients northward?', 'Consider again the fact that the pole of a magnet that orients northward is called the north pole of the magnet.']

['What is the magnetic pole of Earth called that is close to the geographic North Pole?', 'If unlike poles attract, then the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic North Pole must be a magnetic south pole!']

['What term is used to describe the phenomenon where the magnetic pole of a magnet aligns with the geographic North Pole?', 'Likewise, the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic South Pole must be a magnetic north pole.']

["What does Figure 20.5 depict in relation to Earth's magnetic poles?", 'This situation is depicted in Figure 20.5, in which Earth is represented as containing a giant internal bar magnet with its magnetic south pole at the geographic North Pole and vice versa.']

['What would happen if we were to suspend a small bar magnet near Earth?', 'If we were to somehow suspend a giant bar magnet in space near Earth, then the north pole of the space magnet would be attracted to the south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['How does a compass needle demonstrate the phenomenon of magnetization?', 'This is in essence what happens with a compass needle:']

["What is the term used to describe the phenomenon displayed by a compass needle, where its magnetic north pole is attracted to the magnetic south pole of Earth's internal magnet?", 'Its magnetic north pole is attracted to the magnet south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['Teacher: Can magnets be magnetized?', 'The answer is no:']
["Teacher: That's correct, but can you explain why each half of the bar magnet has a north pole and a south pole?", 'Each half of the bar magnet has a north pole and a south pole.']

['Teacher: Very good! Can you explain why cutting each piece of the bar magnet in half always results in a new, smaller magnet with two opposite poles?', 'You can even continue cutting each piece of the bar magnet in half, and you will always obtain a new, smaller magnet with two opposite poles.']

['Teacher: Great observation! Now, why do even the smallest particles that behave as magnets have two opposite poles?', 'As shown in Figure 20.6, you can continue this process down to the atomic scale, and you will find that even the smallest particles that behave as magnets have two opposite poles.']

['Teacher: Why is it that no experiment has ever found any object with a single magnetic pole, from the smallest subatomic particle such as electrons to the largest objects in the universe such as stars?', 'In fact, no experiment has ever found any object with a single magnetic pole, from the smallest subatomic particle such as electrons to the largest objects in the universe such as stars.']
['Why are magnets always referred to as magnetic dipoles?', 'Because magnets always have two poles, they are referred to as magnetic dipoles—di means two.']
['Why do magnetic dipoles have properties that are analogous to electric dipoles?', 'Below, we will see that magnetic dipoles have properties that are analogous to electric dipoles.']
['Teacher: What types of materials exhibit strong magnetic effects?', 'Only certain materials, such as iron, cobalt, nickel, and gadolinium, exhibit strong magnetic effects.']
['Teacher: Why are these materials called ferromagnetic?', 'Such materials are called ferromagnetic, after the Latin word ferrum for iron.']
['Teacher: Can you give an example of a material that exhibits weak magnetic effects?', 'Other materials exhibit weak magnetic effects, which are detectable only with sensitive instruments.']

['Teacher: What are some properties of ferromagnetic materials besides their strong magnetic response?', 'Not only do ferromagnetic materials respond strongly to magnets—the way iron is attracted to magnets—but they can also be magnetized themselves—that is, they can be induced to be magnetic or made into permanent magnets (Figure 20.7).']

['Teacher: How long does a permanent magnet retain its magnetic behavior, even when exposed to demagnetizing influences?', 'A permanent magnet is simply a material that retains its magnetic behavior for a long time, even when exposed to demagnetizing influences.']

['Teacher: What happens to a previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material when a magnet is brought near it?', 'When a magnet is brought near a previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material, it causes local magnetization of the material with unlike poles closest, as in the right side of Figure 20.7.']

['Teacher: How does the local magnetization of the previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material occur when a magnet is brought near it?', 'This causes an attractive force, which is why unmagnetized iron is attracted to a magnet.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what is illustrated in Figure 7(a) in terms of the topic we are discussing?', 'What happens on a microscopic scale is illustrated in Figure 7(a).']
['How do the regions within the material, known as domains, behave on a microscopic scale?', 'Regions within the material called domains act like small bar magnets.']
['Teacher: What is the overall alignment of the magnetic poles within the domains of a material like?', 'Within domains, the magnetic poles of individual atoms are aligned.']
['What is the overall effect of the alignment of the magnetic poles of individual atoms within domains?', 'Each atom acts like a tiny bar magnet.']
['What is the state of the domains in an unmagnetized ferromagnetic object?', 'Domains are small and randomly oriented in an unmagnetized ferromagnetic object.']

['How do the domains behave in response to an external magnetic field?', 'In response to an external magnetic field, the domains may grow to millimeter size, aligning themselves, as shown in Figure 7(b).']

['What are the methods by which induced magnetization can be made permanent?', 'This induced magnetization can be made permanent if the material is heated and then cooled, or simply tapped in the presence of other magnets.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of how a permanent magnet can be demagnetized?', 'Conversely, a permanent magnet can be demagnetized by hard blows or by heating it in the absence of another magnet.']

['Teacher: How does increased thermal motion at higher temperatures contribute to the demagnetization of a permanent magnet?', 'Increased thermal motion at higher temperature can disrupt and randomize the orientation and size of the domains.']

['Teacher: What happens to ferromagnetic materials that are heated above the Curie temperature in terms of their magnetization?', 'There is a well-defined temperature for ferromagnetic materials, which is called the Curie temperature, above which they cannot be magnetized.']

['Teacher: What impact does heating a ferromagnetic material above its Curie temperature have on its magnetization?', 'The Curie temperature for iron is 1,043 K (770 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ), which is well above room temperature.']

['What are some examples of elements and alloys that have Curie temperatures lower than room temperature and are ferromagnetic only below those temperatures?', 'There are several elements and alloys that have Curie temperatures much lower than room temperature and are ferromagnetic only below those temperatures.']

['Teacher: What have we seen regarding forces between magnets and ferromagnetic materials in the absence of contact between objects?', 'We have thus seen that forces can be applied between magnets and between magnets and ferromagnetic materials without any contact between the objects.']

['Teacher: What similarity can you draw between the forces acting between magnets and ferromagnetic materials and the electric forces?', 'This is reminiscent of electric forces, which also act over distances.']

['Teacher: How are magnetic forces similar to electric forces in terms of their behavior over distances?', 'Electric forces are described using the concept of the electric field, which is a force field around electric charges that describes the force on any other charge placed in the field.']

['Teacher: How can we describe the force between magnets using the concept of a <mask>?', 'Likewise, a magnet creates a magnetic field around it that describes the force exerted on other magnets placed in the field.']

['Teacher: How can the strength and direction of a magnetic field be visualized using the concept of magnetic field lines?', 'As with electric fields, the pictorial representation of magnetic field lines is very useful for visualizing the strength and direction of the magnetic field.']

['Teacher: How is the direction of magnetic field lines defined according to Figure 20.9?', 'As shown in Figure 20.9, the direction of magnetic field lines is defined to be the direction in which the north pole of a compass needle points.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the north pole of a compass needle behaves when placed near the north pole of a magnet, based on Figure 20.9?', 'If you place a compass near the north pole of a magnet, the north pole of the compass needle will be repelled and point away from the magnet.']

["Teacher: According to the information presented in Figure 20.9, how do magnetic field lines behave in the proximity of a magnet's south pole?", 'Thus, the magnetic field lines point away from the north pole of a magnet and toward its south pole.']
['Teacher: How can magnetic field lines be mapped out?', 'Magnetic field lines can be mapped out using a small compass.']

['Teacher: How is the compass used to map out magnetic field lines around a magnet?', 'The compass is moved from point to point around a magnet, and at each point, a short line is drawn in the direction of the needle, as shown in Figure 20.10.']
['Teacher: How can the path of a magnetic field line be revealed once the short lines have been drawn?', 'Joining the lines together then reveals the path of the magnetic field line.']
['Teacher: What happens when iron filings are sprinkled around a magnet?', 'Another way to visualize magnetic field lines is to sprinkle iron filings around a magnet.']

['Teacher: How do iron filings help visualize magnetic field lines around a magnet?', 'The filings will orient themselves along the magnetic field lines, forming a pattern such as that shown on the right in Figure 20.10.']

['Teacher: What happens to the magnetic field lines when two magnets are brought close together?', 'When two magnets are brought close together, the magnetic field lines are perturbed, just as happens for electric field lines when two electric charges are brought together.']

['Teacher: How does the bending of magnetic field lines differ when two north poles are brought together compared to when two south poles are brought together?', 'Bringing two north poles together—or two south poles—will cause a repulsion, and the magnetic field lines will bend away from each other.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens to the magnetic field lines when two north poles are brought close together, based on Figure 20.11?', 'This is shown in Figure 20.11, which shows the magnetic field lines created by the two closely separated north poles of a bar magnet.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the behavior of magnetic field lines when opposite poles of two magnets are brought together, based on Figure 20.11?', 'When opposite poles of two magnets are brought together, the magnetic field lines join together and become denser between the poles.']

['Teacher: What happens to the bending of magnetic field lines when opposite poles of two magnets are brought close together, as depicted in Figure 20.11?', 'This situation is shown in Figure 20.11.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the relationship between the density of magnetic field lines and the strength of the magnetic field?', 'Like the electric field, the magnetic field is stronger where the lines are denser.']

['Teacher: Why is the magnetic field weaker between the two north poles in Figure 20.11?', 'Thus, between the two north poles in Figure 20.11, the magnetic field is very weak because the density of the magnetic field is almost zero.']

["What would happen to a compass placed between two north poles in Figure 20.11 if we ignore Earth's magnetic field?", 'A compass placed at that point would essentially spin freely if we ignore Earth’s magnetic field.']

["What would happen to a compass placed between the north and south poles in Figure 20.11 if we ignore Earth's magnetic field?", 'Conversely, the magnetic field lines between the north and south poles in Figure 20.11 are very dense, indicating that the magnetic field is very strong in this region.']

["What would happen to a compass placed between the north pole on the left and the south pole on the right in Figure 20.11 if we ignore Earth's magnetic field?", 'A compass placed here would quickly align with the magnetic field and point toward the south pole on the right.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why magnets are not the sole source of magnetic fields?', 'Note that magnets are not the only things that make magnetic fields.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you provide an example of how electrical currents can create magnetic fields?", 'Early in the nineteenth century, people discovered that electrical currents cause magnetic effects.']

['Teacher: How did Hans Christian Oersted observe the relationship between electrical currents and magnetic fields?', 'The first significant observation was by the Danish scientist Hans Christian Oersted (1777–1851), who found that a compass needle was deflected by a current-carrying wire.']

["What was Hans Christian Oersted's observation with regards to the relationship between electrical currents and magnetic fields?", 'This was the first significant evidence that the movement of electric charges had any connection with magnets.']
['What is an example of a device that uses electric current to generate a magnetic field?', 'An electromagnet is a device that uses electric current to make a magnetic field.']
['What is the purpose of using an electromagnet?', 'These temporarily induced magnets are called electromagnets.']

['What are some examples of practical applications of electromagnets?', 'Electromagnets are employed for everything from a wrecking yard crane that lifts scrapped cars to controlling the beam of a 90-km-circumference particle accelerator to the magnets in medical-imaging machines (see Figure 20.12).']
['Teacher: What is shown in Figure 20.13?', 'The magnetic field created by an electric current in a long straight wire is shown in Figure 20.13.']
['Teacher: How does the magnetic field lines appear around the long straight wire?', 'The magnetic field lines form concentric circles around the wire.']

['Teacher: How can we determine the direction of the magnetic field around a long straight wire using the right-hand rule?', 'The direction of the magnetic field can be determined using the right-hand rule.']

['Teacher: Why is the right-hand rule used to determine the direction of the magnetic field around a long straight wire?', 'This rule shows up in several places in the study of electricity and magnetism.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the right-hand rule is applied to determine the direction of the magnetic field around a long straight wire with an electric current?', 'Applied to a straight current-carrying wire, the right-hand rule says that, with your right thumb pointed in the direction of the current, the magnetic field will be in the direction in which your right fingers curl, as shown in Figure 20.13.']

['What is the equation for the strength of the magnetic field if the wire is very long compared to the distance from the wire?', 'If the wire is very long compared to the distance r from the wire, the strength B of the magnetic field is given by']
['Teacher: What is the formula for calculating the magnetic field strength of a straight wire?', '$$\\[B_{\\text{straight}\\text{wire}} = \\frac{\\mu_{0}']
['Teacher: That\'s correct! Now, what does the variable "mu zero" represent in the formula for calculating the magnetic field strength of a straight wire?', 'I}{2\\pi r}\\]$$']
['Teacher: Can you explain to me what the variable "I" represents in this context of magnetic fields?', 'where I is the current in the wire in amperes.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you please tell me what the SI unit for magnetic field is in terms of its symbol?', 'The SI unit for magnetic field is the tesla (T).']

['what is the value of the symbol $$\\(\\mu_{0}\\)$$ in the context of magnetic fields?', 'The symbol  $$\\(\\mu_{0}\\)$$ —read “mu-zero”—is a constant called the “permeability of free space” and is given by']
['Teacher: What is the purpose of winding a wire around a cylinder in this scenario?', 'Now imagine winding a wire around a cylinder with the cylinder then removed.']
['Teacher: Why is the resulting structure referred to as a wire coil?', 'The result is a wire coil, as shown in Figure 20.14.']
['Teacher: How does the wire coil in Figure 20.14 differ from a regular wire?', 'This is called a solenoid.']

['Teacher: How can we determine the direction of the magnetic field produced by a solenoid?', 'To find the direction of the magnetic field produced by a solenoid, apply the right-hand rule to several points on the coil.']

['Teacher: How does the direction of the magnetic field inside the solenoid differ from the direction outside the solenoid?', 'You should be able to convince yourself that, inside the coil, the magnetic field points from left to right.']

['Teacher: How does the direction of the magnetic field outside the solenoid differ from the direction inside the solenoid?', 'In fact, another application of the right-hand rule is to curl your right-hand fingers around the coil in the direction in which the current flows.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the direction of the current flow and the direction of the magnetic field inside the coil?', 'Your right thumb then points in the direction of the magnetic field inside the coil: left to right in this case.']
['Teacher: How does each loop of wire contribute to the magnetic field inside the solenoid?', 'Each loop of wire contributes to the magnetic field inside the solenoid.']
['Teacher: Why must the magnetic field lines form closed loops?', 'Because the magnetic field lines must form closed loops, the field lines close the loop outside the solenoid.']
['Teacher: Why are the magnetic field lines much denser inside the solenoid than outside the solenoid?', 'The magnetic field lines are much denser inside the solenoid than outside the solenoid.']
['Teacher: What does the resulting magnetic field inside the solenoid resemble?', 'The resulting magnetic field looks very much like that of a bar magnet, as shown in Figure 20.15.']

So, based on Newton's third law, if a magnetic field can exert a force on a magnet, what can we conclude about a moving electric charge?", 'If a moving electric charge, that is electric current, produces a magnetic field that can exert a force on another magnet, then the reverse should be true by Newton’s third law.']

['What is the expected outcome when a charge moves through the magnetic field produced by another object?', 'In other words, a charge moving through the magnetic field produced by another object should experience a force—and this is exactly what we find.']

We can see that the charge experiences a force in a direction perpendicular to both its velocity and the magnetic field.', 'As a concrete example, consider Figure 20.16, which shows a charge q moving with velocity  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  through a magnetic field  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']

['What determines the magnitude of the force experienced by the charge in Figure 20.16?', 'The magnitude F of the force experienced by this charge is']

['Teacher: How do we determine the direction of the force on a charged particle moving through a magnetic field?', 'The direction of the force may be found by using another version of the right-hand rule: First, we join the tails of the velocity vector and a magnetic field vector, as shown in step 1 of Figure 20.16.']

['Teacher: How does curling our right fingers from the velocity vector to the magnetic field vector help us determine the direction of the force on a charged particle?', 'We then curl our right fingers from  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\)$$, as indicated in step (2) of Figure 20.16.']

['Teacher: What does the direction in which the right thumb points represent in determining the direction of the force on a charged particle moving through a magnetic field?', 'The direction in which the right thumb points is the direction of the force.']

['Teacher: How can we use the right-hand rule to determine the direction of the force on a charged particle moving through a magnetic field in the given Figure 20.16?', 'For the charge in Figure 20.16, we find that the force is directed into the page.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why a charge that moves parallel to a magnetic field experiences zero force according to the equation F = qvBsinθ?', 'Note that the factor  $$\\(\\sin\\theta\\)$$  in the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ means that zero force is applied on a charge that moves parallel to a magnetic field because  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\sin 0 = 0\\)$$ .']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain why a charge experiences the maximum force when it moves perpendicular to the magnetic field?", 'The maximum force a charge can experience is when it moves perpendicular to the magnetic field, because  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\sin 90{^\\circ} = 1\\;\\text{.}\\)$$']

['Teacher: In this scenario, how does the angle between the velocity of the charges in the wire and the magnetic field affect the force experienced by the wire?', 'Instead of a single charge moving through a magnetic field, consider now a steady current I moving through a straight wire.']

['Teacher: Right! Now, can you explain how the speed of the charges in the wire relates to the velocity of the charges in the context of an electric current?', 'If the charges q move a distance  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a time t, then their speed is  $$\\(v = {\\ell/t\\text{.}}\\)$$']

['Teacher: How can we interpret the factor q/t in this equation?', 'The factor q/t in this equation is nothing more than the current in the wire.']
