['Teacher: How would you summarize the equation $$F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta$$ and its purpose?', 'This equation gives the force on a straight current-carrying wire of length  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a magnetic field of strength B.']

['Teacher: Excellent, well done! Can you please explain why the sine of the angle θ is included in the equation?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the current vector and the magnetic field vector.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to consider the angle θ in the equation F = IℓBsinθ?', 'Note that  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  is the length of wire that is in the magnetic field and for which  $$\\(\\theta \\neq 0\\;\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in Figure 20.19.']
['Teacher: How is the direction of the force determined in this equation?', 'The direction of the force is determined in the same way as for a single charge.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the specific process of curling your right fingers from the vector for I to the vector for B to determine the direction of the force on the wire?', 'Curl your right fingers from the vector for I to the vector for B, and your right thumb will point in the direction of the force on the wire.']

['Teacher: According to the information provided in the passage, in which direction is the force directed for the wire shown in Figure 20.19?', 'For the wire shown in Figure 20.19, the force is directed into the page.']

['Teacher: What kind of symmetries have you noticed between magnetic effects and electric effects throughout this section?', 'Throughout this section, you may have noticed the symmetries between magnetic effects and electric effects.']

["Teacher: That's a great observation! Can you provide an example of a specific magnetic effect and its corresponding electric effect?", 'These effects all fall under the umbrella of electromagnetism, which is the study of electric and magnetic phenomena.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain how the equation F = IℓBsinθ relates to electric and magnetic effects?", 'We have seen that electric charges produce electric fields, and moving electric charges produce magnetic fields.']

['Teacher: How does the equation F = IℓBsinθ relate to the magnetic and electric effects that you mentioned earlier?', 'A magnetic dipole produces a magnetic field, and, as we will see in the next section, moving magnetic dipoles produce an electric field.']

['Teacher: How does the equation F = IℓBsinθ relate to the symmetries between magnetic and electric effects that you have mentioned earlier?', 'Thus, electricity and magnetism are two intimately related and symmetric phenomena.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the force experienced by a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is calculated using the equation F = IℓBsinθ?', 'As we learned previously, a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field experiences a force—recall  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$ .']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you give an example of how electric motors use magnetic force to function?", 'Electric motors, which convert electrical energy into mechanical energy, are the most common application of magnetic force on current-carrying wires.']
['Can you explain how the force experienced by a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is related to the functioning of electric motors?', 'Motors consist of loops of wire in a magnetic field.']

['How is the force experienced by a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field related to the rotation of the shaft in electric motors?', 'When current is passed through the loops, the magnetic field exerts a torque on the loops, which rotates a shaft.']
['What is the main purpose or function of electric motors?', 'Electrical energy is converted to mechanical work in the process.']
['What does Figure 20.23 in the textbook illustrate?', 'Figure 20.23 shows a schematic drawing of an electric motor.']

['Teacher: What does examining the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23 allow us to find?', 'Let us examine the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23 to find the torques produced about the axis of the vertical shaft—this will lead to a useful equation for the torque on the loop.']

['What is the purpose of examining the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23?', 'We take the magnetic field to be uniform over the rectangular loop, which has width w and height  $$\\(\\ell\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in the figure.']
['What can we find by examining the force on each segment of the loop?', 'First, consider the force on the top segment of the loop.']
['What does the student use the right-hand rule for when examining the force on the top segment of the loop?', 'To determine the direction of the force, we use the right-hand rule.']

['What is the direction of the force on the top segment of the loop when the current goes from left to right into the page and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page?', 'The current goes from left to right into the page, and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page.']

['What direction will the force on the top segment of the loop be when the current goes from left to right into the page and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page?', 'Curl your right fingers from the current vector to the magnetic field vector and your right thumb points down.']
['What can we conclude about the torque produced on the shaft by the force on the top segment?', 'Thus, the force on the top segment is downward, which produces no torque on the shaft.']

['What can we conclude about the torque produced on the shaft by the force on the bottom segment?', 'Repeating this analysis for the bottom segment—neglect the small gap where the lead wires go out—shows that the force on the bottom segment is upward, again producing no torque on the shaft.']
['Teacher: When considering the left vertical segment of the loop, what specific factors should we take into account?', 'Consider now the left vertical segment of the loop.']

['What is the direction of the force exerted on the left vertical segment of the loop according to the right-hand rule?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, we find that the force exerted on this segment is perpendicular to the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.23.']
['What are the effects of the torque produced on the shaft by the force exerted on the left vertical segment of the loop?', 'This force produces a torque on the shaft.']

['How does the force exerted on the right vertical segment of the loop affect the torque produced on the shaft?', 'Repeating this analysis on the right vertical segment of the loop shows that the force on this segment is in the direction opposite that of the force on the left segment, thereby producing an equal torque on the shaft.']

['What is the relationship between the total torque on the shaft and the torque on one of the vertical segments of the loop?', 'The total torque on the shaft is thus twice the toque on one of the vertical segments of the loop.']

['Teacher: What does Figure 20.24 represent in relation to the torque of the wire loop spin?', 'To find the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins, consider Figure 20.24, which shows a view of the wire loop from above.']

['Teacher: How does Figure 20.24 help us in understanding the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins?', 'Recall that torque is defined as  $$\\(\\tau = rF\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  where F is the applied force, r is the distance from the pivot to where the force is applied, and θ is the angle between r and F.']

['Teacher: What does the direction of the applied force have to do with the torque experienced by the wire loop as it spins?', 'Notice that, as the loop spins, the current in the vertical loop segments is always perpendicular to the magnetic field.']

['Teacher: How does the equation F = IℓBsinθ relate to the force on each vertical segment of the wire loop as it spins?', 'Thus, the equation  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives the magnitude of the force on each vertical segment as  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What is the value of the torque created by the force applied to the wire loop as it spins?', 'The distance r from the shaft to where this force is applied is w/2, so the torque created by this force is']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the torque of a multiple loop system and the torque of a single loop system?', 'If we have a multiple loop with N turns, we get N times the torque of a single loop.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the relationship between the number of loops and the torque of the system can be derived using the expression for the area of the loop?', 'Using the fact that the area of the loop is  $$\\(A = w\\ell\\text{;}\\)$$  the expression for the torque becomes']
['Teacher: Can you explain the significance of the variables N, I, A, and θ in the formula for torque?', 'This is the torque on a current-carrying loop in a uniform magnetic field.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you now explain how the variables in the formula for torque are related to the physical characteristics of the current-carrying loop?", 'This equation can be shown to be valid for a loop of any shape.']

['Teacher: What is the condition for the torque to be zero in the equation $$\\tau = NIAB\\sin\\theta$$?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\tau = NIAB\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  we see that the torque is zero when  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What is the value of torque when θ is 90° in the equation τ = NIABsinθ?', 'As the wire loop rotates, the torque increases to a maximum positive torque of  $$\\(w\\ell B\\)$$  when  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['Teacher: What happens to the value of torque when θ is between 90° to 180° in the equation τ = NIABsinθ?', 'The torque then decreases back to zero as the wire loop rotates to  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$  From  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\theta = 360{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{,}\\)$$  the torque is negative.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the torque changing sign every half turn in the given equation?', 'Thus, the torque changes sign every half turn, so the wire loop will oscillate back and forth.']

['Teacher: What happens to the direction of current in the coil when we run the motor in reverse and mechanically force the coil to rotate in the magnetic field?', 'Consider now what happens if we run the motor in reverse; that is, we attach a handle to the shaft and mechanically force the coil to rotate within the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.26.']

['What is the equation that describes the magnetic force experienced by charges in the wires of the loop?', 'As per the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ —where  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the vectors  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\text{—charges}\\)$$  in the wires of the loop experience a magnetic force because they are moving in a magnetic field.']

['B}\\text{, and—thumb pointed in the direction of}\\)$$ the current, we find that the magnetic force on charges in the wires is directed inward toward the center of the loop when  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\;\\text{and}\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}$$.\nTeacher: How do we ensure that the coil continues rotating in the same direction even after passing through  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\;\\text{and}\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}$$?\nStudent: To ensure that the coil continues rotating in the same direction, the current is reversed as the coil passes through  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\;\\text{and}\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}$$ using automatic switches called brushes, as shown in Figure 20.25', 'Again using the right-hand rule, where we curl our fingers from vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the current to be reversed as the coil passes through θ = 0 and θ = 180°?', 'However, charges in the vertical wires experience forces parallel to the wire, causing a current to flow through the wire and through an external circuit if one is connected.']

['Teacher: What is the function of a device like the one described, which converts mechanical energy into electrical energy?', 'A device such as this that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is called a generator.']

['Teacher: What is the reason for reversing the current as the coil passes through $\\theta = 0$ and $\\theta = 180^\\circ$ using automatic switches called brushes?', 'Because current is induced only in the side wires, we can find the induced emf by only considering these wires.']

['Teacher: How can we relate the concept of induced current in a wire to the reversal of current in the coil as it passes through $\\theta = 0$ and $\\theta = 180^\\circ$?', 'As explained in Induced Current in a Wire, motional emf in a straight wire moving at velocity v through a magnetic field B is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\text{,}\\)$$  where the velocity is perpendicular to the magnetic field.']

['Teacher: How does the angle $\\theta$ between the velocity and the magnetic field affect the velocity component perpendicular to the field?', 'In the generator, the velocity makes an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  with B (see Figure 20.27), so the velocity component perpendicular to B is  $$\\(v\\sin\\theta\\text{.}\\)$$']

['Teacher: How does the induced emf on each vertical wire segment contribute to the reversal of current in the coil as it passes through $\\theta = 0$ and $\\theta = 180^\\circ$?', 'Thus, in this case, the emf induced on each vertical wire segment is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  and they are in the same direction.']

['what is the relationship between the angle theta and the angular velocity omega?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is related to the angular velocity by  $$\\(\\theta = \\omega t\\text{,}\\)$$  so that']

["Teacher: Excellent! Now, let's further explore the equation $$E = 2B\\ell v\\sin\\omega t$$. Can you explain how the tangential velocity \\(v\\) and angular velocity \\(\\omega\\) are related in this equation?", 'Recall that tangential velocity v is related to angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  by  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, what is the value of the constant \\(B\\) in the equation \\(E = 2B\\ell v\\sin\\omega t\\) representing?", 'Here,  $$\\(r = {w/2}\\)$$, so that  $$\\(v = \\left( {w\\operatorname{/2}} \\right)\\omega\\)$$  and']

['Teacher: What does the equation $$\\[E = NAB\\omega\\sin\\omega t\\]$$ represent in the context of a generator coil?', 'is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  in a uniform magnetic field B.']
['Teacher: What does Figure 20.28 show in relation to the generator and the emf?', 'Figure 20.28 shows a generator connected to a light bulb and a graph of the emf vs. time.']

['What is the maximum (peak) emf denoted on the graph in Figure 20.28?', 'Note that the emf oscillates from a positive maximum of  $$\\(E_{0}\\)$$  to a negative maximum of  $$\\({-E}_{0}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What is the significance of the emf going through zero and zero current flowing through the light bulb at these times?', 'In between, the emf goes through zero, which means that zero current flows through the light bulb at these times.']

['What is the frequency of the flickering of the light bulb in Figure 20.28?', 'Thus, the light bulb actually flickers on and off at a frequency of 2f, because there are two zero crossings per period.']

['What is the relationship between the frequency of the alternating current and the frequency of the flickering lights in Figure 20.28?', 'In the United States, the frequency of alternating current is 60 Hz, so the lights flicker on and off at a frequency of 120 Hz.']
["Teacher: Why don't we notice the flicker of the lights in Figure 20.28?", 'This is faster than the refresh rate of the human eye, so you don’t notice the flicker of the lights.']

['What are some factors that prevent different types of light bulbs from switching on and off quickly?', 'Also, other factors prevent various different types of light bulbs from switching on and off so fast, so the light output is smoothed out a bit.']

['Teacher: How do electric generators in real life differ in appearance from the figures in this section, despite sharing the same principles?', 'In real life, electric generators look a lot different than the figures in this section, but the principles are the same.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the sources of mechanical energy that can turn the coil in electric generators?', 'The source of mechanical energy that turns the coil can be falling water—hydropower—steam produced by the burning of fossil fuels, or the kinetic energy of wind.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the process depicted in Figure 20.29 that helps produce mechanical energy to turn the coil in an electric generator?', 'Figure 20.29 shows a cutaway view of a steam turbine; steam moves over the blades connected to the shaft, which rotates the coil within the generator.']
['Teacher: How does a transformer utilize magnetic induction?', 'Another very useful and common device that exploits magnetic induction is called a transformer.']

['Teacher: How does a transformer perform the transformation of voltages from one value to another?', 'Transformers do what their name implies—they transform voltages from one value to another; the term voltage is used rather than emf because transformers have internal resistance.']

['Teacher: Why is the term "voltage" used instead of "emf" when discussing transformers?', 'For example, many cell phones, laptops, video games, power tools, and small appliances have a transformer built into their plug-in unit that changes 120 V or 240 V AC into whatever voltage the device uses.']
['Teacher: What is shown in Figure 20.30?', 'Figure 20.30 shows two different transformers.']
['What is the purpose of the wire coils in the transformers shown in Figure 20.30?', 'Notice the wire coils that are visible in each device.']
['Teacher: What explanation is provided for the purpose of the wire coils in the transformers shown in Figure 20.30?', 'The purpose of these coils is explained below.']

["Teacher: What principle is the laminated-coil transformer based on and how is it similar to Faraday's apparatus in construction?", 'Figure 20.31 shows a laminated-coil transformer, which is based on Faraday’s law of induction and is very similar in construction to the apparatus Faraday used to demonstrate that magnetic fields can generate electric currents.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain the role of the primary and secondary coils in a laminated-coil transformer?', 'The two wire coils are called the primary and secondary coils.']

['Teacher: How is the input voltage applied in a laminated-coil transformer and what is the function of the secondary coil?', 'In normal use, the input voltage is applied across the primary coil, and the secondary produces the transformed output voltage.']

['Teacher: How does the iron core of a laminated-coil transformer contribute to the magnetic field strength and what is the analogy between its effect and dielectric in a capacitor?', 'Not only does the iron core trap the magnetic field created by the primary coil, but also its magnetization increases the field strength, which is analogous to how a dielectric increases the electric field strength in a capacitor.']

['What is the relationship between the input voltage in a laminated-coil transformer and the generated magnetic flux in the secondary coil?', 'Since the input voltage is AC, a time-varying magnetic flux is sent through the secondary coil, inducing an AC output voltage.']

['Teacher: What are the two factors that determine the output voltage \\(V_S\\) in the transformer shown in Figure 20.31?', 'For the transformer shown in Figure 20.31, the output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  from the secondary coil depends almost entirely on the input voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  across the primary coil and the number of loops in the primary and secondary coils.']

['What is the relationship between the input voltage and the output voltage in the transformer?', 'Faraday’s law of induction for the secondary coil gives its induced output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  to be']

['Teacher: Can you provide a brief explanation of what the variables $$\\(N_{\\text{S}}\\)$$ and $$\\({\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}\\)$$ represent in the equation?', 'where  $$\\(N_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  is the number of loops in the secondary coil and  $$\\({\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}\\)$$  is the rate of change of magnetic flux.']

['Teacher: What does the equation state about the output voltage in relation to the induced electromotive force (emf) and coil resistance?', 'The output voltage equals the induced emf  $$\\(\\text{(}V_{\\text{S}} = E_{\\text{S}}\\text{),}\\)$$  provided coil resistance is small—a reasonable assumption for transformers.']

['Teacher: How does the number of loops in the secondary coil affect the output voltage in the equation?', 'The cross-sectional area of the coils is the same on each side, as is the magnetic field strength, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ/Δ}t\\)$$  is the same on each side.']

['Student: The input primary voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  is also related to changing flux by the equation: <fill in the blank>.', 'The input primary voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  is also related to changing flux by']
['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by "the transformer equation"?', 'This is known as the transformer equation.']

['Teacher: How do we represent the ratio of the secondary voltage to the primary voltage in a transformer?', 'It simply states that the ratio of the secondary voltage to the primary voltage in a transformer equals the ratio of the number of loops in secondary coil to the number of loops in the primary coil.']

['Teacher: What devices are commonly used in the electric power industry to increase voltages before long-distance transmission via high-voltage wires?', 'Transformers are widely used in the electric power industry to increase voltages—called step-up transformers—before long-distance transmission via high-voltage wires.']
['What is the purpose of step-down transformers in the electric power industry?', 'They are also used to decrease voltages—called step-down transformers—to deliver power to homes and businesses.']

['How is electric power commonly generated in order to transmit it through the power lines?', 'The overwhelming majority of electric power is generated by using magnetic induction, whereby a wire coil or copper disk is rotated in a magnetic field.']

['What is the primary energy source commonly used to rotate the coils or disk in order to generate electric power?', 'The primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk can be provided by a variety of means.']

['What other means can be used to provide the primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk in order to generate electric power?', 'Hydroelectric power plants use the kinetic energy of water to drive electric generators.']

['What are some other means, besides hydroelectric power, that can be used to provide the primary energy required to rotate the coils and generate electric power?', 'Coal or nuclear power plants create steam to drive steam turbines that turn the coils.']

['What are some alternative sources of primary energy that can be used to rotate the coils and generate electric power, besides coal, nuclear power, wind, tides, or waves on water?', 'Other sources of primary energy include wind, tides, or waves on water.']

['Teacher: What is the next step after power generation that needs to be done for the electricity to reach the consumer?', 'Once power is generated, it must be transmitted to the consumer, which often means transmitting power over hundreds of kilometers.']

["of the transformer's turns ratio. This allows for efficient transmission over long distances.", 'To do this, the voltage of the power plant is increased by a step-up transformer, that is stepped up, and the current decreases proportionally because']

['Teacher: How does the lower current in the transmission wires affect the Joule losses?', 'The lower current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  in the transmission wires reduces the Joule losses, which is heating of the wire due to a current flow.']

['What is the relationship between the current in the transmission wires and the Joule losses?', 'This heating is caused by the small, but nonzero, resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{wire}}\\)$$  of the transmission wires.']
['What is the formula to calculate the power lost to the environment through this heat?', 'The power lost to the environment through this heat is']
['Teacher: According to the equation, what variable represents the current squared in the transmission wire?', 'which is proportional to the current squared in the transmission wire.']

['Teacher: Why must the transmitted current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$ be as small as possible?', 'This is why the transmitted current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  must be as small as possible and, consequently, the voltage must be large to transmit the power  $$\\(P_{\\text{transmitted}}\\text{⋅}\\)$$']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the power loss (P_lost) and the square of the transmitted current (I_transmitted) multiplied by the resistance of the wire (R_wire)?', 'Voltages ranging from 120 to 700 kV are used for transmitting power over long distances.']
['What role does the voltage play in the equation for power loss?', 'The voltage is stepped up at the exit of the power station by a step-up transformer, as shown in Figure 20.32.']

['Teacher: What happens to the voltage once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center?', 'Once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center, the voltage is stepped down at a substation to between 5 and 30 kV.']

['Teacher: How is the voltage adjusted at a substation once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center?', 'Finally, at individual homes or businesses, the power is stepped down again to 120, 240, or 480 V.']

['Teacher: How is the power transmitted from a population or industrial center to individual homes or businesses?', 'Each step-up and step-down transformation is done with a transformer designed based on Faradays law of induction.']

['Teacher: What is the basis for designing transformers used in the step-up and step-down transformation process?', 'We’ve come a long way since Queen Elizabeth asked Faraday what possible use could be made of electricity.']
['Teacher: Wonderful! Now, can you explain how changing magnetic fields can influence the surrounding environment?', 'In the preceding section, we learned that a current creates a magnetic field.']

['Teacher: Exactly! So, based on this knowledge, what do you think happens when a changing magnetic field is present?', 'If nature is symmetrical, then perhaps a magnetic field can create a current.']

['What is the significance of the experiments conducted by Michael Faraday and Joseph Henry in 1831?', 'In 1831, some 12 years after the discovery that an electric current generates a magnetic field, English scientist Michael Faraday (1791–1862) and American scientist Joseph Henry (1797–1878) independently demonstrated that magnetic fields can produce currents.']

['What is the term used to describe the process of generating currents with magnetic fields?', 'The basic process of generating currents with magnetic fields is called induction; this process is also called magnetic induction to distinguish it from charging by induction, which uses the electrostatic Coulomb force.']

["Teacher: How did Faraday respond to Queen Victoria's question about the possible use of electricity after discovering Faraday's law of induction?", 'When Faraday discovered what is now called Faraday’s law of induction, Queen Victoria asked him what possible use was electricity.']
["Teacher: How did Faraday compare the usefulness of electricity to a baby when responding to Queen Victoria's question?", '“Madam,” he replied, “What good is a baby?”']
['What is the importance of currents induced by magnetic fields in our technological society?', 'Today, currents induced by magnetic fields are essential to our technological society.']

['What is one example of a technology that utilizes currents induced by magnetic fields?', 'The electric generator—found in everything from automobiles to bicycles to nuclear power plants—uses magnetism to generate electric current.']

['What role do pickup coils play in the generation of sound in electric guitars and other musical instruments?', 'Other devices that use magnetism to induce currents include pickup coils in electric guitars, transformers of every size, certain microphones, airport security gates, and damping mechanisms on sensitive chemical balances.']

['Teacher: What did Faraday do to demonstrate magnetic induction and measure the resulting electric current through the wire?', 'One experiment Faraday did to demonstrate magnetic induction was to move a bar magnet through a wire coil and measure the resulting electric current through the wire.']
["What is the purpose of moving a bar magnet through a wire coil in Faraday's experiment?", 'A schematic of this experiment is shown in Figure 20.33.']

['What did Faraday find regarding the induction of current in the wire coil when the magnet moves with respect to the coil?', 'He found that current is induced only when the magnet moves with respect to the coil.']

["What happens to the induction of current in the wire coil when the magnet is motionless with respect to the coil during Faraday's experiment?", 'When the magnet is motionless with respect to the coil, no current is induced in the coil, as in Figure 20.33.']

["What are the two factors that can change the direction of the induced current in the wire coil during Faraday's experiment?", 'In addition, moving the magnet in the opposite direction (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) or reversing the poles of the magnet (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) results in a current in the opposite direction.']

['Teacher: What did Faraday reason must exist in order for a current to be induced in the coil?', 'If a current is induced in the coil, Faraday reasoned that there must be what he called an electromotive force pushing the charges through the coil.']

['Teacher: Why did Faraday reason that there must be an electromotive force pushing the charges through the coil when a current is induced?', 'This interpretation turned out to be incorrect; instead, the external source doing the work of moving the magnet adds energy to the charges in the coil.']

['Teacher: How is the electromotive force related to the energy added per unit charge in the coil?', 'The energy added per unit charge has units of volts, so the electromotive force is actually a potential.']
['What is the potential often confused for due to its name?', 'Unfortunately, the name electromotive force stuck and with it the potential for confusing it with a real force.']

['What abbreviation is commonly used for electromotive force?', 'For this reason, we avoid the term electromotive force and just use the abbreviation emf, which has the mathematical symbol  $$\\(\\varepsilon\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the mathematical symbol used to represent the abbreviation "emf"?', 'The emf may be defined as the rate at which energy is drawn from a source per unit current flowing through a circuit.']

['What is the definition of emf in terms of energy and current?', 'Thus, emf is the energy per unit charge added by a source, which contrasts with voltage, which is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the motion of the bar magnet in Figure 20.34 results in the generation of an induced electromotive force in the wire loop?', 'To understand why an emf is generated in a coil due to a moving magnet, consider Figure 20.34, which shows a bar magnet moving downward with respect to a wire loop.']

['Teacher: What happens to the number of magnetic field lines going through the wire loop as the bar magnet moves downward?', 'Initially, seven magnetic field lines are going through the loop (see left-hand image).']

['Teacher: How does the change in the number of magnetic field lines going through the wire loop relate to the motion of the bar magnet downward?', 'Because the magnet is moving away from the coil, only five magnetic field lines are going through the loop after a short time  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  (see right-hand image).']

['Teacher: Why is an electromotive force (emf) induced in the wire loop when there is a change in the number of magnetic field lines going through it?', 'Thus, when a change occurs in the number of magnetic field lines going through the area defined by the wire loop, an emf is induced in the wire loop.']

['Teacher: How can we determine the magnitude and direction of the induced electromotive force in the wire loop when the number of magnetic field lines through it changes?', 'Experiments such as this show that the induced emf is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic field.']

['Teacher: How can we mathematically express the magnitude and direction of the induced electromotive force in the wire loop when the number of magnetic field lines through it changes?', 'Mathematically, we express this as']

['Teacher: What does "ΔB" represent in the context of the magnetic field?', 'Note that magnetic field lines that lie in the plane of the wire loop do not actually pass through the loop, as shown by the left-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['Teacher: How is the area of the loop represented in the figure?', 'In this figure, the arrow coming out of the loop is a vector whose magnitude is the area of the loop and whose direction is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.']

['Teacher: Why does the contribution of the magnetic field lines to the emf increase as the loop is rotated from $$\\theta = 90{^\\circ}$$ to $$\\theta = 0{^\\circ}$$ in Figure 20.35?', 'In Figure 20.35, as the loop is rotated from  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$ to  $$\\({\\theta = 0{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}}\\text{,}\\)$$  the contribution of the magnetic field lines to the emf increases.']

['Teacher: How does the magnitude of the magnetic field affect the contribution to the emf in the wire loop?', 'Thus, what is important in generating an emf in the wire loop is the component of the magnetic field that is perpendicular to the plane of the loop, which is  $$\\({B\\cos\\theta}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Teacher: How is the concept of "ΔB" being analogous to a sail in the wind related to the topic we are studying?', 'This is analogous to a sail in the wind.']

['Teacher: Great analogy! So, based on what you just said, how does the change in the magnitude of the magnetic field, ΔB, affect the conducting loop?', 'Think of the conducting loop as the sail and the magnetic field as the wind.']

["Teacher: That's right! So, if we want to maximize the force on the conducting loop, how should the surface vector of the loop be oriented in relation to the magnetic field?", 'To maximize the force of the wind on the sail, the sail is oriented so that its surface vector points in the same direction as the winds, as in the right-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain what happens to the force on the conducting loop when the surface vector of the loop is parallel to the magnetic field?', 'When the sail is aligned so that its surface vector is perpendicular to the wind, as in the left-most loop in Figure 20.35, then the wind exerts no force on the sail.']

['Teacher: How can we reduce the number of magnetic field lines that go through the conducting loop in Figure 20.35 without moving the magnet?', 'Another way to reduce the number of magnetic field lines that go through the conducting loop in Figure 20.35 is not to move the magnet but to make the loop smaller.']

["Teacher: That's a great observation! Based on what you just mentioned, can you explain why changing the area of a conducting loop in a stable magnetic field induces an emf?", 'Experiments show that changing the area of a conducting loop in a stable magnetic field induces an emf in the loop.']

['Teacher: Can you recall the specific mathematical relationship that describes the proportionality between the induced emf and the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area?', 'Thus, the emf produced in a conducting loop is proportional to the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area']
['Teacher: Can you please explain what the symbol "Δ" represents in the given equation?', 'where  $$\\(B\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is the perpendicular magnetic field and A is the area of the loop.']
['Teacher: Why is the product \\(BA\\cos\\theta\\) considered important in the given equation?', 'The product  $$\\(BA\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is very important.']

['Teacher: How does the quantity \\(BA\\cos\\theta\\) relate to the number of magnetic field lines passing through the surface of area A?', 'It is proportional to the number of magnetic field lines that pass perpendicularly through a surface of area A. Going back to our sail analogy, it would be proportional to the force of the wind on the sail.']
['Teacher: What is the relationship between the magnetic flux (\\(\\text{Φ}\\)) and the product \\(BA\\cos\\theta\\)?', 'It is called the magnetic flux and is represented by  $$\\(\\text{Φ}\\)$$ .']
['Teacher: What is the mathematical representation of magnetic flux?', 'The unit of magnetic flux is the weber (Wb), which is magnetic field per unit area, or T/m2.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you please explain the relationship between magnetic flux and magnetic field in terms of the mathematical representation?", 'The weber is also a volt second (Vs).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the relationship between the number of loops in a coil and the strength of the emf generated?', 'Finally, for a coil made from N loops, the emf is N times stronger than for a single loop.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, how can we mathematically express the relationship between the change in magnetic flux and the change in time for a coil with N loops?", 'Thus, the emf induced by a changing magnetic field in a coil of N loops is']

['Teacher: How did Heinrich Lenz explain the direction of the current flow in relation to the magnetic field and flux?', 'The last question to answer before we can change the proportionality into an equation is “In what direction does the current flow?” The Russian scientist Heinrich Lenz (1804–1865) explained that the current flows in the direction that creates a magnetic field that tries to keep the flux constant in the loop.']

["Teacher: What is the significance of Figure 20.34 in understanding Heinrich Lenz's explanation about the direction of current flow in relation to the magnetic field and flux?", 'For example, consider again Figure 20.34.']

["Teacher: How does the decrease in the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines in Figure 20.34 relate to Heinrich Lenz's explanation of the direction of current flow?", 'The motion of the bar magnet causes the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines that go through the loop to decrease.']

["Teacher: How does the generation of an emf in the loop, as explained by the decrease in the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines, relate to Heinrich Lenz's explanation of the direction of current flow?", 'Therefore, an emf is generated in the loop that drives a current in the direction that creates more upward-pointing magnetic field lines.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to use the right-hand rule when determining the direction of the current flow in the given figure?', 'By using the right-hand rule, we see that this current must flow in the direction shown in the figure.']

["Teacher: What does the introduction of a minus sign into the proportionality equation represent in Faraday's law of induction?", 'To express the fact that the induced emf acts to counter the change in the magnetic flux through a wire loop, a minus sign is introduced into the proportionality  $$\\(\\varepsilon \\propto {{\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}}\\text{.}\\)$$, which gives Faraday’s law of induction.']
["Teacher: Why is Lenz's law considered to be very important in the context of this passage?", 'Lenz’s law is very important.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Figure 20.36 helps in better understanding Lenz's law and the direction of the resulting current in the coil?", 'To better understand it, consider Figure 20.36, which shows a magnet moving with respect to a wire coil and the direction of the resulting current in the coil.']

["What is the significance of the magnetic field lines pointing towards the coil in Figure 20.36 in relation to Lenz's law?", 'In the top row, the north pole of the magnet approaches the coil, so the magnetic field lines from the magnet point toward the coil.']

["What does the increase in the magnetic field direction indicate about the induced current in the coil according to Lenz's law?", 'Thus, the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}} = B_{\\text{mag}}\\left( \\hat{x} \\right)\\)$$  pointing to the right increases in the coil.']

["Teacher: According to Lenz's law, what direction will the induced current in the coil flow in response to the increase in the magnetic field direction?", 'According to Lenz’s law, the emf produced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}} = B_{\\text{coil}}\\left( {- \\hat{x}} \\right)\\)$$  inside the coil pointing to the left.']

["Teacher: How does the induced current in the coil, flowing in the direction that creates a magnetic field inside the coil pointing to the left, counter the increase in magnetic flux pointing to the right, according to Lenz's law?", 'This will counter the increase in magnetic flux pointing to the right.']

["Teacher: How does the process of curling your right fingers help determine the direction of the induced current in the coil, as stated by Lenz's law?", 'To see which way the current must flow, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil,}}\\)$$  and the current will flow in the direction indicated by curling your right fingers.']

["What does the image of the right hand in the top row of Figure 20.36 show in relation to determining the direction of the induced current in the coil, according to Lenz's law?", 'This is shown by the image of the right hand in the top row of Figure 20.36.']

["What does the direction of the induced current shown in Figure 4(a) indicate about the magnitude of the rate of change of magnetic flux according to Lenz's law?", 'Thus, the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(a).']
['Teacher: What happens to the direction in which the magnet moves in Figure 4(b)?', 'In Figure 4(b), the direction in which the magnet moves is reversed.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the direction in which the magnet moves and the right-pointing magnetic field in the coil in Figure 4(b)?', 'In the coil, the right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  due to the moving magnet decreases.']

["Teacher: How does Lenz's law explain the relationship between the decrease in the right-pointing magnetic field due to the moving magnet and the emf in the coil?", 'Lenz’s law says that, to counter this decrease, the emf will drive a current that creates an additional right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}}\\)$$  in the coil.']

["Teacher: How can we determine the direction of the current flow in the coil based on Lenz's law and the right-pointing magnetic field in the coil?", 'Again, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field, and the current will flow in the direction indicate by curling your right fingers (Figure 4(b)).']
['Teacher: In Figure 4(c), what is done to the magnet to change its orientation?', 'Finally, in Figure 4(c), the magnet is reversed so that the south pole is nearest the coil.']

["Teacher: Why does the magnetic field $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$ now point toward the magnet instead of toward the coil after reversing the magnet's orientation in Figure 4(c)?", 'Now the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  points toward the magnet instead of toward the coil.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the orientation of the magnet and the direction of the magnetic field in the coil?', 'As the magnet approaches the coil, it causes the left-pointing magnetic field in the coil to increase.']

["Teacher: According to Lenz's law, what is the direction of the induced current in the coil when the magnet is reversed in orientation?", 'Lenz’s law tells us that the emf induced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field pointing to the right.']

["Teacher: How does the induced current in the coil affect the changing magnetic flux caused by reversing the magnet's orientation?", 'This will counter the increasing magnetic flux pointing to the left due to the magnet.']

['Teacher: How does the direction of the induced current in the coil affect the orientation of the magnetic field caused by reversing the magnet?', 'Using the right-hand rule again, as indicated in the figure, shows that the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(c).']
['Teacher: What is the subject of the first story mentioned in the passage about Blackbodies?', 'Our first story of curious significance begins with a T-shirt.']

['Teacher: Why does wearing a tight black T-shirt outside on a hot day provide a significantly less comfortable experience compared to wearing a white shirt?', 'You are likely aware that wearing a tight black T-shirt outside on a hot day provides a significantly less comfortable experience than wearing a white shirt.']

['Why do black shirts absorb and re-emit a significantly greater amount of radiation from the sun compared to white shirts?', 'Black shirts, as well as all other black objects, will absorb and re-emit a significantly greater amount of radiation from the sun.']
['What does it mean for an object to be a "blackbody"?', 'This shirt is a good approximation of what is called a blackbody.']
['Teacher: How would you define a perfect blackbody?', 'A perfect blackbody is one that absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy that is incident upon it.']
['Teacher: Why is it like wearing a tight shirt that absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy when describing a perfect blackbody?', 'Imagine wearing a tight shirt that did this!']

['Teacher: How is the phenomenon of a perfect blackbody, where it absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy, different from the scenario of wearing a tight shirt?', 'This phenomenon is often modeled with quite a different scenario.']

['Teacher: How does carving a small hole in an oven that can be heated to very high temperatures help model the phenomenon of a perfect blackbody?', 'Imagine carving a small hole in an oven that can be heated to very high temperatures.']

['What happens to the radiation emitted from the small hole in the container as the temperature of the container increases?', 'As the temperature of this container gets hotter and hotter, the radiation out of this dark hole would increase as well, re-emitting all energy provided it by the increased temperature.']
['Why would the hole in the container begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased?', 'The hole may even begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased.']

['What analogy can you use to describe the color change of the glowing hole in the container as the temperature increases?', 'Like a burner on your stove, the hole would glow red, then orange, then blue, as the temperature is increased.']
['Why would the light emitted from the glowing hole eventually become invisible to our eyes?', 'In time, the hole would continue to glow but the light would be invisible to our eyes.']
['What is the significance of the phenomenon of the glowing hole becoming invisible to our eyes in relation to a perfect blackbody?', 'This container is a good model of a perfect blackbody.']

['Teacher: What specific analysis of blackbodies led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century?', 'It is the analysis of blackbodies that led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century.']
['What does Figure 21.2 depict in relation to the analysis of blackbodies?', 'Take a moment to carefully examine Figure 21.2.']

['What key information or insights can be gained from interpreting Figure 21.2 in relation to the analysis of blackbodies?', 'The more time you spend interpreting this figure, the closer you will be to understanding quantum physics!']
['Teacher: How would you describe the plot shown in Figure 21.2 of the textbook?', 'Figure 21.2 is a plot of radiation intensity against radiated wavelength.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the graph in Figure 21.2 is important for understanding blackbody radiation?', 'In other words, it shows how the intensity of radiated light changes when a blackbody is heated to a particular temperature.']
['Teacher: Which line should we follow on the graph to understand the behavior of a red hot object?', 'It may help to just follow the bottom-most red line labeled 3,000 K, red hot.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the red hot object radiates energy across the electromagnetic spectrum when it reaches a temperature of 3,000 K according to the graph?', 'The graph shows that when a blackbody acquires a temperature of 3,000 K, it radiates energy across the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['Teacher: Why is the energy most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm when a blackbody reaches a temperature of 3,000 K according to the graph?', 'However, the energy is most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm.']
['Teacher: What does it mean when we say that the energy is most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm?', 'This is in the infrared portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

["What does it mean for a body to appear 'infrared-hot'?", 'While a body at this temperature would appear red-hot to our eyes, it would truly appear ‘infrared-hot’ if we were able to see the entire spectrum.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens to the total amount of energy radiated as temperature increases, according to Figure 21.2?', 'As temperature increases, the total amount of energy radiated increases.']
['Teacher: How does the figure in Figure 21.2 demonstrate the relationship between temperature and the total amount of energy radiated?', 'This is shown by examining the area underneath each line.']

['Teacher: How does the consistent pattern observed in all red lines on the graph support the relationship between temperature and the total amount of energy radiated?', 'Regardless of temperature, all red lines on the graph undergo a consistent pattern.']

['Teacher: How does Figure 21.2 illustrate the peak wavelength of the electromagnetic radiation emitted at different temperatures?', 'While electromagnetic radiation is emitted throughout the spectrum, the intensity of this radiation peaks at one particular wavelength.']

['Teacher: How does the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity change as temperature changes, according to Figure 21.2?', 'As the temperature changes, the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity changes.']

['Teacher: According to Figure 21.2, what can you conclude about the relationship between temperature and the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity?', 'At 4,000 K, the radiation is most intense in the yellow-green portion of the spectrum.']

['Teacher: How does the color of the radiation emitted change as the temperature of the blackbody increases, as shown in Figure 21.2?', 'At 6,000 K, the blackbody would radiate white hot, due to intense radiation throughout the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['Teacher: How does the emission of all visible colors simultaneously contribute to the white hot appearance of the blackbody at 6,000 K, as mentioned in Figure 21.2?', 'Remember that white light is the emission of all visible colors simultaneously.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the relationship between frequency and temperature based on Figure 21.2?', 'As the temperature increases, the frequency of light providing the greatest intensity increases as well.']
['Teacher: According to Figure 21.2, how does the relationship between frequency and wavelength relate to the increase in temperature?', 'Recall the equation  $$\\(v = f\\lambda.\\)$$']

['Teacher: How does the equation \\(v = f\\lambda\\) explain the relationship between frequency and wavelength mentioned in Figure 21.2?', 'Because the speed of light is constant, frequency and wavelength are inversely related.']
['What evidence in Figure 21.2 supports the statement that the speed of light is constant?', 'This is verified by the leftward movement of the three red lines as temperature is increased.']

['Teacher: Why is theorizing about the observations crucial to scientific advancement?', 'While in science it is important to categorize observations, theorizing as to why the observations exist is crucial to scientific advancement.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on why questions about theorizing drove significant research at the turn of the twentieth century?', 'It is questions like these that drove significant research at the turn of the twentieth century.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what Max Planck discovered that was of tremendous importance within the context of these questions?', 'And within the context of these questions, Max Planck discovered something of tremendous importance.']

["Teacher: Can you explain the prevailing theory that was in place before Max Planck's discovery?", 'The prevailing theory at the time of Max Planck’s discovery was that intensity and frequency were related by the equation  $$\\(I = \\frac{2kT}{\\lambda^{2}}.\\)$$']

['Teacher: How did the prevailing theory, based on classical physics and wave phenomena, describe the relationship between intensity and wavelength?', 'This equation, derived from classical physics and using wave phenomena, infers that as wavelength increases, the intensity of energy provided will decrease with an inverse-squared relationship.']

['What was the troubling trend shown in Figure 21.3 regarding the relationship between wavelength and intensity of energy?', 'This relationship is graphed in Figure 21.3 and shows a troubling trend.']

['What deviation or discrepancy is observed between the graph from the prevailing theory equation and the blackbody graphs obtained through experimentation?', 'For starters, it should be apparent that the graph from this equation does not match the blackbody graphs found experimentally.']

['Teacher: What was the significance or implication of the fact that the prevailing theory predicted an infinite amount of energy emission at the shortest wavelengths for objects of any temperature?', 'Additionally, it shows that for an object of any temperature, there should be an infinite amount of energy quickly emitted in the shortest wavelengths.']
['What did Max Planck propose as a solution or alternative to the prevailing theory?', 'When theory and experimental results clash, it is important to re-evaluate both models.']
['How did Max Planck propose to address the issue of the ultraviolet catastrophe?', 'The disconnect between theory and reality was termed the ultraviolet catastrophe.']

['Teacher: What was it that Max Planck began to question due to concerns over the ultraviolet catastrophe, regarding the relationship between intensity and wavelength?', 'Due to concerns over the ultraviolet catastrophe, Max Planck began to question whether another factor impacted the relationship between intensity and wavelength.']

['What was the factor that Max Planck proposed could affect the probability of short wavelength light being emitted?', 'This factor, he posited, should affect the probability that short wavelength light would be emitted.']

['What effect would this proposed factor have on the radiance curve?', 'Should this factor reduce the probability of short wavelength light, it would cause the radiance curve to not progress infinitely as in the classical theory, but would instead cause the curve to precipitate back downward as is shown in the 5,000 K, 4,000 K, and 3,000 K temperature lines of the graph in Figure 21.3.']

['What did Planck conclude about the relationship between the proposed factor and temperature in his study?', 'Planck noted that this factor, whatever it may be, must also be dependent on temperature, as the intensity decreases at lower and lower wavelengths as the temperature increases.']

["Teacher: What did the determination of the probability factor in Planck's Revolution provide insight into?", 'The determination of this probability factor was a groundbreaking discovery in physics, yielding insight not just into light but also into energy and matter itself.']

["What were the implications of Planck's determination of the probability factor in terms of physics?", 'It would be the basis for Planck’s 1918 Nobel Prize in Physics and would result in the transition of physics from classical to modern understanding.']

['What theory did Max Planck construct in an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor?', 'In an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor, Max Planck constructed a new theory.']

['What is the name of the theory that Max Planck constructed in order to determine the cause of the probability factor?', 'This theory, which created the branch of physics called quantum mechanics, speculated that the energy radiated by the blackbody could exist only in specific numerical, or quantum, states.']

["What is the equation that describes Planck's theory of quantum mechanics?", 'This theory is described by the equation  $$\\(E = nhf,\\)$$  where n is any nonnegative integer (0, 1, 2, 3, …) and h is Planck’s constant, given by  $$\\(h = 6.626\\  \\times \\ 10^{-34}\\text']
["What are the units of Planck's constant?", '{J} \\cdot \\text{s},\\)$$  and f is frequency.']
["Teacher: How can Planck's probability factor be more clearly understood?", 'Through this equation, Planck’s probability factor can be more clearly understood.']
["What is the equation that can help us understand Planck's probability factor more clearly?", 'Each frequency of light provides a specific quantized amount of energy.']

["What determines the amount of energy provided by each frequency of light according to Planck's theory?", 'Low frequency light, associated with longer wavelengths would provide a smaller amount of energy, while high frequency light, associated with shorter wavelengths, would provide a larger amount of energy.']

["What is the relationship between the specified temperatures, specific total energies, and the amount of low frequency light versus high frequency light radiated according to Planck's theory?", 'For specified temperatures with specific total energies, it makes sense that more low frequency light would be radiated than high frequency light.']

["What analogy does the student use to describe the relationship between specified temperatures, specific total energies, and the amount of low frequency light versus high frequency light radiated according to Planck's theory?", 'To a degree, the relationship is like pouring coins through a funnel.']

["What can we infer about the passage of low frequency light and high frequency light through a filter, based on the student's analogy of pouring coins through a funnel?", 'More of the smaller pennies would be able to pass through the funnel than the larger quarters.']

["What can be said about the probability of high frequency light passing through a filter, based on the student's analogy of pouring coins through a funnel?", 'In other words, because the value of the coin is somewhat related to the size of the coin, the probability of a quarter passing through the funnel is reduced!']

['Teacher: Can you explain how an increase in temperature is related to the presence of higher energy, according to Planck’s Revolution?', 'Furthermore, an increase in temperature would signify the presence of higher energy.']

["How does the presence of higher energy relate to the radiated high frequency, short wavelength energies in the context of Planck's Revolution?", 'As a result, the greater amount of total blackbody energy would allow for more of the high frequency, short wavelength, energies to be radiated.']

["What effect does the increase in temperature have on the peak of the blackbody curve in Planck's Revolution?", 'This permits the peak of the blackbody curve to drift leftward as the temperature increases, as it does from the 3,000 K to 4,000 K to 5,000 K values.']
["How does increasing the temperature affect the range of frequencies and wavelengths in Planck's Revolution?", 'Furthering our coin analogy, consider a wider funnel.']

["How does the wider funnel analogy relate to the range of frequencies and wavelengths in Planck's Revolution?", 'This funnel would permit more quarters to pass through and allow for a reduction in concern about the probability factor.']

["Teacher: What factor contributes to the creation of the curve illustrated in Figure 21.3 in relation to Planck's Revolution?", 'In summary, it is the interplay between the predicted classical model and the quantum probability that creates the curve depicted in Figure 21.3.']

["What is the relationship between higher frequencies and larger amounts of energy, according to the student's explanation?", 'Just as quarters have a higher currency denomination than pennies, higher frequencies come with larger amounts of energy.']

["What is the connection between the probability of a high frequency light existing in a fixed temperature object and the passage's explanation of the interplay between classical model and quantum probability?", 'However, just as the probability of a quarter passing through a fixed diameter funnel is reduced, so is the probability of a high frequency light existing in a fixed temperature object.']

['What does the student imply about the significance of balancing multiple ideas in physics?', 'As is often the case in physics, it is the balancing of multiple incredible ideas that finally allows for better understanding.']
['Teacher: How can we deepen our understanding of quantum states at this point?', 'It may be helpful at this point to further consider the idea of quantum states.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of physical entities that are quantized and explain why they appear only in certain discrete values?', 'Atoms, molecules, and fundamental electron and proton charges are all examples of physical entities that are quantized—that is, they appear only in certain discrete values and do not have every conceivable value.']
['Teacher: Can you elaborate on why the concept of quantization is not revolutionary on a macroscopic scale?', 'On the macroscopic scale, this is not a revolutionary concept.']

['Teacher: Why does the idea of quantization not apply in a revolutionary way on a macroscopic scale, like with a standing wave on a string?', 'A standing wave on a string allows only particular harmonics described by integers.']

['Teacher: Can you think of another example in the macroscopic world where quantization is evident?', 'Going up and down a hill using discrete stair steps causes your potential energy to take on discrete values as you move from step to step.']

["Teacher: Why is it not possible to have a fraction of an atom or part of an electron's charge in the macroscopic world?", 'Furthermore, we cannot have a fraction of an atom, or part of an electron’s charge, or 14.33 cents.']
['Why is everything in the macroscopic world built of integral multiples of substructures?', 'Rather, everything is built of integral multiples of these substructures.']

['Teacher: What was surprising about discovering quantum states within a phenomenon that science had always considered continuous?', 'That said, to discover quantum states within a phenomenon that science had always considered continuous would certainly be surprising.']

["Teacher: How did Max Planck's use of quantization to describe the blackbody spectrum contribute to our understanding of energy?", 'When Max Planck was able to use quantization to correctly describe the experimentally known shape of the blackbody spectrum, it was the first indication that energy was quantized on a small scale as well.']

["Teacher: What impact did Max Planck's discovery of energy quantization have on the field of physics?", 'This discovery earned Planck the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918 and was such a revolutionary departure from classical physics that Planck himself was reluctant to accept his own idea.']

["Teacher: How did Einstein's explanation of the photoelectric effect further support the idea of energy quantization?", 'The general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization was greatly enhanced by Einstein’s explanation of the photoelectric effect (discussed in the next section), which took energy quantization a step further.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the process of ejecting electrons from certain materials when light strikes them?', 'When light strikes certain materials, it can eject electrons from them.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain why this phenomenon is called the photoelectric effect?', 'This is called the photoelectric effect, meaning that light (photo) produces electricity.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you provide another example of a practical application of the photoelectric effect?", 'One common use of the photoelectric effect is in light meters, such as those that adjust the automatic iris in various types of cameras.']

["Teacher: That's right! Can you explain how the photoelectric effect is utilized in the functioning of light meters in cameras?", 'Another use is in solar cells, as you probably have in your calculator or have seen on a rooftop or a roadside sign.']

['Teacher: How does the photoelectric effect allow solar cells to convert light into electricity?', 'These make use of the photoelectric effect to convert light into electricity for running different devices.']

["Teacher: What was Max Planck's contribution in his theory regarding the quantization of energy in a blackbody radiator, and why was it considered revolutionary?", 'When Max Planck theorized that energy was quantized in a blackbody radiator, it is unlikely that he would have recognized just how revolutionary his idea was.']

["Teacher: How did Albert Einstein contribute to exploring the implications of Max Planck's theory on the quantization of energy in a blackbody radiator?", 'Using tools similar to the light meter in Figure 21.5, it would take a scientist of Albert Einstein’s stature to fully discover the implications of Max Planck’s radical concept.']

['Teacher: What did Albert Einstein realize through careful observations of the photoelectric effect that led him to the conclusion that EM radiation is quantized?', 'Through careful observations of the photoelectric effect, Albert Einstein realized that there were several characteristics that could be explained only if EM radiation is itself quantized.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of one of the characteristics that Albert Einstein observed in the photoelectric effect that could only be explained if EM radiation is quantized?', 'While these characteristics will be explained a bit later in this section, you can already begin to appreciate why Einstein’s idea is very important.']

['Teacher: How does the idea of EM radiation being quantized affect our understanding of the apparently continuous stream of energy in an EM wave?', 'It means that the apparently continuous stream of energy in an EM wave is actually not a continuous stream at all.']

['Teacher: What term is used to describe the tiny quantum packets of energy that compose an electromagnetic wave?', 'In fact, the EM wave itself is actually composed of tiny quantum packets of energy called photons.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what the variables E, f, and h represent in the equation E = hf?', 'where E is the energy of a photon of frequency f and h is Planck’s constant.']

['Teacher: How does the equation E = hf explain the nature of light as a beam from a flashlight?', 'A beam from a flashlight, which to this point had been considered a wave, instead could now be viewed as a series of photons, each providing a specific amount of energy see Figure 21.6.']

['Teacher: How does the equation E = hf help us understand the energy of photons in a beam from a flashlight?', 'Furthermore, the amount of energy within each individual photon is based upon its individual frequency, as dictated by  $$\\(E = hf.\\)$$']

['Teacher: How can we determine the total amount of energy provided by a beam from a flashlight using the equation E = hf?', 'As a result, the total amount of energy provided by the beam could now be viewed as the sum of all frequency-dependent photon energies added together.']

["Teacher: Why was it necessary for Einstein's concept of the photon to succeed where classical physics failed in order to be accepted by the scientific community?", 'Just as with Planck’s blackbody radiation, Einstein’s concept of the photon could take hold in the scientific community only if it could succeed where classical physics failed.']
["Why was the photoelectric effect considered to be a key in demonstrating Einstein's brilliance?", 'The photoelectric effect would be a key to demonstrating Einstein’s brilliance.']
['Teacher: Can you please explain the significance of the five properties of the photoelectric effect?', 'Consider the following five properties of the photoelectric effect.']

['Teacher: How do the five properties of the photoelectric effect support the hypothesis that individual photons of EM radiation are absorbed by individual electrons?', 'All of these properties are consistent with the idea that individual photons of EM radiation are absorbed by individual electrons in a material, with the electron gaining the photon’s energy.']

['Teacher: Which specific property of the photoelectric effect suggests that EM radiation is not a simple wave?', 'Some of these properties are inconsistent with the idea that EM radiation is a simple wave.']

['Teacher: How does the property of the photoelectric effect related to monochromatic EM radiation support or contradict the idea that EM radiation is a simple wave?', 'For simplicity, let us consider what happens with monochromatic EM radiation in which all photons have the same energy hf.']

['Teacher: What do we find when we vary the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'If we vary the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface, we find the following:']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the threshold frequency (f0) is significant when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'For a given material, there is a threshold frequency f0 for the EM radiation below which no electrons are ejected, regardless of intensity.']

['Teacher: How does the photon model explain the significance of the threshold frequency (f0) when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'Using the photon model, the explanation for this is clear.']

['Teacher: How do individual photons interact with individual electrons when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'Individual photons interact with individual electrons.']

['Teacher: How does the energy of an individual photon relate to the ejection of electrons when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'Thus if the energy of an individual photon is too low to break an electron away, no electrons will be ejected.']

['Teacher: Why is increasing the intensity not sufficient to eject electrons if EM radiation were a simple wave?', 'However, if EM radiation were a simple wave, sufficient energy could be obtained simply by increasing the intensity.']

['Teacher: What is the role of the frequency of the EM radiation in the ejection of electrons from a clean metal surface?', 'Once EM radiation falls on a material, electrons are ejected without delay.']

['Teacher: How does the ejection of electrons from a clean metal surface occur when an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron?', 'As soon as an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron, the electron is ejected.']

['Teacher: In light of what you just mentioned, why is the ejection of electrons quicker when the EM radiation consists of individual photons of sufficiently high frequency, rather than a simple wave?', 'If the EM radiation were a simple wave, several minutes would be required for sufficient energy to be deposited at the metal surface in order to eject an electron.']

['What determines the number of electrons ejected per unit time when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'The number of electrons ejected per unit time is proportional to the intensity of the EM radiation and to no other characteristic.']

['What happens to the number of electrons ejected per unit time when the intensity of the EM radiation is increased?', 'High-intensity EM radiation consists of large numbers of photons per unit area, with all photons having the same characteristic energy, hf.']

['What is the relationship between the number of photons per unit area and the number of electrons per unit area ejected when the intensity of the EM radiation is increased?', 'The increased number of photons per unit area results in an increased number of electrons per unit area ejected.']

['What do we find if we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons?', 'If we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons, we find the following:']

['What does the maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons depend on when we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons?', 'The maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons is independent of the intensity of the EM radiation.']

['What determines the maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons when we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons?', 'Instead, as noted in point 3 above, increased intensity results in more electrons of the same energy being ejected.']

['How does the energy of ejected electrons depend on the intensity of the EM radiation when varying the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'If EM radiation were a simple wave, a higher intensity could transfer more energy, and higher-energy electrons would be ejected.']

['What is the equation for the kinetic energy (KE) of an ejected electron in terms of the photon energy and the binding energy (BE) of the electron?', 'The kinetic energy KE of an ejected electron equals the photon energy minus the binding energy BE of the electron in the specific material.']
['What does it mean when an individual photon gives all of its energy to an electron?', 'An individual photon can give all of its energy to an electron.']

['How does the energy transferred from an individual photon to an electron contribute to the ejection of the electron from the material?', 'The photon’s energy is partly used to break the electron away from the material.']
['What happens to the remaining energy of the individual photon after it breaks the electron away from the material?', 'The remainder goes into the ejected electron’s kinetic energy.']

['What is the equation that relates the kinetic energy of an ejected electron, the photon energy, and the binding energy of the electron in the specific material?', 'In equation form, this is given by']

["Teacher: What is the relationship between $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$, the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electron, and the photon's energy, represented by $$\\(hf\\)$$, and also the binding energy of the electron, BE?", 'where  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  is the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electron,  $$\\(hf\\)$$  is the photon’s energy, and BE is the binding energy of the electron to the particular material.']

['Teacher: How does the given equation explain the properties of the photoelectric effect quantitatively?', 'This equation explains the properties of the photoelectric effect quantitatively and demonstrates that BE is the minimum amount of energy necessary to eject an electron.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the electron cannot be ejected if the energy supplied is less than the binding energy (BE)?', 'If the energy supplied is less than BE, the electron cannot be ejected.']

['Teacher: How does the threshold frequency (f0) relate to the binding energy (BE) in the context of the photoelectric effect?', 'The binding energy can also be written as  $$\\(BE = hf_{0},\\)$$  where  $$\\(f_{0}\\)$$  is the threshold frequency for the particular material.']

['What does the graph in Figure 21.8 show in terms of the relationship between the maximum $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$ and the frequency of incident electromagnetic radiation?', 'Figure 21.8 shows a graph of maximum  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  versus the frequency of incident EM radiation falling on a particular material.']

["Teacher: How significant was Einstein's understanding of the photoelectric effect in the early 1900s?", 'While Einstein’s understanding of the photoelectric effect was a transformative discovery in the early 1900s, its presence is ubiquitous today.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of everyday devices that utilize the photoelectric effect for detection?', 'If you have watched streetlights turn on automatically in response to the setting sun, stopped elevator doors from closing simply by putting your hands between them, or turned on a water faucet by sliding your hands near it, you are familiar with the electric eye, a name given to a group of devices that use the photoelectric effect for detection.']
['Teacher: What is the common factor among all these devices?', 'All these devices rely on photoconductive cells.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain how the activation of photoconductive cells occurs when light is absorbed by a semi-conductive material?", 'These cells are activated when light is absorbed by a semi-conductive material, knocking off a free electron.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the nearby electron being attracted to the electron void left behind in a photoconductive cell?', 'When this happens, an electron void is left behind, which attracts a nearby electron.']
