['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Now, could you please explain how this movement of electrons in a photoconductive cell leads to the production of a current?', 'The movement of this electron, and the resultant chain of electron movements, produces a current.']

['Teacher: How does the continued process of electron ejection and creation of holes in a photoconductive cell affect its electrical conductivity?', 'If electron ejection continues, further holes are created, thereby increasing the electrical conductivity of the cell.']

['What are some examples of familiar mechanisms that can be activated by the current produced in a photoconductive cell?', 'This current can turn switches on and off and activate various familiar mechanisms.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of where this particular mechanism occurs, even in unexpected places?', 'One such mechanism takes place where you may not expect it.']

['Teacher: How does the photoelectric effect play a role in the sound system at movie theaters?', 'Next time you are at the movie theater, pay close attention to the sound coming out of the speakers.']
['Teacher: How does the photoelectric effect contribute to the production of sound in movie theaters?', 'This sound is actually created using the photoelectric effect!']
['What role does the audiotape play in the photoelectric effect for sound production in movie theaters?', 'The audiotape in the projector booth is a transparent piece of film of varying width.']

['What happens when the varying width of the audiotape passes between the photocell and the bright light produced by the exciter lamp?', 'This film is fed between a photocell and a bright light produced by an exciter lamp.']

['What effect does the varying width of the audiotape have on the amount of light that strikes the photocell in the movie theater sound system?', 'As the transparent portion of the film varies in width, the amount of light that strikes the photocell varies as well.']

['How does the change in current in the photoconductive circuit affect the production of sound in movie theaters?', 'As a result, the current in the photoconductive circuit changes with the width of the filmstrip.']

['What happens when the changing current is converted to a changing frequency in the photoconductive circuit of the movie theater sound system?', 'This changing current is converted to a changing frequency, which creates the soundtrack commonly heard in the theater.']
['Teacher: Is it unusual to think about it, or is it something we commonly accept?', 'Although strange to consider, the answer to both questions is yes.']

['Teacher: What did scientists prior to Einstein suspect about the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation in relation to macroscopic particles?', 'Despite the odd nature of photons, scientists prior to Einstein had long suspected that the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation shared properties with our more macroscopic particles.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how scientists observed the shared properties between the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation and macroscopic particles?', 'This is no clearer than when considering the photoelectric effect, where photons knock electrons out of a substance.']

['Teacher: How did scientists explain the phenomenon of photons knocking electrons out of a substance, despite being massless?', 'While it is strange to think of a massless particle exhibiting momentum, it is now a well-established fact within the scientific community.']
['Teacher: What does Figure 21.10 show in relation to photon momentum?', 'Figure 21.10 shows macroscopic evidence of photon momentum.']
['Teacher: What is depicted in Figure 21.10?', 'Figure 21.10 shows a comet with two prominent tails.']
['Teacher: What are comet tails primarily composed of?', 'Comet tails are composed of gases and dust evaporated from the body of the comet and ionized gas.']
['Teacher: Why do comet tails always point away from the Sun?', 'What most people do not know about the tails is that they always point away from the Sun rather than trailing behind the comet.']
['Teacher: How does the momentum of photons play a role in the direction of comet tails?', 'This can be seen in the diagram.']

['Teacher: What does the evidence indicate about the dust particles of the comet when photons strike them?', 'The evidence indicates that the dust particles of the comet are forced away from the Sun when photons strike them.']

['Teacher: How do photons transfer their momentum to the dust particles of the comet when they strike them?', 'Evidently, photons carry momentum in the direction of their motion away from the Sun, and some of this momentum is transferred to dust particles in collisions.']

['Teacher: What is the cause of the blue tail of the comet, according to the passage?', 'The blue tail is caused by the solar wind, a stream of plasma consisting primarily of protons and electrons evaporating from the corona of the Sun.']
["Teacher: In what fields is momentum conserved, according to the student's statement?", 'Momentum is conserved in quantum mechanics, just as it is in relativity and classical physics.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the Compton Effect and how it relates to the conservation of momentum?', 'Some of the earliest direct experimental evidence of this came from the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons in substances, a phenomenon discovered by American physicist Arthur H. Compton (1892–1962).']

["Teacher: What is the significance of Compton's observation regarding the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons?", 'Around 1923, Compton observed that X-rays reflecting from materials had decreased energy and correctly interpreted this as being due to the scattering of the X-ray photons by electrons.']

['Teacher: How does the observation of the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons support the conservation of momentum in the Compton Effect?', 'This phenomenon could be handled as a collision between two particles—a photon and an electron at rest in the material.']

['Teacher: What happens to the energy and momentum of the photon and electron in the collision between the two particles?', 'After careful observation, it was found that both energy and momentum were conserved in the collision.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of Solar Sails and how they relate to momentum conservation?', 'See Figure 21.11.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of Solar Sails relate to momentum conservation?', 'For the discovery of this conserved scattering, now known as the Compton effect, Arthur Compton was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1929.']
['Teacher: Who determined the value of the photon momentum shortly after the discovery of Compton scattering?', 'was determined by Louis de Broglie.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the de Broglie relation involves and how it relates to the determination of photon momentum?', 'In this equation, called the de Broglie relation, h represents Planck’s constant and λ is the photon wavelength.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the photon momentum is small, considering the equation  p = h/λ and the value of h?', 'We can see that photon momentum is small, since  $$\\(\\mathbf{p} = h/\\lambda.\\)$$  and h is very small.']
['Teacher: How does the small value of h contribute to the observed smallness of photon momentum?', 'It is for this reason that we do not ordinarily observe photon momentum.']
['What could be a possible explanation for why our mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them?', 'Our mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them, except perhaps in cartoons.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on why Compton saw the effects of photon momentum specifically when observing X-rays interacting with electrons?', 'Compton saw the effects of photon momentum because he was observing X-rays, which have a small wavelength and a relatively large momentum, interacting with the lightest of particles, the electron.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics of electromagnetic radiation that make it similar to a wave?', 'We have long known that EM radiation is like a wave, capable of interference and diffraction.']
['Teacher: How do we now model light besides its wave-like characteristics?', 'We now see that light can also be modeled as particles—massless photons of discrete energy and momentum.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the particle-wave duality of EM radiation is demonstrated in experiments or observations?', 'We call this twofold nature the particle-wave duality, meaning that EM radiation has properties of both particles and waves.']

['Teacher: Why is it surprising that electromagnetic radiation exhibits properties of both particles and waves?', 'This may seem contradictory, since we ordinarily deal with large objects that never act like both waves and particles.']
['Teacher: What is an example of a large object that behaves only as either a wave or a particle, but not both?', 'An ocean wave, for example, looks nothing like a grain of sand.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an analogy to help explain the concept of particle-wave duality in electromagnetic radiation?', 'However, this so-called duality is simply a term for properties of the photon analogous to phenomena we can observe directly, on a macroscopic scale.']
['Teacher: What does Figure 21.14 illustrate about the concept of particle-wave duality in electromagnetic radiation?', 'See Figure 21.14.']

['Teacher: How does the illustration in Figure 21.14 support the idea that we can observe either particle-like or wave-like properties of electromagnetic radiation, but not both at the same time?', 'If this term seems strange, it is because we do not ordinarily observe details on the quantum level directly, and our observations yield either particle-like or wave-like properties, but never both simultaneously.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the connection between photons and matter in terms of exploring the possibility of a particle-wave duality for matter?', 'Since we have a particle-wave duality for photons, and since we have seen connections between photons and matter in that both have momentum, it is reasonable to ask whether there is a particle-wave duality for matter as well.']
['What is the answer to the possibility of a particle-wave duality for matter?', 'The answer, strangely, is yes.']

['What are some of the consequences of the existence of particle-wave duality for matter?', 'The consequences of this are tremendous, as particle-wave duality has been a constant source of scientific wonder during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.']

['Teacher: How would you describe our current knowledge about atoms?', 'While often taken for granted, our knowledge of the existence and structure of atoms is the result of centuries of contemplation and experimentation.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the speculation on atoms made by Leucippus and Democritus in the fifth century B.C.?', 'The earliest known speculation on the atom dates back to the fifth century B.C., when Greek philosophers Leucippus and Democritus contemplated whether a substance could be divided without limit into ever smaller pieces.']

['Teacher: Who were some of the scientists that contributed to our understanding of the fundamental structure of matter?', 'Since then, scientists such as John Dalton (1766–1844), Amadeo Avogadro (1776–1856), and Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) helped to discover the properties of that fundamental structure of matter.']

['Teacher: What specific role did Ernest Rutherford (1871-1937) play in our understanding of the fundamental structure of matter?', 'While much could be written about any number of important scientific philosophers, this section will focus on the role played by Ernest Rutherford (1871–1937).']

['Teacher: What surprising discovery did Ernest Rutherford make about the interior of the atom that was fundamental in explaining many well-known phenomena?', 'Though his understanding of our most elemental matter is rooted in the success of countless prior investigations, his surprising discovery about the interior of the atom is most fundamental in explaining so many well-known phenomena.']
["Teacher: What was the accepted model of the atom in the early 1900's?", 'In the early 1900’s, the plum pudding model was the accepted model of the atom.']

['What were some of the characteristics of the plum pudding model of the atom proposed by J.J. Thomson in 1904?', 'Proposed in 1904 by J. J. Thomson, the model suggested that the atom was a spherical ball of positive charge, with negatively charged electrons scattered evenly throughout.']

['What were some of the problems or limitations of the plum pudding model of the atom proposed by J.J. Thomson?', 'In that model, the positive charges made up the pudding, while the electrons acted as isolated plums.']

["What did Rutherford's experiment reveal about the structure of the atom?", 'During its short life, the model could be used to explain why most particles were neutral, although with an unbalanced number of plums, electrically charged atoms could exist.']

["Teacher: What was the model that was challenged in Ernest Rutherford's gold foil experiment in 1909?", 'When Ernest Rutherford began his gold foil experiment in 1909, it is unlikely that anyone would have expected that the plum pudding model would be challenged.']

["What was the result of Rutherford's gold foil experiment that challenged the plum pudding model?", 'However, using a radioactive source, a thin sheet of gold foil, and a phosphorescent screen, Rutherford would uncover something so great that he would later call it “the most incredible event that has ever happened to me in my life”[James, L. K. (1993).']
['What did Rutherford discover in his gold foil experiment that he considered to be the most incredible event of his life?', 'Nobel Laureates in Chemistry, 1901–1992.']
['Who were some of the Nobel Laureates in Chemistry from 1901 to 1992?', 'Washington, DC: American Chemical Society.]']
['Teacher: Can you please describe the experiment that Rutherford designed as depicted in Figure 22.2?', 'The experiment that Rutherford designed is shown in Figure 22.2.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of placing the radioactive source in a lead container with a hole in one side?\nor\nTeacher: Why were positively charged helium particles, called alpha particles, used in the experiment?', 'As you can see in, a radioactive source was placed in a lead container with a hole in one side to produce a beam of positively charged helium particles, called alpha particles.']
['Teacher: Why was a thin gold foil sheet placed in the beam of alpha particles?', 'Then, a thin gold foil sheet was placed in the beam.']
["Teacher: Can you explain why the scattering of alpha particles was important in Rutherford's experiment?", 'When the high-energy alpha particles passed through the gold foil, they were scattered.']

['What conclusions did Rutherford draw from the scattering of alpha particles in his experiment?', 'The scattering was observed from the bright spots they produced when they struck the phosphor screen.']

["Teacher: What was the expectation of the plum pudding model regarding the behavior of high-energy alpha particles in the presence of the gold sheet in Rutherford's experiment?", 'The expectation of the plum pudding model was that the high-energy alpha particles would be scattered only slightly by the presence of the gold sheet.']

["Why did the high-energy alpha particles in Rutherford's experiment not behave as expected according to the plum pudding model?", 'Because the energy of the alpha particles was much higher than those typically associated with atoms, the alpha particles should have passed through the thin foil much like a supersonic bowling ball would crash through a few dozen rows of bowling pins.']

["What was the actual behavior of the high-energy alpha particles in Rutherford's experiment when they passed through the gold sheet?", 'Any deflection was expected to be minor, and due primarily to the electrostatic Coulomb force between the alpha particles and the foil’s interior electric charges.']
["Teacher: Can you explain why the true result of Rutherford's experiment was not what was expected?", 'However, the true result was nothing of the sort.']

['Teacher: What did Rutherford and his collaborators observe during the experiment with alpha particles and the foil?', 'While the majority of alpha particles passed through the foil unobstructed, Rutherford and his collaborators Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden found that alpha particles occasionally were scattered to large angles, and some even came back in the direction from which they came!']

["What was the implication of the scattering of alpha particles in Rutherford's experiment on the size of gold nuclei and gold atoms?", 'The result, called Rutherford scattering, implied that the gold nuclei were actually very small when compared with the size of the gold atom.']

["What was the significance of the scattering of alpha particles in Rutherford's experiment on our understanding of the structure of an atom?", 'As shown in Figure 22.3, the dense nucleus is surrounded by mostly empty space of the atom, an idea verified by the fact that only 1 in 8,000 particles was scattered backward.']

["Teacher: Why did it take Rutherford two years to convince himself of the meaning of the experiment's results?", 'Although the results of the experiment were published by his colleagues in 1909, it took Rutherford two years to convince himself of their meaning.']

["What was Rutherford's initial reaction to the results of the experiment?", 'Rutherford later wrote: “It was almost as incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.']

["What eventually led Rutherford to realize the concentration of mass in the atom's nucleus?", 'On consideration, I realized that this scattering backwards ... [meant] ... the greatest part of the mass of the atom was concentrated in a tiny nucleus.”']

["What was the significance of Rutherford's analysis and proposed model of the atom that he published in 1911?", 'In 1911, Rutherford published his analysis together with a proposed model of the atom, which was in part based on Geiger’s work from the previous year.']

["What did Rutherford's analysis and proposed model of the atom in 1911 help determine about the size of the nucleus?", 'As a result of the paper, the size of the nucleus was determined to be about  $$\\(10^{-15}\\)$$  m, or 100,000 times smaller than the atom.']

["What does Rutherford's proposed model of the atom imply about the density of the nucleus?", 'That implies a huge density, on the order of  $$\\(10^{15}\\)$$  g/cm3, much greater than any macroscopic matter.']

["Teacher: What did Rutherford propose about the atom's structure after his experiment revealed the size and mass of the nucleus, as well as the mass of electrons?", 'Based on the size and mass of the nucleus revealed by his experiment, as well as the mass of electrons, Rutherford proposed the planetary model of the atom.']

["What did Rutherford's planetary model of the atom depict regarding the location of low-mass electrons and a large-mass nucleus?", 'The planetary model of the atom pictures low-mass electrons orbiting a large-mass nucleus.']

["What information about the size of electron orbits and the composition of the atom does Rutherford's experiment reveal?", 'The sizes of the electron orbits are large compared with the size of the nucleus, and most of the atom is a vacuum.']

["What is the analogy that Rutherford's planetary model of the atom draws between the electron orbits and our solar system?", 'The model is analogous to how low-mass planets in our solar system orbit the large-mass Sun.']
['What force in the atom is analogous to gravitation in the planetary system?', 'In the atom, the attractive Coulomb force is analogous to gravitation in the planetary system (see Figure 22.4).']

['Teacher: How did Max Planck contribute to our understanding of the emission of energy from a source?', 'In 1900, Max Planck recognized that all energy radiated from a source is emitted by atoms in quantum states.']

["Teacher: Can you explain what Max Planck's recognition about the emission of energy from a source helped scientists discover about the spectrum of light produced by an energized gas?", 'The answer was first found by investigating the spectrum of light or emission spectrum produced when a gas is highly energized.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how Figure 22.5 demonstrates the process of isolating the emission spectrum of a specific gas?', 'Figure 22.5 shows how to isolate the emission spectrum of one such gas.']

['What is the purpose of placing the gas in the discharge tube and energizing it in the process of isolating the emission spectrum of a specific gas?', 'The gas is placed in the discharge tube at the left, where it is energized to the point at which it begins to radiate energy or emit light.']

['Why is the light passed through a diffraction grating in the process of isolating the emission spectrum of a specific gas?', 'The radiated light is channeled by a thin slit and then passed through a diffraction grating, which will separate the light into its constituent wavelengths.']
['What happens when the separated light strikes the photographic film on the right?', 'The separated light will then strike the photographic film on the right.']

['Teacher: What does the line spectrum shown in part (b) of Figure 22.5 represent for excited iron?', 'The line spectrum shown in part (b) of Figure 22.5 is the output shown on the film for excited iron.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the appearance of the line spectrum shown in part (b) of Figure 22.5?', 'Note that this spectrum is not continuous but discrete.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the line spectrum for excited iron is described as discrete and not continuous?', 'In other words, only particular wavelengths are emitted by the iron source.']

['Teacher: What can you tell me about the spectrum of light emitted by excited iron within the visible spectrum?', 'The spectrum of light created by excited iron shows a variety of discrete wavelengths emitted within the visible spectrum.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by a "discrete emission spectrum"?', 'Each element, when excited to the appropriate degree, will create a discrete emission spectrum as in part (b) of Figure 22.5.']
['Teacher: How does the discrete emission spectrum of an element differ from the continuous spectrum of light?', 'However, the wavelengths emitted will vary from element to element.']

['Teacher: How does the emission spectrum of iron compare to the continuous spectrum of light in terms of its wavelengths?', 'The emission spectrum for iron was chosen for Figure 22.5 solely because a substantial portion of its emission spectrum is within the visible spectrum.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the difference between the discrete emission spectrum of iron and the emission spectrum of hydrogen shown in Figure 22.6?', 'Figure 22.6 shows the emission spectrum for hydrogen.']

['Teacher: How does the emission spectrum of hydrogen differ from the emission spectrum of iron in terms of the regions where the emission takes place?', 'Note that, while discrete, a large portion of hydrogen emission takes place in the ultraviolet and infrared regions.']

['Teacher: How does an absorption spectrum differ from an emission spectrum in terms of the wavelengths of light displayed?', 'Just as an emission spectrum shows all discrete wavelengths emitted by a gas, an absorption spectrum will show all light that is absorbed by a gas.']

['What characteristic of an absorption spectrum distinguishes it from an emission spectrum, and how does this affect the appearance of the spectrum?', 'Black lines exist where the wavelengths are absorbed, with the remainder of the spectrum lit by light is free to pass through.']
['Teacher: In Figure 22.7, what do the black lines indicate in the absorption spectrum of the Sun?', 'Figure 22.7 shows the absorption spectrum of the Sun.']

['What is the significance of the black lines in the absorption spectrum of the Sun?', 'The black lines are called Fraunhofer lines, and they correspond to the wavelengths absorbed by gases in the Sun’s exterior.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of quantization come into play when deriving the value of angular momentum "L" in this equation?', 'For a small object at a radius r, $$\\(I = mr^{2}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\omega = \\frac{v}{r}\\)$$, so that  $$\\(L = I\\omega = \\left( {mr^{2}} \\right)\\left( \\frac{v}{r} \\right) = mvr.\\)$$  Quantization says that the value of mvr can only be equal to h / 2, 2h / 2, 3h / 2, etc.']

["Teacher: What can you tell me about the limits of Bohr's theory?", 'There are limits to Bohr’s theory.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why Bohr's theory cannot be fully applied to multielectron atoms, including the two-electron helium atom?", 'It does not account for the interaction of bound electrons, so it cannot be fully applied to multielectron atoms, even one as simple as the two-electron helium atom.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain why Bohr's model is considered semiclassical?", 'Bohr’s model is what we call semiclassical.']
["Teacher: Why are the orbits in Bohr's model considered semiclassical?", 'The orbits are quantized (nonclassical) but are assumed to be simple circular paths (classical).']

["Teacher: How does the development of quantum mechanics challenge the assumption of well-defined orbits in Bohr's model?", 'As quantum mechanics was developed, it became clear that there are no well-defined orbits; rather, there are clouds of probability.']

["Teacher: How does the phenomenon of spectral line doublets challenge the assumptions of Bohr's theory?", 'Additionally, Bohr’s theory did not explain that some spectral lines are doublets or split into two when examined closely.']

["Teacher: What should we keep in mind when discussing these aspects of quantum mechanics in relation to Bohr's theory?", 'While we shall examine a few of those aspects of quantum mechanics in more detail, it should be kept in mind that Bohr did not fail.']

["Teacher: What are some of the important contributions made by Bohr's theory despite its limitations?", 'Rather, he made very important steps along the path to greater knowledge and laid the foundation for all of atomic physics that has since evolved.']
["Teacher: Can you please summarize the key points of DeBroglie's Waves for us?", 'Following']

["Teacher: What was the time gap between Bohr's work on the hydrogen atom and Louis de Broglie's proposal about matter having wave properties?", 'Bohr’s initial work on the hydrogen atom, a decade was to pass before Louis de Broglie proposed that matter has wave properties.']

['What observations confirmed the wave-like properties of matter?', 'The wave-like properties of matter were subsequently confirmed by observations of electron interference when scattered from crystals.']
["Why were DeBroglie's waves important for understanding the behavior of electrons in atoms?", 'Electrons can exist only in locations where they interfere constructively.']

['What analogy can be used to describe the wavelength of an electron bound to an atom?', 'When an electron is bound to an atom, its wavelength must fit into a small space, something like a standing wave on a string (see Figure 22.12).']
['What is allowed in orbits where an electron can constructively interfere with itself?', 'Orbits in which an electron can constructively interfere with itself are allowed.']
['What happens to orbits where an electron cannot constructively interfere with itself?', 'All orbits in which constructive interference cannot occur are not able to exist.']
['What term is used to describe the orbits in which electrons can constructively interfere with themselves?', 'Thus, only certain orbits are allowed.']

['What did de Broglie propose about the wave nature of electrons and its connection to the quantization of orbits?', 'The wave nature of an electron, according to de Broglie, is why the orbits are quantized!']

['Teacher: Can you explain why constructive interference occurs in a circular orbit for an electron?', 'For a circular orbit, constructive interference occurs when the electron’s wavelength fits neatly into the circumference, so that wave crests always align with crests and wave troughs align with troughs, as shown in Figure 22.12(b).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how constructive interference occurs in a circular orbit for an electron?', 'More precisely, when an integral multiple of the electron’s wavelength equals the circumference of the orbit, constructive interference is obtained.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the condition for constructive interference in a circular electron orbit can be expressed in equation form?', 'In equation form, the condition for constructive interference and an allowed electron orbit is']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example or explain how this uncertainty principle is demonstrated in real-life situations?', 'It is impossible to measure a physical quantity exactly, and greater precision in measuring one quantity produces less precision in measuring a related quantity.']

["Teacher: Can you explain what Werner Heisenberg's work on quantum mechanics and wave characteristics of particles revealed about the limit to knowledge, as mentioned in the passage?", 'It was Werner Heisenberg who first stated that limit to knowledge in 1929 as a result of his work on quantum mechanics and the wave characteristics of all particles (see Figure 22.14).']

['Teacher: What are some methods that can be used to measure the position of a moving electron according to the passage?', 'For example, you can measure the position of a moving electron by scattering light or other electrons from it.']

['Teacher: Why does scattering light or other electrons to measure the position of a moving electron impart momentum to the electron?', 'However, by doing so, you are giving the electron energy, and therefore imparting momentum to it.']

['Teacher: How does the uncertainty principle relate to the inability to precisely determine the momentum of an electron when using scattering methods to measure its position?', 'As a result, the momentum of the electron is affected and cannot be determined precisely.']

['Teacher: How does the uncertainty principle explain the relationship between the precision of measuring the position of an electron and the uncertainty in its momentum?', 'This change in momentum could be anywhere from close to zero up to the relative momentum of the electron ( $$\\(p \\approx h/\\lambda\\)$$ ).']

['Teacher: What is the mathematical expression for the uncertainty in momentum (Δp) according to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle?', 'Note that, in this case, the particle is an electron, but the principle applies to any particle.']

["Teacher: What did Heisenberg recognize about the electron's position when viewed through the model of wave-particle duality?", 'Viewing the electron through the model of wave-particle duality, Heisenberg recognized that, because a wave is not located at one fixed point in space, there is an uncertainty associated with any electron’s position.']

['Teacher: How did Heisenberg describe the uncertainty in the position of an electron when viewed through the model of wave-particle duality?', 'That uncertainty in position,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x\\)$$ , is approximately equal to the wavelength of the particle.']

["Teacher: What is the relationship between the uncertainty in the position of an electron and the wavelength of the particle, according to Heisenberg's description?", 'That is,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x \\approx \\lambda\\)$$ .']
['What trade-off does Heisenberg describe in relation to position and momentum?', 'There is an interesting trade-off between position and momentum.']

["Teacher: How does Heisenberg describe the relationship between the uncertainty in an electron's position and the uncertainty in its momentum?", 'The uncertainty in an electron’s position can be reduced by using a shorter-wavelength electron, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x \\approx \\lambda\\)$$ .']

["Teacher: What is the relationship between the uncertainty in an electron's position and the uncertainty in its momentum, according to Heisenberg's description?", 'But shortening the wavelength increases the uncertainty in momentum, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}p \\approx h/\\lambda\\)$$ .']

["How does lengthening the wavelength of an electron affect the uncertainty in its position, according to Heisenberg's description?", 'Conversely, the uncertainty in momentum can be reduced by using a longer-wavelength electron, but that increases the uncertainty in position.']

["What mathematical expression can be used to represent the trade-off between the uncertainties in position and momentum, according to Heisenberg's description?", 'Mathematically, you can express the trade-off by multiplying the uncertainties.']
['$$\\(\\text{Δ}x \\cdot \\text{Δ}p \\approx h\\)$$', 'The wavelength cancels, leaving']

['Teacher: Can you explain why, according to the passage, if one uncertainty is reduced, the other must increase in order to maintain their product as approximately equal to h?', 'Therefore, if one uncertainty is reduced, the other must increase so that their product is  $$\\(\\approx h\\)$$  .']

['Teacher: What did Heisenberg prove with the use of advanced mathematics in relation to simultaneous measurement of position and momentum?', 'With the use of advanced mathematics, Heisenberg showed that the best that can be done in a simultaneous measurement of position and momentum is']

["Teacher: What is the reason why the idea of well-defined orbits gives way to a model in which there is a cloud of probability, consistent with Heisenberg's uncertainty principle?", 'Because of the wave characteristic of matter, the idea of well-defined orbits gives way to a model in which there is a cloud of probability, consistent with Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle.']

["Teacher: What does Figure 22.15 illustrate in relation to the cloud of probability and Heisenberg's uncertainty principle?", 'Figure 22.15 shows how the principle applies to the ground state of hydrogen.']

['Teacher: Why would attempting to follow the electron in a well-defined orbit with a small-wavelength probe result in knocking the electron out of its orbit?', 'If you try to follow the electron in some well-defined orbit using a probe that has a wavelength small enough to measure position accurately, you will instead knock the electron out of its orbit.']

["Teacher: How does the concept of a cloud of probability relate to the measurement of the electron's position near the nucleus?", 'Each measurement of the electron’s position will find it to be in a definite location somewhere near the nucleus.']

['Teacher: How are the results of repeated measurements related to the concept of a cloud of probability in the quantum model of the atom?', 'Repeated measurements reveal a cloud of probability like that in the figure, with each speck the location determined by a single measurement.']
['Teacher: What kind of distribution is there in the quantum model of the atom?', 'There is not a well-defined, circular-orbit type of distribution.']

['Teacher: In what way does the quantum model of the atom differ from the classical model with regards to the distribution of electron orbits?', 'Nature again proves to be different on a small scale than on a macroscopic scale.']
['Teacher: What is the main focus or objective of the ongoing quest mentioned in the passage?', 'There is an ongoing quest to find the substructures of matter.']
['What are some of the substructures of matter being sought in the ongoing quest mentioned in the passage?', 'At one time, it was thought that atoms would be the ultimate substructure.']

['What is the current understanding about the substructure of atoms?', 'However, just when the first direct evidence of atoms was obtained, it became clear that they have a substructure and a tiny nucleus.']
['What are some of the prominent characteristics of the nucleus mentioned in the passage?', 'The nucleus itself has spectacular characteristics.']

['What are some of the effects of the decay of unstable nuclei mentioned in the passage?', 'For example, certain nuclei are unstable, and their decay emits radiations with energies millions of times greater than atomic energies.']

['What are some examples of mysteries of nature that are explained by nuclear phenomena, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Some of the mysteries of nature, such as why the core of Earth remains molten and how the Sun produces its energy, are explained by nuclear phenomena.']

['What are some of the aspects of the exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus that have been revealed?', 'The exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus has revealed new fundamental particles, forces, and conservation laws.']

['What are some of the key terms related to the exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus that have been revealed?', 'That exploration has evolved into a search for further underlying structures, such as quarks.']
['What is the focus of this section in the textbook?', 'In this section, we will explore the fundamentals of the nucleus and nuclear radioactivity.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain the role of the neutron and proton in the structure of the nucleus?", 'At this point, you are likely familiar with the neutron and proton, the two fundamental particles that make up the nucleus of an atom.']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Can you tell me what distinguishes the neutron from the proton in terms of their properties?', 'Those two particles, collectively called nucleons, make up the small interior portion of the atom.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, can you explain why the neutron is slightly more massive than the proton in terms of their properties?', 'Both particles have nearly the same mass, although the neutron is about two parts in 1,000 more massive.']

['Teacher: How does the mass of a proton compare to the mass of electrons?', 'The mass of a proton is equivalent to 1,836 electrons, while the mass of a neutron is equivalent to that of 1,839 electrons.']
['How does the mass of a neutron compare to the mass of electrons?', 'That said, each of the particles is significantly more massive than the electron.']

['Teacher: Why is it most reasonable to measure the mass of objects on the scale of nucleons and atoms in terms of atoms?', 'When describing the mass of objects on the scale of nucleons and atoms, it is most reasonable to measure their mass in terms of atoms.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the reason behind defining the atomic mass unit (u) based on the mass of a neutral carbon atom?', 'The atomic mass unit (u) was originally defined so that a neutral carbon atom would have a mass of exactly 12 u.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the atomic mass unit (u) to be defined based on the mass of a neutral carbon atom instead of other elements?', 'Given that protons and neutrons are approximately the same mass, that there are six protons and six neutrons in a carbon atom, and that the mass of an electron is minuscule in comparison, measuring this way allows for both protons and neutrons to have masses close to 1 u.']

['Teacher: What information does Table 22.1 provide about the mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons on the new scale?', 'Table 22.1 shows the mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons on the new scale.']
['Teacher: What is another useful mass unit on the atomic scale?', 'Another other useful mass unit on the atomic scale is the  $$\\(\\text{M}\\text{e}\\text{V}/c^{2}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the mass unit $$\\(\\text{M}\\text{e}\\text{V}/c^{2}\\)$$ is useful in the equation $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$?', 'While rarely used in most contexts, it is convenient when one uses the equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$, as will be addressed later in this text.']

['Teacher: What are the two other important quantities that we need to consider in order to more completely characterize nuclei?', 'To more completely characterize nuclei, let us also consider two other important quantities: the atomic number and the mass number.']
['Teacher: Great! Now, what does the mass number, A, represent within a nucleus?', 'The atomic number, Z, represents the number of protons within a nucleus.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, what does the mass number, A, represent within a nucleus?', 'That value determines the elemental quality of each atom.']

['Teacher: Fantastic! Can you explain in your own words how the mass number, A, is related to the elemental quality of an atom?', 'Every carbon atom, for instance, has a Z value of 6, whereas every oxygen atom has a Z value of 8.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you now tell me how the mass number, A, is related to the elemental quality of an atom?", 'For clarification, only oxygen atoms may have a Z value of 8.']
["Teacher: That's correct! So what does the mass number, A, tell us about the elemental quality of an atom?", 'If the Z value is not 8, the atom cannot be oxygen.']
['Teacher: What does the mass number, A, represent in an atom?', 'The mass number, A, represents the total number of protons and neutrons, or nucleons, within an atom.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the mass number is the total number of protons and neutrons in an atom?', 'For an ordinary carbon atom the mass number would be 12, as there are typically six neutrons accompanying the six protons within the atom.']
['Teacher: How can you determine the mass of an atom if you know the number of protons and neutrons?', 'In the case of carbon, the mass would be exactly 12 u.']
['Teacher: How does the atomic mass of an atom compare to its mass number?', 'For oxygen, with a mass number of 16, the atomic mass is 15.994915 u.']
['Teacher: Why can the difference between the atomic mass of an atom and its mass number be ignored for most scenarios?', 'Of course, the difference is minor and can be ignored for most scenarios.']

['Teacher: Why is the mass of an electron usually ignored when determining the atomic mass of an atom?', 'Again, because the mass of an electron is so small compared to the nucleons, the mass number and the atomic mass can be essentially equivalent.']
['Teacher: What does the figure 22.16 show?', 'Figure 22.16 shows an example of Lithium-7, which has an atomic number of 3 and a mass number of 7.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose or intent of the mass number when differentiating between various isotopes of an atom?', 'The intent of the mass number is to differentiate between various isotopes of an atom.']

['What is the significance of the number of neutrons in determining the isotopes of an atom?', 'The term isotope refers to the variation of atoms based upon the number of neutrons within their nucleus.']

['How does the number of neutrons within a carbon atom affect its classification as an isotope?', 'While it is most common for there to be six neutrons accompanying the six protons within a carbon atom, it is possible to find carbon atoms with seven neutrons or eight neutrons.']

['What is the primary distinction between carbon-13 and carbon-14 atoms?', 'Those carbon atoms are respectively referred to as carbon-13 and carbon-14 atoms, with their mass numbers being their primary distinction.']

['Why is it important to understand the isotope distinction and how it relates to the number of neutrons within an atom?', 'The isotope distinction is an important one to make, as the number of neutrons within an atom can affect a number of its properties, not the least of which is nuclear stability.']

['Teacher: How are the atomic number and mass number typically represented in the nuclide form?', 'To more easily identify various atoms, their atomic number and mass number are typically written in a form of representation called the nuclide.']

['What does the form of representation called the nuclide look like?', 'The nuclide form appears as follows: $$\\({}_{A}^{Z}X{}_{N}\\)$$, where X is the atomic symbol and N represents the number of neutrons.']
['Teacher: What notation is used to express nuclides in the passage?', 'Let us look at a few examples of nuclides expressed in the  $$\\({}_{A}^{Z}X{}_{N}\\)$$  notation.']

['What is the notation used to express the nuclides in the passage?', 'The nucleus of the simplest atom, hydrogen, is a single proton, or  $$\\({}_{}^{}{}\\)$$ (the zero for no neutrons is often omitted).']
['What is the atomic number Z of hydrogen?', 'To check the symbol, refer to the periodic table—you see that the atomic number Z of hydrogen is 1.']
['What is the mass number A of hydrogen?', 'Since you are given that there are no neutrons, the mass number A is also 1.']

['What is the notation used to express the nucleus of deuterium?', 'There is a scarce form of hydrogen found in nature called deuterium; its nucleus has one proton and one neutron and, hence, twice the mass of common hydrogen.']
['What is the mass number A of deuterium?', 'The symbol for deuterium is, thus,  $$\\({}_{1}^{2}\\text{H}{}_{2}\\)$$ .']

['What is the notation used to express the nucleus of tritium?', 'An even rarer—and radioactive—form of hydrogen is called tritium, since it has a single proton and two neutrons, and it is written  $$\\({}_{1}^{3}\\text{H}{}_{2}\\)$$ .']
['What is the mass number A of tritium?', 'The three varieties of hydrogen have nearly identical chemistries, but the nuclei differ greatly in mass, stability, and other characteristics.']
['What term is used to describe the different nuclei of hydrogen with different mass numbers?', 'Again, the different nuclei are referred to as isotopes of the same element.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why there is redundancy in the symbols A, X, Z, and N in the context of the structure of the nucleus?', 'There is some redundancy in the symbols A, X, Z, and N.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now, can you explain how the symbols A, X, Z, and N help us determine the atomic structure of an element?", 'If the element X is known, then Z can be found in a periodic table.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, can you explain how we can determine the mass number (A) of an element if we know the atomic number (Z) and the number of neutrons (N)?', 'If both A and X are known, then N can also be determined by first finding Z; then, N  = A  – Z.']
['What is the advantage of using the symbols A, X, Z, and N in the notation for nuclides?', 'Thus the simpler notation for nuclides is']
['Teacher: Which type of radioactive decay is sufficient and most commonly used in the context of ${}^{A}X$?', 'which is sufficient and is most commonly used.']

['Teacher: What are the three isotopes of hydrogen in the context of ${}^{A}X$?', 'For example, in this simpler notation, the three isotopes of hydrogen are  $$\\({}^{1}\\text{H}\\)$$, $$\\({}^{2}\\text{H}\\)$$, and  $$\\({}^{3}\\text{H}\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: How do we determine the number of neutrons (N) in an isotope of uranium, such as ${}^{238}U$, using the information from the periodic table?', 'For $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$, should we need to know, wecan determine that Z = 92 for uranium from the periodic table, and thus, N = 238 − 92 = 146.']
['Teacher: What did the French physicist Antoine Henri Becquerel notice in 1896?', 'In 1896, the French physicist Antoine Henri Becquerel (1852–1908) noticed something strange.']

['Teacher: What strange phenomenon did Antoine Henri Becquerel observe when he placed pitchblende on a photographic plate inside a completely opaque envelope?', 'When a uranium-rich mineral called pitchblende was placed on a completely opaque envelope containing a photographic plate, it darkened spots on the photographic plate..']

['Teacher: What term is used to describe the phenomenon in which pitchblende darkened spots on a photographic plate when placed inside a completely opaque envelope?', 'Becquerel reasoned that the pitchblende must emit invisible rays capable of penetrating the opaque material.']

['What did Antoine Henri Becquerel conclude about the phenomenon of the pitchblende darkening spots on the photographic plate without any light shining on it?', 'Stranger still was that no light was shining on the pitchblende, which means that the pitchblende was emitting the invisible rays continuously without having any energy input!']

["What does Einstein's equation, \\(E = mc^{2}\\), explain in relation to the violation of the law of conservation of energy observed by Becquerel with the pitchblende?", 'There is an apparent violation of the law of conservation of energy, one that scientists can now explain using Einstein’s famous equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']

["Why did scientists conclude that Becquerel's rays originate in the nuclei of atoms?", 'It was soon evident that Becquerel’s rays originate in the nuclei of the atoms and have other unique characteristics.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now let's move on to a different type of reaction. Can you tell me what type of reactions we will be focusing on next?", 'To this point, most reactions you have studied have been chemical reactions, which are reactions involving the electrons surrounding the atoms.']

["Q: What type of reactions do Becquerel's rays imply as not originating with electrons, but within the nucleus of an atom?", 'However, two types of experimental evidence implied that Becquerel’s rays did not originate with electrons, but instead within the nucleus of an atom.']
['Teacher: Which elements are found to be associated with radiation, as mentioned in the passage?', 'First, the radiation is found to be only associated with certain elements, such as uranium.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why whether uranium was in the form of an element or compound was irrelevant to its radiation, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Whether uranium was in the form of an element or compound was irrelevant to its radiation.']

['Teacher: What are the factors that do not affect the presence of radiation from uranium, as mentioned in the passage?', 'In addition, the presence of radiation does not vary with temperature, pressure, or ionization state of the uranium atom.']

['Teacher: Why do the factors such as temperature, pressure, and ionization state of the uranium atom not affect the presence of radiation from uranium?', 'Since all of those factors affect electrons in an atom, the radiation cannot come from electron transitions, as atomic spectra do.']

['Teacher: What is the second piece of evidence that supports the claim that radiation cannot be atomic?', 'The huge energy emitted during each event is the second piece of evidence that the radiation cannot be atomic.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the energy emitted during each nuclear radiation event is considered to be evidence that radiation cannot be atomic?', 'Nuclear radiation has energies on the order of 106 eV per event, which is much greater than typical atomic energies that are a few eV, such as those observed in spectra and chemical reactions, and more than ten times as high as the most energetic X-rays.']
['Teacher: What is necessary in order to answer those questions about radioactivity and nuclear forces?', 'To answer those questions, it is necessary to look into the structure of the nucleus.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why looking into the structure of the nucleus is necessary to answer questions about radioactivity and nuclear forces?', 'Though it is perhaps surprising, you will find that many of the same principles that we observe on a macroscopic level still apply to the nucleus.']

['Teacher: How does a variety of experiments suggest that a nucleus behaves?', 'A variety of experiments indicate that a nucleus behaves something like a tightly packed ball of nucleons, as illustrated in Figure 22.17.']
['Teacher: What does the passage suggest about the behavior of nucleons in a nucleus?', 'Those nucleons have large kinetic energies and, thus, move rapidly in very close contact.']

['Teacher: How do nucleons in a nucleus behave when subjected to a large force like a collision with another nucleus?', 'Nucleons can be separated by a large force, such as in a collision with another nucleus, but strongly resist being pushed closer together.']

['What is one piece of evidence that suggests nucleons are closely packed in a nucleus?', 'The most compelling evidence that nucleons are closely packed in a nucleus is that the radius of a nucleus, r, is found to be approximately']
['Teacher: Based on the equation you mentioned, can you explain the relationship between the radius of the nucleus and the mass number of the nucleus?', 'Note that  $$\\(r^{3} \\propto A\\)$$ .']

['Teacher: Excellent observation! Can you now explain why the volume of a nucleus is proportional to the number of nucleons in it?', 'Since many nuclei are spherical, and the volume of a sphere is  $$\\(V = \\left( \\frac{4}{3} \\right)\\pi r^{3}\\)$$, we see that  $$\\(V \\propto A\\)$$ —that is, the volume of a nucleus is proportional to the number of nucleons in it.']

['Teacher: Great explanation! And what can you conclude about the density of a nucleus based on this information?', 'That is what you expect if you pack nucleons so close that there is no empty space between them.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the repulsive forces between protons in the nucleus are expected to be tremendous?', 'After all, the nucleus is very small and its protons, being positive, should exert tremendous repulsive forces on one another.']

["Teacher: That's correct! So, based on the repulsive forces between protons, what should be happening to the nucleus?", 'Considering that, it seems that the nucleus would be forced apart, not together!']

['Teacher: What force is responsible for holding the nucleus together and causing it to form a densely packed ball of nucleons?', 'The answer is that a previously unknown force holds the nucleus together and makes it into a tightly packed ball of nucleons.']
['Teacher: Very good! Now, can you please explain the characteristics or properties of the strong nuclear force?', 'This force is known as the strong nuclear force.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Can you tell me what is the value of the nucleon-nucleon separation, represented by the symbol $$\\(r_{o} =\\)$$, in this context?', 'The strong force has such a short range that it quickly fall to zero over a distance of only 10–15 meters.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, based on what you just said about the strong nuclear force, can you provide an approximate value for the nucleon-nucleon separation in this context?", 'However, like glue, it is very strong when the nucleons get close to one another.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how the balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces contributes to maintaining the nucleus' spherical shape?", 'The balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces is what allows the nucleus to maintain its spherical shape.']

['Teacher: What would happen if the electromagnetic force overcomes the nuclear force within the nucleus?', 'If, for any reason, the electromagnetic force should overcome the nuclear force, components of the nucleus would be projected outward, creating the very radiation that Becquerel discovered!']

['Teacher: How does Table 22.2 help us understand the reasons behind the possible breaking apart of the nucleus?', 'Understanding why the nucleus would break apart can be partially explained using Table 22.2.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the relationship between the balance of the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force as shown in Table 22.2?', 'The balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force is a tenuous one.']

['Teacher: How does the balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force contribute to the stability of the nucleus?', 'Recall that the attractive strong nuclear force exists between any two nucleons and acts over a very short range while the weaker repulsive electromagnetic force only acts between protons, although over a larger range.']

['Teacher: Based on the information you just provided about the balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force, what can happen if there is an imperfect balance between neutrons and protons in the nucleus?', 'Considering the interactions, an imperfect balance between neutrons and protons can result in a nuclear reaction, with the result of regaining equilibrium.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the large number of protons present in uranium-rich pitchblende in relation to the radiation discovered by Becquerel?', 'The radiation discovered by Becquerel was due to the large number of protons present in his uranium-rich pitchblende.']

['Teacher: How did the large number of protons in uranium-rich pitchblende affect the electromagnetic force and the strong nuclear force?', 'In short, the large number of protons caused the electromagnetic force to be greater than the strong nuclear force.']

['What is the relation between the large number of protons in uranium-rich pitchblende and the need for the nucleus to undergo alpha (α) decay?', 'To regain stability, the nucleus needed to undergo a nuclear reaction called alpha (α) decay.']
['Teacher: What is the definition of radioactivity?', 'Radioactivity refers to the act of emitting particles or energy from the nucleus.']

["What is Becquerel's experiment commonly associated with?", 'When the uranium nucleus emits energetic nucleons in Becquerel’s experiment, the radioactive process causes the nucleus to alter in structure.']
['Teacher: What is the definition of radioactive decay?', 'The alteration is called radioactive decay.']
['What is the difference between radioactivity and radioactive decay?', 'Any substance that undergoes radioactive decay is said to be radioactive.']

['What is the relationship between radioactivity, radioactive decay, and radiation?', 'That those terms share a root with the term radiation should not be too surprising, as they all relate to the transmission of energy.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the type of decay that occurs when there are an excess number of protons in the nucleus of an atom?', 'Alpha decay refers to the type of decay that takes place when too many protons exist in the nucleus.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Alpha decay is indeed the most common type of decay. Can you explain what happens to the nucleus during alpha decay to regain equilibrium between its two competing internal forces?", 'It is the most common type of decay and causes the nucleus to regain equilibrium between its two competing internal forces.']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Can you explain why the nucleus specifically ejects two protons and two neutrons during alpha decay?', 'During alpha decay, the nucleus ejects two protons and two neutrons, allowing the strong nuclear force to regain balance with the repulsive electromagnetic force.']
['What does the nuclear equation for an alpha decay process represent?', 'The nuclear equation for an alpha decay process can be shown as follows.']
["Teacher: What happens to the original nuclide's atomic number when an alpha particle is ejected?", 'By ejecting an alpha particle, the original nuclide decreases in atomic number.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why the original nuclide's atomic number decreases when an alpha particle is ejected?", 'That means that Becquerel’s uranium nucleus, upon decaying, is actually transformed into thorium, two atomic numbers lower on the periodic table!']
['Teacher: How is the process of changing elemental composition referred to in this context?', 'The process of changing elemental composition is called transmutation.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the combination of the two protons and two neutrons ejected from the nucleus to form a helium nucleus?', 'Note that the two protons and two neutrons ejected from the nucleus combine to form a helium nucleus.']

['What term is used to describe the process of the ejected helium ion acquiring two electrons to become a stable helium atom?', 'Shortly after decay, the ejected helium ion typically acquires two electrons to become a stable helium atom.']

['What is the term used to describe the principle that physical conservation still takes place despite the elemental change?', 'Finally, it is important to see that, despite the elemental change, physical conservation still takes place.']

['What principle is demonstrated by the fact that the mass number of the new element and the alpha particle together equal the mass number of the original element?', 'The mass number of the new element and the alpha particle together equal the mass number of the original element.']

['What principle is demonstrated by the fact that the net charge of all particles involved remains the same before and after the transmutation?', 'Also, the net charge of all particles involved remains the same before and after the transmutation.']

['Teacher: What is another type of radioactive decay that occurs when there is an imbalance between neutrons and protons within the nucleus, similar to alpha decay?', 'Like alpha decay, beta ( βββ ) decay also takes place when there is an imbalance between neutrons and protons within the nucleus.']

["Teacher: That's correct, the transformation of a neutron into a proton and electron (or vice versa) is a key process in beta decay. Can you explain why this transformation occurs?", 'For beta decay, however, a neutron is transformed into a proton and electron or vice versa.']

['Why does the total mass number of the atom remain the same during beta decay?', 'The transformation allows for the total mass number of the atom to remain the same, although the atomic number will increase by one (or decrease by one).']
['What happens to the atomic number during beta decay?', 'Once again, the transformation of the neutron allows for a rebalancing of the strong nuclear and electromagnetic forces.']
['What does the nuclear equation for a beta decay process usually involve?', 'The nuclear equation for a beta decay process is shown below.']
['Teacher: What does the symbol $$\\(v\\)$$ represent in the equation?', 'The symbol  $$\\(v\\)$$  in the equation above stands for a high-energy particle called the neutrino.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the change that occurs in the values of Z and N when a nucleus emits a positron?', 'A nucleus may also emit a positron, and in that case Z decreases and N increases.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens to the overall charge of the nucleus when it emits a positron?', 'It is beyond the scope of this section and will be discussed in further detail in the chapter on particles.']

['Teacher: Can you briefly explain what happens to the mass number and the charge in all beta-decay reactions?', 'It is worth noting, however, that the mass number and charge in all beta-decay reactions are conserved.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why gamma decay is considered a unique form of radiation that does not involve balancing forces within the nucleus?', 'Gamma decay is a unique form of radiation that does not involve balancing forces within the nucleus.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now, can you explain why the process of gamma decay results in the emission of high-energy photons?", 'Gamma decay occurs when a nucleus drops from an excited state to the ground state.']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation. Can you provide an example of how an excited nucleus can transition to the ground state through gamma decay?', 'Recall that such a change in energy state will release energy from the nucleus in the form of a photon.']

['Teacher: How does the energy associated with the photon emitted during gamma decay compare to the energy associated with an X-ray?', 'The energy associated with the photon emitted is so great that its wavelength is shorter than that of an X-ray.']
['What does the nuclear equation for gamma decay typically look like?', 'Its nuclear equation is as follows.']
['Teacher: How do the charges of the three radiated particles compare?', 'The charges of the three radiated particles differ.']
['Teacher: What about the charges of beta particles and gamma rays?', 'Alpha particles, with two protons, carry a net charge of +2.']
['Teacher: How about the charges of gamma rays?', 'Beta particles, with one electron, carry a net charge of –1.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the charges of gamma rays?', 'Meanwhile, gamma rays are solely photons, or light, and carry no charge.']

['Teacher: How does the difference in charge affect the impact of the three radiations on surrounding substances?', 'The difference in charge plays an important role in how the three radiations affect surrounding substances.']

['Teacher: How do alpha particles interact with ions in the air and electrons within metals?', 'Alpha particles, being highly charged, will quickly interact with ions in the air and electrons within metals.']
['Teacher: Why do alpha particles have a short range and short penetrating distance in most materials?', 'As a result, they have a short range and short penetrating distance in most materials.']
['Teacher: How do beta particles interact with ions in the air and electrons within metals?', 'Beta particles, being slightly less charged, have a larger range and larger penetrating distance.']

['Teacher: Why do gamma rays have little electric interaction with particles and travel much farther compared to alpha and beta particles?', 'Gamma rays, on the other hand, have little electric interaction with particles and travel much farther.']

['Teacher: What is the process that occurs to unstable nuclei?', 'Unstable nuclei decay.']

["Teacher: That's correct, some nuclides decay faster than others. Can you tell me what term we use to describe the rate at which radioactive substances decay?", 'However, some nuclides decay faster than others.']

["Teacher: That's true! We often measure the rate at which radioactive substances decay using a specific term. Can you recall what term we use for this purpose?", 'For example, radium and polonium, discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie, decay faster than uranium.']

["Teacher: That's correct! So, what specific term do we use to measure the rate at which radioactive substances decay, and how is it related to the shorter lifetimes and greater rate of decay of radium and polonium compared to uranium?", 'That means they have shorter lifetimes, producing a greater rate of decay.']

['What are the specific terms we use to measure the lifetime and rate of decay of radioactive substances?', 'Here we will explore half-life and activity, the quantitative terms for lifetime and rate of decay.']

['Teacher: Where can we find information about the decrease in the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample with time?', 'The answer can be found by examining Figure 22.24, which shows how the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample decreases with time.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the half-life represents in the context of radioactive decay?', 'The time in which half of the original number of nuclei decay is defined as the half-life,  $$\\(t_{\\frac{1}{2}}\\)$$ .']
['Teacher: What happens to the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample after one half-life has passed?', 'After one half-life passes, half of the remaining nuclei will decay in the next half-life.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample and the number of half-lives that have passed?', 'Then, half of that amount in turn decays in the following half-life.']

['Teacher: According to the information you just mentioned, what happens to the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample after two half-lives have passed?', 'Therefore, the number of radioactive nuclei decreases from N to N / 2 in one half-life, to N / 4 in the next, to N / 8 in the next, and so on.']
['Teacher: Why is nuclear decay considered a purely statistical process?', 'Nuclear decay is an example of a purely statistical process.']

['Teacher: What does the term "rate of decay" generally indicate in this passage?', 'Generally, it means the number of decays per unit time is very high.']

['Teacher: How is radioactive dating or radiometric dating achieved?', 'Radioactive dating or radiometric dating is a clever use of naturally occurring radioactivity.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how carbon-14 dating utilizes radioactive dating or radiometric dating principles?', 'Its most familiar application is carbon-14 dating.']

['What happens to the carbon-14 isotope in the atmosphere after it is produced by solar neutrino interactions?', 'Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon that is produced when solar neutrinos strike  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  particles within the atmosphere.']

['What is the fate of carbon-14 in the biosphere after it is consumed by living organisms?', 'Radioactive carbon has the same chemistry as stable carbon, and so it mixes into the biosphere, where it is consumed and becomes part of every living organism.']

['What can you do with the number of carbon nuclei in an object?', 'Carbon-14 has an abundance of 1.3 parts per trillion of normal carbon, so if you know the number of carbon nuclei in an object (perhaps determined by mass and Avogadro’s number), you can multiply that number by  $$\\(1.3\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 12}\\)$$  to find the number of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei within the object.']

['What is the significance of the half-life of carbon-14 in radiometric dating?', 'Over time, carbon-14 will naturally decay back to  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  with a half-life of 5,730 years (note that this is an example of beta decay).']

['What can scientists measure in a sample to determine the age of an organism using radiometric dating?', 'When an organism dies, carbon exchange with the environment ceases, and  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{']
['What can scientists measure in a sample to determine the age of an organism using radiometric dating?', 'C}\\)$$  is not replenished.']

['How can scientists determine the age of an artifact, such as mummy wrappings, using radiometric dating?', 'By comparing the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  in an artifact, such as mummy wrappings, with the normal abundance in living tissue, it is possible to determine the artifact’s age (or time since death).']

['What is the range of accuracy for carbon-14 dating in terms of the age of biological tissues?', 'Carbon-14 dating can be used for biological tissues as old as 50 or 60 thousand years, but is most accurate for younger samples, since the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei in them is greater.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the significance of the Shroud of Turin in the context of radiometric dating methods?', 'One of the most famous cases of carbon-14 dating involves the Shroud of Turin, a long piece of fabric purported to be the burial shroud of Jesus (see Figure 22.25).']
['Teacher: How does the Shroud of Turin relate to carbon-14 dating?', 'This relic was first displayed in Turin in 1354 and was denounced as a fraud at that time by a French bishop.']

['Teacher: How does the negative imprint on the Shroud of Turin contribute to the controversy surrounding its authenticity?', 'Its remarkable negative imprint of an apparently crucified body resembles the then-accepted image of Jesus.']
['Teacher: What method was used to determine the age of the Shroud of Turin?', 'As a result, the relic has been remained controversial throughout the centuries.']

["Teacher: How did the refinement of the carbon-14 dating process in 1988 contribute to the study of the Shroud of Turin's age?", 'Carbon-14 dating was not performed on the shroud until 1988, when the process had been refined to the point where only a small amount of material needed to be destroyed.']

['Teacher: What were the results of the carbon-14 dating performed on the Shroud of Turin in 1988?', 'Samples were tested at three independent laboratories, each being given four pieces of cloth, with only one unidentified piece from the shroud, to avoid prejudice.']

['Teacher: Based on the results of the carbon-14 dating, what conclusion can be drawn about the age of the Shroud of Turin?', 'All three laboratories found samples of the shroud contain 92 percent of the  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  found in living tissues, allowing the shroud to be dated (see How Old is the Shroud of Turin?).']
['Teacher: What key terms were discussed in the previous section on naturally occurring nuclear decay?', 'The previous section dealt with naturally occurring nuclear decay.']

['Teacher: Can you recall any specific key terms related to naturally occurring nuclear decay that were discussed in the previous section?', 'Without human intervention, some nuclei will change composition in order to achieve a stable equilibrium.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a key term related to the less-natural process discussed in this section?', 'This section delves into a less-natural process.']
['Teacher: Can you elaborate on what less-natural process is discussed in this section?', 'The answer to this question is yes.']

['Teacher: What are the two distinct methods discussed in this section that humankind has used to manipulate the atom and release its internal energy?', 'Through two distinct methods, humankind has discovered multiple ways of manipulating the atom to release its internal energy.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the process of nuclear fission in more detail?', 'In simplest terms, nuclear fission is the splitting of an atomic bond.']

['Teacher: What is the result or outcome of splitting an atomic bond during nuclear fission?', 'Given that it requires great energy separate two nucleons, it may come as a surprise to learn that splitting a nucleus can release vast potential energy.']

['Teacher: Why is it surprising that splitting a nucleus during nuclear fission can release vast potential energy?', 'And although it is true that huge amounts of energy can be released, considerable effort is needed to do so in practice.']
['Teacher: What is the natural decay process of an unstable atom, and how long might it take for it to occur?', 'An unstable atom will naturally decay, but it may take millions of years to do so.']
['Teacher: What is the role of a physical catalyst in the process of nuclear fission?', 'As a result, a physical catalyst is necessary to produce useful energy through nuclear fission.']

["Teacher: How does the catalyst, in the form of a free neutron, cause nuclear fission in a high-mass atom's nucleus?", 'The catalyst typically occurs in the form of a free neutron, projected directly at the nucleus of a high-mass atom.']

['Teacher: How is the effect of a neutron strike on the nucleus described in Figure 22.26?', 'As shown in Figure 22.26, a neutron strike can cause the nucleus to elongate, much like a drop of liquid water.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the model is referred to as the liquid drop model?', 'This is why the model is known as the liquid drop model.']

['Teacher: Why does the repulsive electromagnetic force overcome the short-range strong nuclear force when the nucleus elongates in the liquid drop model?', 'As the nucleus elongates, nucleons are no longer so tightly packed, and the repulsive electromagnetic force can overcome the short-range strong nuclear force.']

['Teacher: What happens when the two ends of the elongated nucleus in the liquid drop model fly apart?', 'The imbalance of forces can result in the two ends of the drop flying apart, with some of the nuclear binding energy released to the surroundings.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the splitting of nuclei in nuclear fission leads to substantial consequences?', 'As you can imagine, the consequences of the nuclei splitting are substantial.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you elaborate on how the release of energy and neutrons during nuclear fission contributes to the substantial consequences?", 'When a nucleus is split, it is not only energy that is released, but a small number of neutrons as well.']

['How does the release of neutrons during nuclear fission contribute to causing further fission in other nuclei?', 'Those neutrons have the potential to cause further fission in other nuclei, especially if they are directed back toward the other nuclei by a dense shield or neutron reflector (see part (d) of Figure 22.26).']
['Teacher: What happens to every neutron produced by fission?', 'However, not every neutron produced by fission induces further fission.']

['Teacher: Exactly! Now, can you explain what happens when some neutrons interact with a nucleus without causing it to split?', 'Some neutrons escape the fissionable material, while others interact with a nucleus without making it split.']

['Teacher: How can we enhance the number of fissions produced by neutrons?', 'We can enhance the number of fissions produced by neutrons by having a large amount of fissionable material as well as a neutron reflector.']
['Teacher: Why is the critical mass important for self-sustained fission of a nuclide?', 'The minimum amount necessary for self-sustained fission of a given nuclide is called its critical mass.']
['Teacher: What is the significance of a nuclide producing more neutrons per fission?', 'Some nuclides, such as 239Pu, produce more neutrons per fission than others, such as 235U.']

['Teacher: How does the ability of a nuclide to produce more neutrons per fission affect its suitability for use as a fuel in nuclear reactors?', 'Additionally, some nuclides are easier to make fission than others.']

['Teacher: Why is it advantageous for a nuclide to be easier to fission when considering its suitability as a fuel in nuclear reactors?', 'In particular, 235U and 239Pu are easier to fission than the much more abundant 238U.']
['Teacher: How does the size of the critical mass of a nuclide affect its suitability as a fuel in nuclear reactors?', 'Both factors affect critical mass, which is smallest for 239Pu.']
['What term is commonly used to refer to the self-sustained fission of nuclei?', 'The self-sustained fission of nuclei is commonly referred to as a chain reaction, as shown in Figure 22.27.']
['Teacher: What can have runaway results in the context of nuclear fission?', 'A chain reaction can have runaway results.']

['What causes the number of nuclear reactions to increase exponentially in a chain reaction?', 'If each atomic split results in two nuclei producing a new fission, the number of nuclear reactions will increase exponentially.']

['Teacher: How does the exponential increase in the number of nuclear reactions affect the overall energy release in a chain reaction?', 'One fission will produce two atoms, the next round of fission will create four atoms, the third round eight atoms, and so on.']

['Teacher: How does the exponential increase in the number of nuclear reactions impact the overall power of the atomic reaction?', 'Of course, each time fission occurs, more energy will be emitted, further increasing the power of the atomic reaction.']
['What happens if more than two neutrons create fission reactions each round?', 'And that is just if two neutrons create fission reactions each round.']

['Teacher: What happens if more than two neutrons create fission reactions each round and the number of nuclear reactions continues to increase exponentially?', 'Perhaps you can now see why so many people consider atomic energy to be an exciting energy source!']
